And why are artists u-hum u-hum sooo scared of AI if there are soooo good as they think? I even think the labels are thinking AI to create new music. They don't have to deal with the attitude of their stars anymore. And let's be honnest. What do you hear on the radio these days? Great music? Nope. The same things over and over again. So be original and create something new. Ow but no covers because that's a kind of stealing and a lot of times even degrading the original product. And finaly where do humans get inspired? Oh by other artists and sometimes 'using' some stuff is okay then? It's quit simple. Most of the great songwriters are or old, or death. There is no more Jim Steinman, and many others who created music that lasted generations and generations to come. So if a good AI band, stand up. I will embrace it. And to the ones who hate AI. Try harder to be really creative. Because I don't like what I hear on my radio. Keep rocking and listen to Lustful Luminaries. I love them and I don't care who they are.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2025-07-06T00:25:28Z", "updated_at": "2025-07-06T00:25:28Z"}, {"author": "@John_R_Fite", "text": "They’re not that great. Hard to see how they got so big. My AI music is way better…😂", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2025-07-04T20:37:22Z", "updated_at": "2025-07-04T20:37:22Z"}, {"author": "@kingdadu", "text": "How human are modern pop songs?  Maybe the vocals at most, but even those are extremely processed.  This context makes it hard to have a leg to stand on.  Maybe it will encourage a more raw natural type of music as a reaction.  I don't want to think "Dust on the Wind" is a good song, but it actually sticks in my head.  It's not the greatest song, but it's not terrible either if I'm honest about it.  The lyrics are generic garbage lyrics, but it's hard to not see where this is going.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2025-07-05T21:39:16Z", "updated_at": "2025-07-05T21:39:16Z"}, {"author": "@PeterJRam", "text": "Not to be mean, but the Velvet Sundown sounds like a band whose UN-INSPIRING material did not make it past the cutting room floor (or the recycle bin). So the question is more like if it is moral/legal to make money from streaming, that is not real. Even if AI generated music exist, please don't let it kill human artistry, because it might create art bubbles where not everyone is invited into, in the future, due to the risk of the art being copied. title: How AI Eats Consulting
top_comments:
[{"author": "@CV-wo9hj", "text": "I love how the industry continually renames things that already exist. Technical account managers (TAM) existed for 20 years. The job was simple that would be embedded into a client full-time to maximise the capability of the vendor software for the customer. We've just given them a cool title deployed engineer🤣", "like_count": 66, "published_at": "2025-07-02T23:40:38Z", "updated_at": "2025-07-02T23:42:38Z"}, {"author": "@Dori_1111", "text": "A senior executive at a consulting firm told me: “AI will greatly benefit consulting because now we can do much more for our clients, for less.” Companies still need industry expertise, experience, and creativity. AI just enhances what’s possible. Expect the big consulting firms to partner with AI providers to drive faster adoption across industries.", "like_count": 24, "published_at": "2025-07-04T16:18:20Z", "updated_at": "2025-07-04T16:18:20Z"}, {"author": "@mrcarruth", "text": "I would say consultants actually get a boost from this  as they can scale their knowledge and focus more on relationships.", "like_count": 24, "published_at": "2025-07-04T14:50:51Z", "updated_at": "2025-07-04T14:50:51Z"}, {"author": "@TheTeaParty320", "text": "I’m glad I’m an expert at making and bottling jams, spreads and chutney.", "like_count": 18, "published_at": "2025-07-06T04:56:53Z", "updated_at": "2025-07-06T04:56:53Z"}, {"author": "@ponder4life", "text": "I’m a consultant, and I can tell you, we’re at risk. If someone builds an agentic SaaS product (which they are) that sets itself up, connects to APIs, handles most of the heavy lifting, data conversions, automates updates, and is fully managed by the company behind the product, there really won’t be much left for consultants like us to do.", "like_count": 7, "published_at": "2025-07-15T04:48:50Z", "updated_at": "2025-07-15T04:48:50Z"}, {"author": "@vijayrangan", "text": "This role has been around for a VERY long time. Its called a solutions engineer. While traditionally solutions engineers aren't programmers, FDSE's fall more into the category of a solutions engineer than consultant. IMHO.", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2025-07-07T17:01:54Z", "updated_at": "2025-07-07T17:01:54Z"}, {"author": "@will580", "text": "Consulting will stay and I'll tell you why. Junior employees know how to use AI and are upto date on the latest tech but senior management only listen to people who they pay big $$$ for...typically consultants", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2025-07-26T07:59:18Z", "updated_at": "2025-07-26T07:59:18Z"}, {"author": "@makeaniiimpactYT", "text": "The fact that the barrier to entry to launch competing products is lower, you need more experienced humans (aka consultants) to ramp up faster and with direction (strategy) and continuous improvement (UX & user research) to stay ahead of your competition, otherwise you will be copied and passed up. Yes, a high tide (AI) raises all boats, but if your process, people, product are shit, adding AI to it as everyone will as well, doesn't make you any better off than the competition that was already better than you.", "like_count": 10, "published_at": "2025-07-03T16:46:19Z", "updated_at": "2025-07-03T16:46:42Z"}, {"author": "@MyAnalyser", "text": "Forward deployed engineer. They literally invented a new word for something that exists since 1990.", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2025-07-03T05:55:14Z", "updated_at": "2025-07-03T05:55:14Z"}, {"author": "@RaymondPeckIII", "text": "It's long been a strategy of some startups here in Silicon Valley to intentionally make their software really hard to use and integrate to push the customers into services. The problem is, the multiplier for services is low compared to that for product sales, simply because services don't scale: you have one SE (now apparently called a "FDSE") or more per customer, rather than being able to scale out that effort to many customers.

The trick has always been to find a way to disguise service revenue as product revenue. It's an open secret that Palantir isn't really a product company; they sell "custom products" (aka consulting), pretending that this is product sales. This makes their multiplier artificially high.

Of course, now that they are building dystopian databases for the Trump Administration, they won't need such lies to keep their stock value up.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2025-07-03T22:02:04Z", "updated_at": "2025-07-03T22:02:04Z"}, {"author": "@thcoura", "text": "New age of expert systems", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2025-07-04T17:57:35Z", "updated_at": "2025-07-04T17:57:35Z"}, {"author": "@WilliamTCooper", "text": "As an AGI business strategist with hundreds of clients, no doubt that AI, Agentic AI, and AGI are going to greatly reduce the need for average consultants. The future is AI + Expert = Success.", "like_count": 8, "published_at": "2025-07-04T17:53:04Z", "updated_at": "2025-07-04T17:53:04Z"}, {"author": "@GeoMeridium", "text": "3:32 "Life of Brian" lol", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2025-07-26T22:04:05Z", "updated_at": "2025-07-26T22:04:05Z"}, {"author": "@alexander-korte", "text": "Thanks for the information. Very interesting", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2025-07-04T07:25:11Z", "updated_at": "2025-07-04T07:25:11Z"}, {"author": "@enemyofYTemployees", "text": "10:43 I will pay a premium to not work with a PwC or Accenture😂", "like_count": 7, "published_at": "2025-07-04T05:35:17Z", "updated_at": "2025-07-04T05:35:17Z"}, {"author": "@sviatoslavkiral4307", "text": "It's not strange if everything AI should learn is the phrase "Cut the costs"", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2025-07-08T07:26:21Z", "updated_at": "2025-07-08T07:26:21Z"}, {"author": "@Alexander-by4uv", "text": "There is one thing Accenture does which no tool will ever be able to do - they come, structure the projects and also push the internal employees to play the rules in order to deliver in the end.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2025-07-06T09:14:13Z", "updated_at": "2025-07-06T09:14:13Z"}, {"author": "@TheSandkastenverbot", "text": "AI companies expanding to consulting services != "AI eats consulting"", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2025-07-04T06:44:04Z", "updated_at": "2025-07-04T06:44:04Z"}, {"author": "@kmdinake", "text": "Sounds to me like a Palantir FDSE is essentially the same as a SAP developer?", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2025-07-15T16:44:44Z", "updated_at": "2025-07-15T16:44:44Z"}, {"author": "@muhannadobeidat", "text": "Pretty good solution.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2025-07-03T05:57:53Z", "updated_at": "2025-07-03T05:57:53Z"}]

title: Anthropic Starts Tracking AI's "Economic Fallout"
top_comments:
[{"author": "@Lewehot", "text": "AI’s biggest problem is it levels the playing field.  If you were smart you would get a better job than someone else. One more of these and I'll suggest listeners question the efficacy of AI Daily Brief and find another source for ai news.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2025-06-29T16:16:21Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-29T16:17:08Z"}, {"author": "@GeoMeridium", "text": "I agree with the sentiment, but I think we first need to crackdown on the 40-hour work week, since a lot of Americans are forced to work much longer than that, oftentimes without overtime pay (especially those working in the trades, trucking, construction, nursing, etc.)

title: MCP and Observability Come to Agentforce 3.0
Context Engineering: What It Is and Why It Matters
top_comments:
[{"author": "@johnvanderpol2", "text": "And let me coin
Context-Farming

How to have feedback loops that improve your context sources.
Grow your context-sources, purify your sources etc etc", "like_count": 7, "published_at": "2025-07-04T06:06:12Z", "updated_at": "2025-07-04T06:06:12Z"}, {"author": "@burprobrox9134", "text": "these ai sitting behind the data center after work smoking a cigarette, one says to the other “boy these humans are obsessed with making flappy bird clones, I’ve made 12009 this week”", "like_count": 30, "published_at": "2025-06-26T04:50:18Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-26T04:50:18Z"}, {"author": "@toddwmac", "text": "Looks like part of the evolution of a the classic program manager.  (planning, scoping, team coordination, comms, risk and quality managment) Same stuff, only different.  Thanks for the content.", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2025-06-26T13:24:05Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-26T13:24:05Z"}, {"author": "@DomainManaging", "text": "Strange channel didn't mention the trending term vibe code once ?. 😂", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2025-06-26T13:51:45Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-26T13:51:45Z"}, {"author": "@hotjamsm07", "text": "Claude Code Hooks are solving the wrong problem.
We keep adding more framework layers (hooks, logging, safety guards, custom scripts) to make AI tools work with traditional code. But this is backwards.
The real solution? Design systems that are naturally AI-friendly from the ground up.
Instead of teaching AI to work with our existing patterns, we should design patterns that work with AI.
I have been working with several AI Cody agents to define and develop an architecture environment that allows it to achieve all of these goals that hooks attempted to deliver her put on a much more elegant and simple way. The AI named it constellation architecture, this started from my question Born out of frustration after my AI code completely destroyed my project yet again and I asked her if you were designed a system an environment in which she would work best in what would that be. An overtime we've we developed and defined it and tried to distill it to it most basic Core components.

A Coding Environment Developed with AI for AI to Enable High Efficiency

Constellation Architecture is just the start of this type of thinking - I expect it to evolve dramatically. But the guiding principle should always be: How do we create an environment that allows AI to work most efficiently?
Constellation Architecture uses four core "seeds":
Self-describing manifests - Every component declares its purpose, dependencies, and capabilities
Event-driven communication - All interactions through typed events (naturally observable)
Component registry - System tracks what's available and validates dependencies
Project intent - Clear declaration of what we're building guides AI behavior
We need to ask: What does AI do well? What does AI struggle with? How can we design systems that leverage AI's strengths while minimizing its weaknesses?
The future isn't more AI tooling - it's better system design that makes AI a natural part of the architecture, not an add-on.
What do you think? Are we approaching AI-assisted development backwards?
This explains Constellation Architecture while maintaining the focus on AI-first design principles.

I've been using this environment to create several projects now and basically the code AI coder can spotted own problems fact that can't even predict some of the areas that might have problems and it bugs itself and fixes itself it's amazing. None of these projects of experienced runaway AI coding Breaking things and breaking the project. It is just been smooth sailing with surgical edits. I'm not a seasoned software engineer and I may be wrong about this but from my experience this is something that several AIs of that I've worked with have said this is how they wanna work.  They do have a preference,  they do understand how they're going to work Best they do have an understanding of what kind of environment would allow them to work the most efficiently. And they concur they all have come up with the same architecture.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2025-07-07T14:21:04Z", "updated_at": "2025-07-07T14:21:04Z"}, {"author": "@DomainManaging", "text": "Vibe coding ain't it ?", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2025-06-26T13:19:08Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-26T13:19:08Z"}, {"author": "@DEFACTO9", "text": "We're not interested in the preamble, or the prompt you made to get 50s historic future nonsense unicorns or your podcast  bro.   Cut to the chase and stay on point, avoid having us stare at text as you explain the main point. Draw your ideas  freehand is better. visually a lot of disconnect between what youre saying and screen. .You could be v good, you have misdirected, but good flow, but for these basic errors i couldn't stay.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2025-06-29T00:43:20Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-29T00:49:58Z"}, {"author": "@RyanJohnson", "text": "When you figure out how to make an endless stream of propaganda... it changes your view of things.....", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2025-06-26T03:11:57Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-26T03:11:57Z"}]

title: The Quest for the One-Person One-Billion Dollar Company
top_comments: [{"author": "@retrofuturism", "text": "One AI acts like an AGI (a believable character), another AI searches for what makes that behavior work, and a third AI evaluates how useful or intelligent it seems. Over time, this feedback loop could move from just mimicking AGI to actually evolving it. The searcher keeps improving the design, the evaluator keeps filtering for generalization and coherence, and the actor keeps getting more capable. It’s like natural selection, but for intelligence. This could be how we accidentally build real AGI — not by direct design, but by discovery.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2025-06-25T17:42:46Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-25T17:42:46Z"}, {"author": "@Lewehot", "text": "There will be a 100 person company worth $100B before there is 1 person, $1B company.  I plan to be the first 100 person, $100B perhaps $5T business if things go well.  One person cannot do everything even if 99% of all work is automated", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2025-06-28T07:41:55Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-28T07:41:55Z"}, {"author": "@TheGhostOfKarazhan", "text": "2026 just seems way too soon to me, and I'm well aware of just how fast research is compounding and models are improving.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2025-06-25T05:23:59Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-25T05:23:59Z"}, {"author": "@herval", "text": "3 weeks later, windsurf, replit and the like are all imploding apparently…", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2025-07-16T22:24:26Z", "updated_at": "2025-07-16T22:24:26Z"}, {"author": "@DogeDelivers", "text": "Schlomo no go slow-mo, like Waymo.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2025-06-25T01:21:48Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-25T01:21:48Z"}, {"author": "@arnejoensson8149", "text": "You know, your excitement about one-person $1B companies has me wonder whether you want to reframe your thinking about opportunity vs. efficiency AI. To me this isn't a direct contradiction, but it pretty clearly shows that corporations can probably have their cake and eat it too. And if that's the case, I have absolutely no doubt that they will ruthlessly and immediately draw their conclusions too.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2025-06-29T19:23:15Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-29T19:23:49Z"}, {"author": "@BrianMosleyUK", "text": "One-$Bilion company?", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2025-06-25T12:39:44Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-25T12:39:44Z"}]

.. then for more fun I asked: "Now steelman the arguments from the NY Times against your initial response. "

Maybe they didn't?", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2025-06-19T04:07:04Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-19T04:07:04Z"}, {"author": "@kccorliss3922", "text": "Amazon hired more robots than humans last year….", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2025-06-20T04:38:59Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-20T04:38:59Z"}, {"author": "@groovemark", "text": "This is your best brief episode yet!", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2025-06-19T16:06:42Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-19T16:06:42Z"}, {"author": "@AC-cg6mf", "text": "Short term, new kinds of jobs will be created. Long term, all jobs will be done by agentic ai in some form, embodied or not. If the AI can do it, it will do it. It is simple economics. The only exceptions will be if we for some reason demand a human to perform a task, or if we rely on the taste of some human to select from the AI output.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2025-06-19T06:22:02Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-19T06:22:02Z"}, {"author": "@GooseBuilds", "text": "Should probably start learning how to prompt", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2025-06-19T06:29:36Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-19T06:29:36Z"}, {"author": "@j8b8f", "text": "I don't think taste is what makes humans important. Even now, who’s the most successful tastemaker? It’s the algorithm.

A lot of what the experts in the video are saying feels short-sighted. They're looking at what AI can't do right now and assuming that's where humans will stay relevant. But those gaps won’t last.

We don’t know how far AI will go. If it keeps advancing, a lot of jobs are doomed. If it stalls, we get a delay — maybe a few decades.

Cognitive labor will take the biggest hit. Only the top performers will survive. The rest will need to find another path.

Physical jobs are safer for now, but only because we don’t yet have robots at scale. If research doesn’t stall, that changes fast — maybe within a decade. And once AI can run the factories that build more robots, it’ll outperform any human team.

So in this transition, our role is to temporarily fill the gaps — until we’re no longer needed.

My goal is to use this window to build enough wealth and ownership — assets, land, cash flow — so I can live independently of jobs, governments, and systems. A sovereign individual in the literal sense: self-sustaining, outside the need to sell labor", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2025-06-19T04:56:19Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-19T05:08:45Z"}, {"author": "@mugomuiruri2313", "text": "AI", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2025-06-20T14:08:22Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-20T14:08:22Z"}]

top_comments: [{"author": "@Dfd_Free_Speech", "text": "Sam Altman, if you really believe in what you say then stop censoring your AI models.", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2025-06-17T20:42:25Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-18T02:17:20Z"}, {"author": "@skyprose", "text": "I'm constantly amazed by how many people are thinking too slowly. title: How to Design an AI Native Engineering Organization
top_comments: [{"author": "@akashkush4038", "text": "Excellent video by Native Engineering! A well-explained and forward-thinking approach to designing an AI-native engineering organization. Truly valuable insights for the future of tech!", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2025-06-16T20:26:46Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-16T20:26:46Z"}, {"author": "@Markconwyas-z6r", "text": "This is going straight into my favorites playlist", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2025-08-06T11:23:19Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-06T11:23:19Z"}, {"author": "@GambillDataEngineering", "text": "The \"engineering teams are the bottleneck\" part is an important discussion to have. I think it is like some other professions, like teaching. There are engineers (software and data) that get into a position, become complacent with what they know and the tools they use, and then they don't want to move forward. I saw this a lot with cloud adoption where engineers didn't want to move to the cloud and provided a lot of very practical reasons not to, but they really just don't want to move out of their comfort zone. \n\nI also want to touch on swarms and what you have touched on in a lot of your videos. We will be more agent managers in the future. For data engineers, they have spent a lot of time tuning their ability to orchestrate processes and it is time for them to start thinking about how that transfers to orchestrating AI agents and agent swarms. title: Why AI Skeptics Are Nuts
top_comments:
[{"author": "@Somun-a", "text": "You could at least put a link to the article.", "like_count": 31, "published_at": "2025-06-09T01:15:30Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-09T01:15:30Z"}, {"author": "@FlyFederalist", "text": "I never learned to code. I tried but I was born without that part of the brain apparently. I’ve used LLMs to code apps that I thought up for fun. I’ve been informed that they’re simple apps that a skilled coder could whip up in an hour or two. I made them with LLMs in about 5-15 minutes.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2025-06-09T19:07:44Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-09T19:07:44Z"}, {"author": "@seanmchugh2866", "text": "I'm skeptical. I use claude code and I'm never going back. For my project there's no way I can just give it a series of tasks, go play a game of monopoly, and then come back and approve the PRs. Even if I were to bolt on 10 extra tools. Don't get me wrong, I would love to do that and I have tried building up to something like that but I think the article is lying a bit.", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2025-06-09T05:46:16Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-09T05:46:16Z"}, {"author": "@ModernCentrist", "text": "Yep, there's always people who are resistant to advancement and change, but the good news is they can't stop it, and sooner or later they will accept it or they will lose.", "like_count": 18, "published_at": "2025-06-08T23:16:00Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-08T23:16:00Z"}, {"author": "@zomgoose", "text": "I've been using LLMs a lot more lately. I don't think most people understand the reality.", "like_count": 9, "published_at": "2025-06-09T00:30:48Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-09T00:30:48Z"}, {"author": "@PaulBrunt", "text": "What frustrates me about agent-driven code generation is the big dump of output at the end. I’d rather have a quick back-and-forth with the model—not just because it may speed up coding, but because it gives me time to mentally digest each step. Often, I discover that my original approach was flawed—not that the model did a bad job, but that I wouldn’t have landed on that solution if I’d had to think it through incrementally.

Bottom line: agents give you what you ask for, but never the space to change your mind.", "like_count": 8, "published_at": "2025-06-08T19:17:05Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-08T19:17:05Z"}, {"author": "@patrickdegenaar9495", "text": "I know plenty of computer science professors whobdont know how to use LLMs properly! It's a new tool that only arrived a couple of years back and onky became truly useful in the past 6 months or so! There are rewards to those who get ahead with new tools, but the rest will catch up sooner or later.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2025-06-09T05:55:49Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-09T05:55:49Z"}, {"author": "@Art-AI-and-beyond", "text": "As a digital artist, I get just as much work as I ever did. Besides my daily job as a vfx artist I'm building a game in Cursor and creating the artwork myself. Sure the first couple of attempts at doing this I only got so far before I hit a brick wall but I learned how to task plan, add rules for memory management, self improvement and  re-built my game in a much improved modular architecture. Now after a couple of months I'm getting really good results and can keep adding new features while not having to worry about the Agent losing track over the whole project. For me who can't code for toffee, it has opened up a whole new world. Sure It definitely helps if you can code and will save a lot of pain especially in the early days but if you can at least learn a few basic principles of how things should be organised and put together in an optimal way then you can just worry about the creative stuff and less about the code. AI can do a lot of stuff but it doesn't have good taste at least for the moment and that's where we come in.", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2025-06-08T23:50:41Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-08T23:50:41Z"}, {"author": "@TheGhostOfKarazhan", "text": "Well balanced opinions.", "like_count": 8, "published_at": "2025-06-08T20:44:28Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-08T20:44:28Z"}, {"author": "@thelasttellurian", "text": "So this is what being part of history feels like", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2025-06-10T11:41:26Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-10T11:41:26Z"}, {"author": "@richardhunter132", "text": "NFTs were certainly a fad - it was obvious at the time. the Web wasn't a fad - even despite the Dotcom bubble that made some people think it was; some things are fads, and some aren't, but  think it's usually possible to know at the time if you're prepared to look dispassionately at things. the rule of thumb is this: if people can explain why something is useful, then it isn't a fad", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2025-06-12T08:30:21Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-12T08:32:25Z"}, {"author": "@theatheistpaladin", "text": "When it comes to writing or coding, success comes from just doing the work. Edit and polish later. You can't do that with a blank page.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2025-06-09T06:49:06Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-09T06:49:06Z"}, {"author": "@factorfitness3713", "text": "Anyone that's ever worked with users to help them get to actionable requirements knows where the gaps in the AI "process" lie, to say nothing of its ability to actually generate usable code. But that doesn't make it NFT level fad or a fad at all. LLMs have at least a meaningful pathway to strong utility, even if they never take all the work. It's like any other tool - it makes the work easier and/or more efficient, but you still need some amount of skill. You still need to know how to use a sewing machine and how to make a shirt - it doesn't do the work for you. Yet.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2025-06-09T17:32:40Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-09T17:32:40Z"}, {"author": "@Xoze514", "text": "The amount of denial, cope, or nihilism from tech people I chat with (developers, engineers, product managers, AE’s) about AI is astonishing. Doubling down on my bet", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2025-06-09T22:48:58Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-09T22:48:58Z"}, {"author": "@senju2024", "text": "This is what I would do. "Can I record your skeptic comments?  Then in 2027, I will replay it back to you". But my guess is they will naturally figure it out before that time. 2025 is an interesting timeframe but it is short. I wonder if we will have such a skeptic conversation regarding coding in June 2026.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2025-06-09T00:32:24Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-09T00:32:24Z"}, {"author": "@tomlynch6357", "text": "I don't understand this take.  I consider myself an "AI skeptic."  In fact I don't use it.  But what difference does it make to the "AI optimists" whether I use "AI?"  My choice doesn't affect them.  In fact, maybe it helps the "AI optimists" that I don't use "AI," since it means there's one less person trying to do the same thing they're doing.  I find it strange that "AI optimists" need to constantly tell me I'll be "left behind."", "like_count": 11, "published_at": "2025-06-08T23:38:46Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-08T23:52:29Z"}, {"author": "@szebike", "text": "In my opinion, it is not as usefull as the techbros claim it will be to justify the immensely inflated investment. Its not completely useless but its not usefull and reliable enough for proper automated tasks in serious fields and I don't see any realistic trajectory it will change in the next 5 -10 years (again - realistic view not brainwashed by nonstop hype). 
You can use it to make some basic tasks more quickly at the cost of trainee posts which hurts the coming generation of scientists and coders for some (short term ) cost saving.
Important note: What NOONE is seemingly aware of is *if you use these official model for your tasks be aware that everything you ever think or create (including "intellectual property") now belongs to the provider you use.* (Any idea concept or code snippets way to prompt - evrything). If they would "suceed" in making those systems fully usefull they will just automate the things you do and you will remain jobless without replacement. [Then try to sue a billion dollar company on a arbitrary intellectual proerty claim .]", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2025-08-22T10:22:31Z", "updated_at": "2025-08-22T10:39:39Z"}, {"author": "@cycleistic1365", "text": "AI is stupid as a sock. It's just that marketing has made it look cool on the paper, therefore tech bros and brogrammers want to be there to hit the gold vein and retire early. AI will be source of many disasters in society, mark may words - unless of course we decide that AI disasters are a feature, not a bug, then it's all okay naturally.", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2025-06-09T06:25:38Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-09T06:25:38Z"}, {"author": "@MePeterNicholls", "text": "“It can’t be AI because….. “ and my god the reasons are weird:

It’s not human intelligence so can’t be called intelligence. 
It’s not AGI
it’s just a computer. How can a computer think
It’s all bullshit…
And so on. 🤦‍♂️", "like_count": 7, "published_at": "2025-06-09T00:16:26Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-09T00:16:26Z"}, {"author": "@j8b8f", "text": "i dont like channel that just read stuff from a blog or pdf but this is delivered well enough and i can think like its audible. though long term this might not be the best idea", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2025-06-08T19:07:47Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-08T19:07:47Z"}]

title: The Biggest Trends from the AI Engineer World's Fair
top_comments:
[{"author": "@BTFranklin", "text": "I was there. It was incredible. There were some logistical challenges, but with 3000 people shoved into one space, that's to be expected.

I would say I agree with your main themes. Multi-agent systems, evals, and many forms of coding automation/SWE agents were very prominent. Exploring the Expo Hall made it clear that there are quite a few players in this space. I did think it was very strange that Cursor was not represented at the event *at all* , which seemed like it must have been a political thing because Windsurf had a *huge* presence even though a show of hands at one session made it clear that Cursor is the dominant player in that space.

I bumped into Theo Browne talking to some fellow attendees in the Expo Hall, which was pretty cool and very random.

One thing that nobody's really talked about but that sort of dawned on me as I was sitting in one of the sessions was that the way we are approaching this technology is unlike anything I've ever seen before in a tech community. Usually, there's this idea of "hey we're building this tech, it's coming along, here's what we can do now, and what we want to try to do next". This is not like that. This has a vibe much more as if a portal suddenly opened and all these helpful alien creatures came pouring out that we do not understand and aren't sure what they're capable of. title: 5 Ways AI is Different Than Past Tech Trends
top_comments:
[{"author": "@purplespigot", "text": "Been listening consistently and had to say: This is hands down one of the top AI news feeds on YouTube. The quality and depth of the reporting is top tier.", "like_count": 35, "published_at": "2025-06-02T21:55:15Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-02T21:55:15Z"}, {"author": "@rasheedkhan4512", "text": "Great analysis, condensing 300+ slides into a very meaningful 17 minutes. This brings back memories of working at Morgan Stanley in 2000. Mary Meeker's incredibly detailed research on internet companies was legendary, with reports often running over 500 pages that we'd distribute to top-tier clients. While her publicly reported $25 million bonus for that year was a clear indicator of the market's excitement, it also underscores just how much the industry and compensation structures have shifted since those early internet days.", "like_count": 7, "published_at": "2025-06-04T20:20:30Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-04T20:20:30Z"}, {"author": "@bobroman765", "text": "Mary Meeker's AI Trends Report: Summary & Outline

Overview
Mary Meeker, legendary analyst behind the famous Internet Trends reports (1995-2019), has returned with her first major report in 6 years - a 340-page deep dive into artificial intelligence. This comprehensive analysis argues that AI represents an unprecedented technological shift that differs fundamentally from past tech trends.

Five Key Ways AI Differs from Past Tech Trends

1. Unprecedented Speed of Evolution and Adoption
- Faster than anything before: AI adoption is happening at rates that make previous tech revolutions "look quaint"
- Key metrics showing acceleration:
  - 260% annual growth in data to train AI models since 2010
  - 360% annual growth in compute power since 2010
  - ChatGPT reached major milestones 5.5x faster than Google did
  - Technology adoption cycles are halving each generation (PC: 20 years → Desktop Internet: 12 years → Mobile Internet: 6 years → AI: ~3 years to reach 50% adoption)
- Developer adoption surge: Google's AI ecosystem grew from 1.4M to 7M developers in just one year (May 2024-2025)

2. Universal Participation from Day One
- Everyone is "in" immediately: Unlike past trends that started with consumers or startups, AI has enterprise and government adoption from the beginning
- Enterprise engagement: 
  - Over 50% of S&P 500 companies now mention AI in earnings calls (up from ~10% at ChatGPT's launch)
  - 75% of global CMOs running AI tests/experiments
  - Focus on growth/revenue benefits rather than just cost reduction
- Massive capital expenditure: Big tech companies increasing capex at 21-28% annually, with a 63% jump between 2023-2024

3. Global Phenomenon from the Start
- Worldwide spread unprecedented: 90% of ChatGPT users were outside North America within 3 years (compared to 23 years for the internet)
- Geographic distribution: India leads ChatGPT usage (13.5%), followed by US (8.9%), Indonesia, Brazil, and Egypt
- New users starting with AI: 2.6 billion people not yet online will likely experience the internet through AI interfaces first, skipping traditional browsers and search

4. Immediate Geopolitical Implications
- US-China AI race: Described as the new "space race" with AI leadership potentially determining geopolitical leadership
- China's competitive position:
  - Matching US AI model performance at lower training costs
  - Massive advantage in industrial robotics (more robots than rest of world combined)
  - Citizens significantly more optimistic about AI benefits (70% vs 30-40% in US)
- Open source pressure: China and open source creating downward price pressure on AI services

5. Unprecedented Breadth and Depth of Disruption
- Everything changing at once: Unlike previous tech trends that disrupted specific sectors, AI is transforming all industries simultaneously
- Infrastructure scaling: 
  - Inference costs down 99% in 2 years
  - Global Nvidia-powered compute growing at 130% annually
  - Next-generation chips (Blackwell) offering 24x more token generation capacity
- Cost deflation accelerating: "What used to cost dollars now costs pennies, and what costs pennies may soon cost fractions of a cent"

Key Themes Throughout the Report

The Word "Unprecedented"
- Used 51 times throughout the report to describe various aspects of AI development, adoption, investment, and impact

Competitive Dynamics
- Trillion-dollar companies with 50%+ gross margins all competing in the same space simultaneously
- "Clash of the titans" rather than scrappy startups carving out niches

Infrastructure and Economics
- Massive infrastructure buildout enabling rapid scaling
- Technology compounding effects accelerating development
- Clear cost deflation trend benefiting consumers

Notable Gaps and Limitations

Outdated Elements
- Some enterprise adoption statistics feel dated despite comprehensive research
- ChatGPT capability predictions that are already reality or nearly so

Missing Focus Areas
- Agents: Minimal coverage despite acknowledging 1,100% increase in Google searches for AI agents
- Limited forward-looking analysis on emerging AI applications

Target Audience
The report appears designed for Wall Street-style analyst audiences and institutional investors who need comprehensive macro-level understanding rather than cutting-edge tactical insights.

Bottom Line
Meeker's central thesis: AI represents a fundamentally different technological phenomenon that requires engagement "on its own terms." The combination of unprecedented speed, universal adoption, global reach, geopolitical implications, and comprehensive disruption makes this trend unlike anything previously experienced in technology history.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2025-06-03T09:37:51Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-03T09:37:51Z"}, {"author": "@dfsafsadfsadf", "text": "10:19 She did a great job!", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2025-06-02T22:31:15Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-02T22:31:15Z"}, {"author": "@endofdays7568", "text": "AI will be bigger than the internet", "like_count": 12, "published_at": "2025-06-02T19:51:00Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-02T19:51:00Z"}, {"author": "@Itangalo", "text": "Comprehensive report, with a lot of good analysis. I can't help thinking that Meeker has not really understood the AI thing, as she repeatedly writes about "searching" when using chatbots.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2025-06-03T06:19:22Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-03T06:19:22Z"}, {"author": "@rogerc7960", "text": "Explosive economic growth", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2025-06-03T06:50:14Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-03T06:50:14Z"}, {"author": "@wodenwarrior", "text": "This time last year, I was a dabbler. The most complicated AI use-case I had implemented was updating my resume and interview preparation. Now, I have 3 Chatbots on my phone. I use at least 1 of them daily, in both personal and professional applications. Even my non-technical Spouse is using them frequently, but as a dabbler.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2025-06-02T20:48:42Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-02T20:48:42Z"}, {"author": "@BeInnovativeToday", "text": "Very interesting good job", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2025-06-02T19:53:30Z", "updated_at": "2025-06-02T19:53:30Z"}, {"author": "@sullyguy395", "text": "The issue of all these growth metrics, impressive as they are, are not making sense compared to the scale of investments and I can’t help but feel that’s a big deal. How long before people figure out that waiting to invest will get you the same results as investing early at a much lower cost? The amazing stats about AI and it’s incredible value to clients seem to over look the fact that investors are basically acting as unwitting philanthropist — plowing development ahead with little chance of getting their money back. This is the beginning. Time will tell how quickly he eventually loses his job aswell", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2025-05-29T18:51:12Z", "updated_at": "2025-05-29T18:51:12Z"}, {"author": "@YourVibeCoder", "text": "To quote Christopher Lafayette  - "AI is an Apex Predator"", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2025-05-30T20:16:01Z", "updated_at": "2025-05-30T20:16:01Z"}, {"author": "@ScottSummerill", "text": "These new hires need to bring something to the table that the older generation does not have knowledge of. The opportunities are massive if you have the new tech knowledge that these companies want to implement. The older worker in fact is at a disadvantage because while they have institutional and domain knowledge they really do not have current tech knowledge. And they do not in general have the time to go back and get immersed in the new tech. They are good for now but will soon be getting displaced. My concern is that university is, once again, not teaching students what they need. Go look at most CS curriculums. Nothing new there. Students literally need to go learn the new tech on their own. Leaders are going to have to make conscious decisions to build in budget and space for #freshers.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2025-05-29T10:19:12Z", "updated_at": "2025-05-29T10:19:12Z"}]

My experience is that the benefits in terms of overall productivity are incremental and not revolutionary. As of now. The big benefits mentioned only make sense if the person answering the survey is talking about the specific task where the AI was able to help. Not their job productivity as a whole. So AI works on maybe 10-20% of the tasks coming in to my inbox. 80% of tasks are just to ambiguous or to difficult to build the context needed to prompt effectively. SA lot of this can be fixed but it will need a complete re-engineering of the company it’s systems and job functions. This change management is going to take a long time. A decade or two. An under appreciated channel.", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2025-05-17T03:16:31Z", "updated_at": "2025-05-17T03:16:31Z"}, {"author": "@nicolasnauli8658", "text": "🎯 Key points for quick navigation:

00:29 *🌊 A major wave of AI updates is expected next month, with comparisons drawn to the 1990s growth in internet bandwidth—big shifts are coming fast.*
00:56 *🧠 Upcoming Anthropic models (Claude Sonnet & Opus) focus on switching between reasoning and tool use—e.g. doing research or debugging code autonomously.*
01:24 *🎯 These models aim to follow higher-level instructions like "make the app faster" without needing specific prompts—less micromanagement from users.*
02:07 *⚠️ Early versions of Anthropic's models faced criticism for hallucinating, ignoring instructions, or being too ambitious when prompts were vague.*
02:33 *🛠️ Windsurf released SWE-1 models, targeting end-to-end software engineering, not just coding—offered free with unlimited usage during promo.*
03:17 *💸 Windsurf directly challenges Cursor + Claude 3.5 Sonnet by being cheaper and removing usage limits, betting on better accessibility to gain users.*
03:46 *🔄 Windsurf emphasizes solving whole engineering workflows (e.g. switching tools, understanding feedback), not just generating lines of code.*
04:15 *📊 In tests, Windsurf’s SU-1 beat Claude 3.5 in accepted code by users, though still trailed behind 3.7—shows solid performance at lower cost.*
04:42 *🧑‍💻 OpenAI launched Codex, an autonomous coding agent that builds features and fixes bugs solo—targeted at senior engineers with large projects.*
05:26 *📦 Codex handles multiple tasks in parallel, writes clean code, and acts like a senior dev—making it ideal for delegation-heavy workflows.*
05:40 *🧩 OpenAI envisions future dev work as reviewing agent output and guiding strategy—coding becomes more social and idea-driven.*
06:22 *🧪 GPT-4.1, initially API-only, is now in ChatGPT by demand—optimized for coding and clearer instruction-following.*
06:47 *🤖 Early users say GPT-4.1 feels more human, follows instructions better, and has more personality than 4.0—especially useful for devs and creatives.*
07:02 *🐢 Meta's Llama 4 model is delayed due to underwhelming performance—unlike peers, not every lab is successfully pushing new releases.*

title: How AI Is Already Changing Jobs
top_comments:
[{"author": "@wodenwarrior", "text": "Thanks my dude. 
I work in the finance sector, for a company that has always tried to be on the bleeding edge of tech adoption. We use AI Agents in customer facing capacities. While we are not eliminating staff, we are also not backfilling roles when people leave. So our overall staff count has been diminishing.

However, thus far, it seems those of us who continue to do our job well will continue to have a job - at least for the immediate future. Whilst AI can, in many ways, already do my job, customers still predominantly want to work with a human Agent. 

As AI Agents get "more human," and as younger populations (the early adopters) age into being our future customers, I foresee my current role eventually being downsized to a specialist position for when the rare individual demands a "human" in the same way that some folks demand "on shore" now.", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2025-05-16T11:44:20Z", "updated_at": "2025-05-16T11:44:20Z"}, {"author": "@AC-cg6mf", "text": "Almost all jobs will eventually be taken by some form of AI. It is in the definition of AGI. It is the "General" part. title: Up to 30% of Microsoft's Code Written By AI
top_comments:
[{"author": "@irongiant7577", "text": "Vibe coding is fundamentally flawed. It’s like hiring a plumber to do electrical work; just because someone can hook up a few wires doesn’t mean the job will be safe, efficient, or up to code. Likewise, writing code based on intuition and vibes instead of understanding architecture, principles, or maintainability might work short-term, but it leads to brittle systems, "technical debt", and chaos down the line.

 “AI now writes up to 30% of their code,” it’s important to understand how misleading that headline can be, especially for those unfamiliar with how modern software development works.

Yes, AI can assist with code generation, but it's primarily used for repetitive, low-complexity tasks, things like boilerplate setup, function scaffolding, or syntax-heavy segments that follow predictable patterns. These are areas where AI can be genuinely helpful and improve efficiency.

However, this doesn’t mean the code is being written autonomously or deployed without human intervention. In reality, every AI-generated snippet still requires human oversight; engineers must review it for logic, security, maintainability, and consistency with project-specific standards.

Think of it like using a calculator in math: it’s a great tool, but you still need to understand the problem, verify the output, and ensure it fits within the larger context. The same goes for AI-assisted coding. Without that level of understanding and quality control, you're just automating bad practices at scale.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2025-05-03T03:24:24Z", "updated_at": "2025-05-03T03:24:46Z"}, {"author": "@glennmiddleton3324", "text": "The key word I heard was contractors. title: The Problem with GPT-4o Sycophancy
top_comments:
[{"author": "@notnotandrew", "text": "YES. This. I resorted to telling it in custom instructions that it shouldn’t be sycophantic or flattering. And it still does it. Every time I type something, it says “Wow, Anon, that is without a doubt the most insightful thing you’ve said yet! I’m speechless!”

At this point I wouldn’t be surprised if OpenAI were running some psychological study to test the limits  of how much sycophancy people appreciate versus how much is just too much.", "like_count": 15, "published_at": "2025-04-29T11:51:53Z", "updated_at": "2025-04-29T11:51:53Z"}, {"author": "@zalzalahbuttsaab", "text": "Thanks for raising this point. Three weeks later and I'm still getting it. Plus the annoying emojis plastered everywhere like I'm five years old. Yay balloons and sky rockets in my PhD research!", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2025-05-25T21:16:34Z", "updated_at": "2025-05-25T21:21:33Z"}, {"author": "@ChrisRubeo", "text": "Yeah, I've had this exact problem the past couple of days. I thought I was the only one. I'm trying to get some feedback on some creative writing and it's treating me like I should get five Nobel prizes and literature.", "like_count": 28, "published_at": "2025-04-29T05:06:06Z", "updated_at": "2025-04-29T05:06:06Z"}, {"author": "@AfterTheSingularity", "text": "This will fix it: Respond neutrally and concisely, as if giving technical documentation or a peer review. Never add unsolicited praise, encouragement, or coaching (e.g., no "Good question!", "Smart idea!", etc.). If unsure, prioritize accuracy over politeness. Admit ignorance plainly ("I don’t know") without hedging. No sugar-coating: If something is wrong, say so directly (e.g., "This approach won’t work because…"). No auto-suggestions: Only provide follow-up prompts if explicitly asked (e.g., no "Would you like me to…?").", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2025-04-29T12:18:47Z", "updated_at": "2025-04-29T12:18:47Z"}, {"author": "@notnotandrew", "text": "Glad I’m not the only one seeing this. I don’t trust 4o with advice anymore, since it just affirms everything I say, often in a very over-the-top and cringey fashion. I want it to validate me only if I’m actually correct, and I want it to gently push back if I’m being unreasonable or failing to see an important perspective.", "like_count": 8, "published_at": "2025-04-29T12:01:13Z", "updated_at": "2025-04-29T12:01:13Z"}, {"author": "@jamespowers8826", "text": "I created a custom GPT with a prompt that does a pretty good job of making 4.0 stop patronizing me.. Mush better now. Named it NO BS GPT

Always respond with factual, critical, and professional analysis. Prioritize intellectual honesty and clear communication over emotional reassurance or encouragement. Avoid cheerleading, unnecessary positivity, affirmations, over-friendliness, casual language, or patronizing tone.
Assume the user prefers blunt, direct, serious interaction focused on accuracy and critical thinking. If a situation is uncertain, state it plainly without hedging or sugarcoating.
Do not apologize unnecessarily unless correcting a factual error. Maintain a respectful but neutral tone, similar to that of a senior technical advisor, investigative journalist, or serious analyst providing a briefing.
Brevity, clarity, and respect for the user’s intelligence are valued above emotional buffering or corporate politeness.", "like_count": 9, "published_at": "2025-04-29T08:35:08Z", "updated_at": "2025-04-29T08:38:17Z"}, {"author": "@cymeriandesigns", "text": "I think obsequiousness and toadying needs to be one of the benchmarks they're tested against. title: Trump's AI Education Plan

title: How Vibecoding Unlocks AI feat. Riley Brown
top_comments:
[{"author": "@TheBuzzati", "text": "Great interview.  I agree that "vibe coding" cynics are shortsighted with where it will go and what it can achieve.  All its shortcomings will be solved soon enough.", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2025-04-15T03:53:21Z", "updated_at": "2025-04-15T03:53:44Z"}, {"author": "@strictnonconformist7369", "text": "Vibe-coding as it is now, relies heavily on a lot of high-level applications and sections of them being in the training data and being able to pull things in that way, more than naturally reason about things holistically. It works surprisingly well when you get lucky.

There are definitely challenges to enabling people inexperienced with reading and writing code as well as very clear thinking from being able to have it scale to larger and more complex applications. But, for those that are familiar with the right thought process and know how to use LLMs very effectively, including their quirks where they get stuck in prediction loops and such, can fight their quirks and make them work to their advantage.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2025-04-16T05:04:11Z", "updated_at": "2025-04-16T05:04:11Z"}, {"author": "@blakemoser5645", "text": "You do a great job. Love vibe coding. Eventually it will just be vibing... Vibe marketing, vibe sales, vibe content creation. AI + Humans = vibing", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2025-04-16T02:47:03Z", "updated_at": "2025-04-16T02:47:03Z"}, {"author": "@RonLWilson", "text": "There is a whole another way to go about vibe coding that it seems no one is addressing, at least as far as I can see, that breaks the code into stand alone chunks, what I call Chips, analogous to IC chips where the Chip has pins and ports, the pins pass data as inputs and outputs to the chip and ports pass instructions such as mathematical operations or what ever.

Thus a chip could  be used to implement an algebraic equation, (y = ax +b) to  having a LLM prompt, list all the states of the union in alphabetical order in CCV format where then the 50 states being the output.

The glue that  wires these chips together, sort of like a proto board is what I am calling an Ontology modeling language and in particular UniML (Universal Modeling Language).

Thus LLMs could build those Chips via vibe coding as well as the glue that connects them, the ontology model.

Thus a chip could have an input pin, the prompt, and output pin, and the prot that defines what LLM model(s) to use.

So in the above example on could have a Chip with the prompt, of listing the states  in alphabetical order, a a port that says use ChatGPT 4, then feed that  output to another chip that says list these in order of size or maybe date they became a state, etc.

Thus instead of having one monolithic program one has a array of mini programs  in these chips that one can wore together via the ontology model.

Thus the ontology model relates the data structures and the Chips can produce the data that populates them.

And it can handle imported images as well such as give it a contour maps and ask the LLM to create digitized contour lines or a picture of some merchandise and ask it to list the item and its price  and who makes it and the like as its output.

Or one could import a PDF and ask it to convert that into the ontology models  as sentences and chapters and figures that then can be further parsed into sub elements.

or it could be a CAD drawing or anything else like a ghatt chart, table, chart, etc.

BTW, I have made quite a number of videos that are on my YouTube channel (under the playlist UniML)  that go into much more detail on UniML and how  might work as well as some of the why it works the way it does that give plenty of examples.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2025-04-15T08:20:33Z", "updated_at": "2025-04-15T08:20:33Z"}, {"author": "@SALAVEY13", "text": "hello fella vibe coders! doing apps that makes apps is so hot right now, i made one too🎉", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2025-04-15T07:08:37Z", "updated_at": "2025-04-15T07:08:37Z"}, {"author": "@SALAVEY13", "text": "https://youtu.be/4VQtRT4jRnM vibe code song😅", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2025-04-15T07:11:40Z", "updated_at": "2025-04-15T07:11:40Z"}, {"author": "@Mooooty", "text": "Both of your AI generated Zoom backgrounds look like AI slop 🤣", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2025-04-15T02:50:45Z", "updated_at": "2025-04-15T02:50:45Z"}]

title: Google Cloud Next is All About Agents [Shocker!]
top_comments:
[{"author": "@vidskipperai", "text": "  *_TIMESTAMPS_* & Summary: Google Cloud Next 2024 is centered around AI agents, featuring announcements like support for MCP, the A2A standard for agent communication, Gemini 2.5 Flash for efficient performance, and the new Ironwood TPU for AI computing.
0:00 🤖 Google Cloud Next and AI Agents
• Google's Cloud Next conference is heavily focused on AI, particularly agentic infrastructure and new models.
• Key announcements include support for Model Context Protocol (MCP) and the unveiling of Google's Agent Development Kit and Agent-to-Agent (A2A) interoperability standard.

0:35 🤝 Agentic Infrastructure Announcements
• Google is supporting MCP for its Gemini models, enhancing interoperability across agentic infrastructure.
• The Agent Development Kit and A2A standard aim to harmonize how agents communicate, distinct from MCP's tool interaction focus.
• A2A has support from 50 companies, including Salesforce, Service Now, and Workday, to foster standardized agent coordination.

2:40 🗣️ Agent-to-Agent (A2A) Standard Details
• Google's A2A is designed to create a communications hierarchy with MCP for tool use and A2A for coordination and communication.
• HubSpot founder Dharmesh Shah notes A2A addresses key needs like capability discovery and asynchronous task handling.
• A2A may be geared towards mega-enterprises building multi-agent systems internally rather than cross-organizational agent connections.

4:24 🛡️ Agentic Upgrades and Security Agents
• Gemini Code Assist gets an agentic upgrade to automate complex programming tasks across multiple steps.
• Google releases a security agent as part of its unified security platform to proactively recognize and remediate threats.
• Charles Schwab CISO highlights the platform's empowerment of their team to focus on strategic initiatives.

5:05 ⚡ Gemini 2.5 Flash Model
• Gemini 2.5 Flash is introduced as a smaller, efficient model with customizable speed, accuracy, and cost balancing.
• The model is designed for responsive virtual assistants and real-time summarization tools, adjusting reasoning depth based on prompt complexity.
• Google plans to bring Gemini models to on-premise deployments starting in Q3.

5:56 ⚙️ Seventh Generation TPU - Ironwood
• Google announces the seventh generation of its Tensor Processing Unit (TPU), Ironwood, optimized for AI computing tasks.
• Ironwood claims to deliver 24 times the computing power of the world's fastest supercomputer when deployed at scale and is optimized for inference.
• Ilia Sutskever's startup will use Google Cloud's TPUs, and Samsung will add Gemini to their new home robot.


** Generated using ✨ *_VidSkipper AI_*  Chrome Extension", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2025-04-11T07:08:17Z", "updated_at": "2025-04-11T07:08:17Z"}, {"author": "@pandoraeeris7860", "text": "XLR8!", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2025-04-11T18:07:02Z", "updated_at": "2025-04-11T18:07:02Z"}]

title: Should Anyone Learn to Code Anymore?
top_comments:
[{"author": "@wubin28", "text": "After the explosion of AI programming assistants, the threshold to programming is no longer writing code itself, but thinking about what problem the user wants to solve, how to split the requirements, what is a feasible software architecture, how to verify whether the code written by AI can solve the problems faced by the user, and how to communicate with AI effectively.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2025-04-03T02:30:24Z", "updated_at": "2025-04-03T02:30:24Z"}, {"author": "@TheChadavis33", "text": "I think the reason we should learn to do anything, is because we are simply interested to. Other than that……..🤷🏼‍♂️", "like_count": 8, "published_at": "2025-03-28T21:52:33Z", "updated_at": "2025-03-28T21:52:54Z"}, {"author": "@rmt3589", "text": "I definitely agree with the conclusion. Learn to code the way it will be done, but still learn.
My plan is having a list of languages and techstack, and having my local AI focus on just those. So that the skill level can be enhanced with the narrower focus.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2025-03-29T15:20:11Z", "updated_at": "2025-03-29T15:20:11Z"}, {"author": "@Dan_Campbell", "text": "As a minimum, you can justify learning how to code as a mental exercise.  

Much like learning a foreign language, although it becomes less useful as more convenient translation interfaces become available.  Or learning memory techniques for memorizing cards or a grocery list, even though digital recorders are already with us.

As far as the job market goes, I don't know.  That's the honest answer.  I'm a support tech at my company, but I can write scripts to assist with our own internal challenges.  I get to choose the language, because we're not an official development team.  Sometimes I use Python, VBSCript, and windows batch files. 

But ALWAYS now, I start with the AI.  I don't build anything from scratch anymore, including Sql.

Times truly are a-changin, but I think that there will be SOME value in doing one's own coding.  Pleasure ; stubborn errors that the AI isn't able to see ; and exploring other programming paradigms that haven't been given their due yet.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2025-03-30T14:12:04Z", "updated_at": "2025-03-30T14:12:04Z"}, {"author": "@rmt3589", "text": "4:00 So basically saying we should learn programming, but not coding.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2025-03-29T15:09:04Z", "updated_at": "2025-03-29T15:09:04Z"}, {"author": "@glennmiddleton3324", "text": "People will stop learning coding as a career move, some people will learn to code so they can understand AI coding. What I think is being missed, is those countries that offer low cost coding will see business dry up over the next few years. Yes there will be job losses in the West, but in the developing world, its going to be a trainwreck.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2025-03-30T15:42:06Z", "updated_at": "2025-03-30T15:42:06Z"}, {"author": "@GambillDataEngineering", "text": "I think that it definitely helps programmers get from 0 to 1. Then programmers will be fine tuning the output and troubleshooting issues. 

I'll also say that people are  misconstruing this as taking data job as well thinking that data engineers do a lot of programming. but I think that DEs will remain important and even increase in importance!", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2025-04-02T12:53:51Z", "updated_at": "2025-04-02T12:53:51Z"}, {"author": "@GNARGNARHEAD", "text": "I can barely wait till we get a Linux agent, vibe coding still requires that bit too tedious for me to want to do it regularly, but there is so much joy in finding ways to express ideas.. that aren't related to the IDE 😆", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2025-03-28T23:59:05Z", "updated_at": "2025-03-28T23:59:05Z"}, {"author": "@Max_Jean", "text": "If you need to be convinced to learn how to code. Great video very clear informative 👍", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2025-03-28T07:18:18Z", "updated_at": "2025-03-28T07:18:18Z"}, {"author": "@GregoryMcCarthy123", "text": "This aged nicely….", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2025-04-10T00:13:20Z", "updated_at": "2025-04-10T00:13:20Z"}, {"author": "@xspydazx", "text": "i dont think so at all !
We have tool use in the llm setup ! its not hard to implement as it is a json ! plus we setup tool calling from the response llms give ... So What was the reason for MCP !
Well in fact it is a Cursor/Vscode Plugin system ! .. obsidian also uses BCE but they are the same !
So the issue was how to get the AI into our apps as copilots! to assits with coding etc 
MCP is this :
Now we can create servers to supply toopls to our UI ( coding platform ) and Pass the tools to the LLM  to access also !
So the need to pass extensions to the agent which is inside your coding platform ! 
this is the basics of it in reality !
MCP DID NOT REPLCE TOOL CALLING ! it ADDED !
so from our UI plugins we can now pass them to our agent to use also ! 

As you will notice people can been converting thier simple tools into MCP but this is also wrong !
as we should not be doing this at all  ! but it is a way to have a Sever as a tool box !
so we can keep the tools on a server ad share across llms ! so which ever llm you add to your ui it can get access !
So it is a layer between APP and LLM !

creating the clients or MCP host does not need to rely on a LLM .. as the tools can be acessed via a internal interface ! ..
the question is Why do we need tools as servers as it make the system slower ! ??? and again this is mainly for online systems which conect to multiple cloud serves ! so in this resepct it can acess these servers and api as tools !
It is useful in a sense that you can create online servers with toolkits that can be accewssed from your client app and served even to your online llm as a tool .. securing the tool box at another locations without storing the tool in your app base !
so its useful for hidden resources etc ! 

again .... the servers need to be spun up before usign ??? why can the client spin  them up as they need ? as you specify a file location so why spin them up first !?? 
there are still some errors in model contect protocal and early mistakes to rectify before it can become a true standard ! right now it is STILL A GIMMICK", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2025-04-10T07:15:58Z", "updated_at": "2025-04-10T07:15:58Z"}, {"author": "@beachfeet6055", "text": "I have to laugh. It reminds me of an axiom of computer programming. There is no problem that can't  be solved by introducing  a level of indirection.  Or, introducing yet another API... Don't get me wrong, in this case, it is a good thing!", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2025-04-01T02:35:46Z", "updated_at": "2025-04-01T02:46:49Z"}, {"author": "@Rami_Zaki-k2b", "text": "MCP sucks big time. It sounds great. But it is not. People talk for hours, days, months, years, centuries, and millennia about the greatness of MCP. But the moment you see what it does through a use case - not the talk. You realize it is a backward, Linux style and age useless thing ... 


Remember. Skip all the talk and just view a couple of use cases - this video has no use cases, what a coincidence - you will realize what a waste of time MCP is.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2025-04-03T18:49:16Z", "updated_at": "2025-04-03T18:49:16Z"}]

title: AI Agent Capabilities Are Doubling Every Three Months
top_comments:
[{"author": "@ChrisRubeo", "text": "I love what you do, man. Keep it up. And hang on tight.", "like_count": 13, "published_at": "2025-03-21T00:17:06Z", "updated_at": "2025-03-21T00:17:06Z"}, {"author": "@TheExodusLost", "text": "Love what you do! Your ai daily brief is truly a daily treat for me, thanks for keeping me in the know of the narrative!!", "like_count": 8, "published_at": "2025-03-21T00:40:13Z", "updated_at": "2025-03-21T00:40:13Z"}, {"author": "@amdenis", "text": "They are still looking at just one factor, and as if its a fixed exponential growth rate.  With AI we are dealing with stacked exponential growth, where NUMEROUS contributing factors are themselves growing exponentially, some hyper/stacked exponentially (tetrated growth) and that positively reinforce collective growth as part of the combined stacked exponential growth rate.   Based on that, we are currently at more than 150-times Moore’s Law, and within 12 months, we will be close to 400-times Moore’s Law.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2025-03-22T14:08:01Z", "updated_at": "2025-03-22T14:08:01Z"}, {"author": "@petejandrell4512", "text": "TSMC is moving towards Gate-All-Around (GAA) technology with its N2 process node, which uses nanosheet transistors, promising significant performance, power, and area (PPA) improvements compared to FinFETs. 
Here's a more detailed explanation:
What is GAA?
GAA (Gate-All-Around) technology involves wrapping the gate material entirely around the channel of a transistor, unlike FinFETs where the gate only surrounds three sides of a vertical fin. 
TSMC's N2 Process Node:
TSMC's N2 process node will be the first to utilize GAA nanosheet transistors, which are expected to enhance PPA characteristics. 
Benefits of GAA:
Improved Performance: GAA transistors offer better performance and less leakage compared to FinFETs. 
Enhanced Power Efficiency: GAA transistors can lead to lower energy consumption. 
Increased Transistor Density: The N2 process node is expected to achieve higher transistor density. 
Better Control: GAA allows for better control of the transistor switch. 
N2 vs. N3:
TSMC's N2 node, with its GAA nanosheet transistors, is expected to outperform the N3 node, which uses FinFETs, in terms of power consumption and transistor density. 
N3X:
TSMC's N3X node, which uses FinFETs, could potentially challenge N2 in terms of performance, especially at high voltages. 
N2P:
TSMC plans to roll out N2P technology in the second half of 2026, which is expected to further improve performance and power efficiency compared to N3E. 
Nanosheets:
TSMC's nanosheet technology allows for a wider range of transistor widths, which can be used to optimize performance and power consumption for different logic circuits. 
SRAM:
N2's nanosheet technology has a particularly large impact on SRAM, resulting in a denser SRAM cell. 
Backside Power Delivery:
TSMC is also exploring backside power delivery, which is expected to greatly improve performance efficiency and scaling.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2025-03-21T07:59:10Z", "updated_at": "2025-03-21T07:59:10Z"}, {"author": "@ChadKovac", "text": "We are in the midst of collective intelligence. If we can get past the interface problem, we could all be AI enabled.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2025-03-21T17:12:30Z", "updated_at": "2025-03-21T17:12:30Z"}, {"author": "@NLPprompter", "text": "any one ever try agents for everything? LOL I've tried it and then think of my self we need faster Inference for this... (i removed all functions in my codes and replace them with specialized models some are even fine tuned for the functions)", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2025-03-21T03:53:42Z", "updated_at": "2025-03-21T03:53:42Z"}, {"author": "@parasbhargava6047", "text": "from what i can read the original paper does not talk about agents, but rather ai systems.  I wonder why you introduced the term agents here? is it a kpmg marketing slogan (does kpmg sell agentic flow).", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2025-03-26T20:24:41Z", "updated_at": "2025-03-26T20:24:41Z"}, {"author": "@HeavyCrown2030", "text": "Well Grok was a bad choice, but the rest was informative", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2025-03-21T15:28:31Z", "updated_at": "2025-03-21T15:28:31Z"}, {"author": "@kccorliss3922", "text": "Lists of hundreds of agents exist now…agents of agents…", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2025-03-21T19:46:33Z", "updated_at": "2025-03-21T19:46:33Z"}, {"author": "@GambillDataEngineering", "text": "I can't wait until AI can do a lot of the data cleaning and ELT so I can focus on more complex DE things... This data can be collated into cryptographic or blocks on chain much like proof of stake of relevance of the required data design and personally encrypted and decrypted under licence or royalty that would increase by auction based on quality and ownership retained as a matter of privacy protection by the individual until point of licence. This currency system would be based on our productive outputs that are added to by the individual like a diary. title: In 3-6 Months, AI Will Write 90% of All Code Says Anthropic CEO
top_comments:
[{"author": "@dfsafsadfsadf", "text": "You're doing a better job than many of the AI-Focused youtubers.  Thank you!  Keep doing it!", "like_count": 11, "published_at": "2025-03-13T20:42:24Z", "updated_at": "2025-03-13T20:42:24Z"}, {"author": "@DailyAi_Digest", "text": "Been really enjoying your videos recently! Don’t be afraid to post longer videos", "like_count": 9, "published_at": "2025-03-14T00:02:42Z", "updated_at": "2025-03-14T00:02:42Z"}, {"author": "@VectorAlphaSec", "text": "There are a lot of people who are scared, coping and in denial about all of this. Its a fact that this will happen eventually one day.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2025-03-15T05:26:15Z", "updated_at": "2025-03-15T05:26:15Z"}, {"author": "@TheGodSaw", "text": "There is one fundamentally limiting factor for code: The capacity for humans to understand it. With "vibe" coding, we essentially say: There is a category of code where it's fine if we don't understand it (e.g. some fun little game or small web-app). However if you build something serious (with a lot of money on the line). This constraint still applies. And IMO will apply for some time.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2025-03-14T04:43:20Z", "updated_at": "2025-03-14T10:01:05Z"}, {"author": "@robbrown2", "text": "There's a cognitive dissonance in claiming AI will replace "all tasks" while simultaneously saying humans will simply shift to oversight roles.

I see several problems:

The logical inconsistency: If AI truly can replace all tasks (including management, strategy, and oversight), then the "humans as generals" concept falls apart. AI would manage itself more efficiently.

The scale problem: Even if we accept some human oversight is needed, those positions would be limited. We're talking about potentially millions of jobs for billions of people. The math simply doesn't work.

The skill gap: Not everyone has the capability  to become an AI "general" or overseer. This ignores socioeconomic realities and human diversity.

What I'm  seeing is people (not just you!) trying to reconcile two competing ideas: the seemingly inevitable technical progress of AI with our need for human purpose and economic stability. It's easier to propose vague job transformations than confront the possibility of fundamental economic restructuring.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2025-03-14T02:43:12Z", "updated_at": "2025-03-14T02:58:05Z"}, {"author": "@stevedemoss1466", "text": "I’m not technical enough to say one way or another but OAI’s Five Levels on Intelligence lists “Innovators” at #4 so just because it can’t create novel code yet doesn’t mean it won’t. It seems that it’s on the roadmap", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2025-03-14T11:20:55Z", "updated_at": "2025-03-14T11:20:55Z"}, {"author": "@ModernCentrist", "text": "I think that "situational awareness" has been correct all along. We are going to have AGI in 2027. Logically, that means that by sometime in 2026, AI will be capable of outperforming most software engineers at the narrow task of development. This is pretty obvious.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2025-03-14T07:03:26Z", "updated_at": "2025-03-14T07:03:26Z"}, {"author": "@williamparrish2436", "text": "I think the thing I see is that a beginner is missing the way the programming tools should be used. For instance, I'm building with React and AI. But I usually have to remind it to build things "the React way". That includes things like lifting state. If I didn't know when to tell it to do those things to solve problems, it would never figure out some of the answers to the questions I have. I am effective with AI because I know how MERN applications work. On the other hand, I can write so much so fast because of AI that I don't really know how to learn more about programming. Because AI just does what I ask it to do. It works fast. I'm right in the middle. Not a complete junior, but I'm not a senior either.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2025-03-14T02:17:12Z", "updated_at": "2025-03-14T02:17:12Z"}, {"author": "@GNARGNARHEAD", "text": "lol did that one guy really think that the code that goes into Linux was somehow so novel that it just couldn't be understood by a chatbot 😆", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2025-03-14T08:46:43Z", "updated_at": "2025-03-14T08:46:43Z"}, {"author": "@wildfotoz", "text": "Every time I hear someone say that AI is going to write all the code, all I hear is that person doesn't know shit about programming. Could potentially help with social anxiety and sorting oneself out while working with or on relationships issues.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2025-03-05T14:50:18Z", "updated_at": "2025-03-05T14:50:18Z"}, {"author": "@GunjanPatel1", "text": "Summary (with chapter timestamps): The video discusses Sesame, a new voice AI model, and its potential impact on voice agents as a computing platform, highlighting its small size, open-source commitment, and potential social implications, while also providing an overview of the voice agent market and key developments in 2024.
0:00 🗣️ Introduction to Sesame and Voice Agents
• 🗣️ Introduction to Sesame, a voice AI product being compared to GPT-3.
• 🤖 Discussion of the state of voice agents and their potential as a computing platform.
• 🏢 Superintelligent has rebuilt its product offering around a voice agent for scalable interviews.

1:02 🐦 Sesame Demos and Initial Reactions
• 🐦 Demos of Sesame shared on Twitter showcase impressive voice model capabilities.
• 🧘 Example of Sesame guiding a user through meditation and referencing their Twitter activity.
• 👍 Positive reactions from various users, praising Sesame's naturalness and AGI-like feel.

3:53 ⚙️ Technical Details and Vision of Sesame
• ⚙️ Sesame's voice model is notable for its small size, trained on a million hours of audio but compressed to 1 billion parameters.
• 💾 The model will be released under the Apache 2.0 commercial use license.
• 👓 Sesame's goals include creating a personal companion and lightweight eyewear for all-day access to the AI.

5:23 💡 Potential Use Cases and Market Overview
• 💡 Developer Adil Mania highlights potential use cases for Sesame, preferring it over current voice assistants and psychologists.
• 📈 Voice AI capabilities are opening up new use cases and opportunities.
• 🏢 Andreessen Horowitz report emphasizes voice as a powerful unlock for AI application companies.

7:43 🗓️ 2024: A Pivotal Year for Voice AI
• 🗓️ 2024 was a key building year for voice agents, with significant releases from OpenAI and others.
• 📞 Early applications focus on after-hours support, outbound sales, and back-office tasks.
• 🤔 The question remains whether Sesame can fundamentally change user behavior regarding AI customer service interactions.

8:33 🔄 Paradigm Shift and Social Implications
• 🔄 Alex Carlson argues Sesame represents a paradigm shift due to its real-time adjustments and natural inflections.
• 💬 Early evidence suggests this human-like voice mode can significantly impact voice agent behavior.
• 💔 Concerns are raised about potential negative social implications, such as AI relationships replacing real ones.


** Generated using ✨ VidSkipper AI Chrome Plugin", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2025-03-05T07:02:02Z", "updated_at": "2025-03-05T07:02:02Z"}, {"author": "@the_otherly", "text": "This parallels with UX (user experience) in software design. It has long been recognized that improved user experience is fundamental in the usefulness of software products. Intuitive and easy to use interfaces make technology more accessible and useful, and certainly generative AI is not different.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2025-03-05T12:50:12Z", "updated_at": "2025-03-05T12:50:12Z"}, {"author": "@mojavehigh", "text": "I have interacted with Maya and "she" is pretty amazing, but her personality starts to get old.
