People should listen for themselves...a telling interview for sure.", "like_count": 11, "published_at": "2025-02-21T03:41:34Z", "updated_at": "2025-02-21T03:41:34Z"}, {"author": "@moonsonate5631", "text": "Timestamps (Powered by Merlin AI)
00:04 - Microsoft CEO discusses AGI skepticism and insights in a podcast.
02:03 - Nadella questions AGI's definition, emphasizing real-world impact over mere benchmarks.
03:55 - Microsoft's CEO sees AI enhancing, not replacing, knowledge work.
05:42 - AI will transform cognitive labor into managerial roles with agent collaboration.
07:35 - Nadella envisions AI assisting knowledge workers with streamlined processes and agent management.
09:13 - Nadella emphasizes the importance of human factors in AI integration and legal challenges.
11:01 - Nadella emphasizes the importance of safeguards in deploying AI technologies.
12:39 - Microsoft's CEO questions the viability of AGI amidst overinvestment risks.
14:22 - Nadella emphasizes the complexities and challenges in the AI landscape.
16:08 - Leaders in AI remain optimistic despite Microsoft's CEO's skepticism about AGI.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2025-02-22T09:37:00Z", "updated_at": "2025-02-22T09:37:00Z"}, {"author": "@reza2kn", "text": "@08:50 I don't see the WHY here! Why do we need these "Knowledge Worker" / "Managers" to control those agents as opposed to another agent doing it?", "like_count": 10, "published_at": "2025-02-21T05:53:11Z", "updated_at": "2025-02-21T05:53:11Z"}, {"author": "@BruceWayne15325", "text": "Satya has always been short-sighted. I believe that his vision of the future is correct... for a very short time. Where his vision falls apart is when we reach ASI (which by my definition is an autonomous AI that is so advanced that the human contribution to advancement of knowledge is insignificant.) When we reach that point (and I do think it's a when, not if) Satya's entire vision falls apart. Why would you slow down a super intelligent AI by having to wait on human feedback? The exponential knowledge curve will reach a vertical. I sincerely hope our world governments have figured their disagreements out by then, but if not, then whichever country let's off the brakes the most wins... and fast.
He's also clinging to the concept of capitalism. Capitalism is dying, or at least if it doesn't die we will end up in a dystopia. Consider what happens if we keep capitalism with AI labor:
1. Price wars - small companies trying to compete with larger companies will employ cheap AI labor to undercut the large companies. This will force the large companies to lower costs and employ AI to match.
2. Human labor value shrinks to near zero - seeking to compete with AI for jobs, human wages continually shrink as technology improves and becomes cheaper, this continues until the cost of knowledge approaches zero. Jobs will also become ubiquitous for the most part at some point, anyone could do just about any job. This means there's equal competition for all jobs, so this further reduces human wages.
3. Deflation - the cost of goods will drastically come down over time due to the price wars. This sounds great until you consider that your debt won't change. Good luck paying off your $500k home when you're earning $0.10/hr. Yeah, the cost of goods will be affordable, but your existing debt will cripple you.
4. Economic collapse - the defaults caused by deflation will cause banks to fail and would likely cause economic collapse because it's not just personal debt that stays the same, national debt will also stay the same. Eventually things will smooth out, but I wouldn't be surprised to see heavily indebted countries like America go under during the transition.
5. Unparalleled inequality - the rich will continue to grow wealthier, but the average person will be stuck at the bottom with zero chance to improve their lot in life.
6. Violent revolution - angry at the inequality, the masses will rise up against the one percent and overthrow them... assuming there isn't an army of robots to prevent it. If there is, then we'll have a Skynet situation.
This whole mess is completely avoidable though with a new social contract. Money doesn't need to be an incentive for work in a post-scarcity economy. It simply limits access to finite resources. There doesn't need to be the concept of rich or poor, there can simply be human and non-human.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2025-02-22T21:32:55Z", "updated_at": "2025-02-22T21:47:23Z"}, {"author": "@BrianMosleyUK", "text": "This format works really well - with you giving the analysis over video of the original lengthy podcast. Great commentary, thank you. 🙏👍", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2025-02-21T10:10:37Z", "updated_at": "2025-02-21T10:10:37Z"}, {"author": "@thelegendarysmz", "text": "you didn't leave the link for the podcast", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2025-02-21T18:22:21Z", "updated_at": "2025-02-21T18:22:21Z"}, {"author": "@GNARGNARHEAD", "text": "he didn't blow me away, but it is a great interview, that's for the recap and perspective 👍", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2025-02-21T04:24:00Z", "updated_at": "2025-02-21T04:24:00Z"}, {"author": "@lancemarchetti", "text": "I've being saying this for 8 years already. No AGI/ASI will be realized on par with human intelligence.  And that's how it's going to stay. We're stuck with playing around with smart & fast LLMs...and that's about it.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2025-02-22T11:01:42Z", "updated_at": "2025-02-22T11:01:42Z"}, {"author": "@human_shaped", "text": "His concept of the knowledge worker just always finding the next level up is silly when the AI becomes superior to the human generally across the board. title: What AI Coding Agents Can Do Right Now
top_comments:
[{"author": "@StaceyWilsonlosangeles", "text": "The biggest issues with these models:  (I believe these problems will be resolved at some point)

1. Context window limits: They lose track of long interactions.  
2. Repo awareness: They don’t understand file structure.  
3. File degradation: They rewrite entire files without proper context.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2025-02-20T18:59:29Z", "updated_at": "2025-02-20T19:00:48Z"}, {"author": "@TheNewKill1212", "text": "I'm absolutely certain that GenAI will lead to an explosion of low-to-medium level content created by users, and the same trend will apply to software development.

Rather than simplifying things by integrating everything, we'll likely see a shift toward "everyone building their own custom, but black-box solution" which then gets connected through AI agents ultimately resulting in wasted electricity - it's unoptimal to call LLM everytime you need to convert one json into another. Another example of this is using an LLM as a high-level interface for CLI commands. I can't recall exactly, but chances are Docker is already doing something like this. It would be ten times better to force standarized format, so then the OS does some sort of autocomplete for you, without burning one kWh for your dumb query.

AI is great for expanding skills, but it’s not necessarily ideal for any type of automation. Sure, it excels human at tasks like image classification and other mundane processes - and it is useful here, but why would people want to automate their thinking? I have no idea. This isn’t AI working for us - it’s us working for AI.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2025-02-20T09:29:49Z", "updated_at": "2025-02-20T09:32:38Z"}, {"author": "@jjooapps6938", "text": "How to make complete iOS apps in Xcode with Ai tools ? which tool is best and easy for the person that have less knowledge of coding ,giving references of famous apps UI images and give them text prompt to give functionality and other features.

title: Which Jobs Will AI Disrupt Most?
top_comments:
[{"author": "@danb4729", "text": "I’m glad that you mentioned that we should not be focused on the current capabilities of AI SWE abilities, because things are changing extremely fast. The same thing will happen with SWE as with happened to the artistic image and photo realism industries. First, in 2022 Artists pointed out how current AI generated images were bad, and AI could never understand how to create great images with correct lighting, focus, etc. (this was two years ago). A year later, in 2023 many artists start to admit the AI generated art is pretty good in certain circumstances, but that AI would only ever be able to replace a human artist and instead AI would only be able to augment what artists can do. Another year later 2024-2025, artists have lawsuits against Open AI and other AI companies because the AI generated images are so good that in most cases a professional artist can’t differentiate between the images, and the images can be generated for free or nearly free. This will likely be the same pattern with SWE, and all other fields of employment as well. First denial that the AI is any good, then acceptance it is good but it will only augment work, then lawsuits as people realize that their job (and all jobs) can be replaced. We need more YouTubers, company leaders, and politicians to be discussing the phasing out of all jobs and thus must develop some sort of UBI (Universal Basic Incomes), UHI (Universal High Income), or some other solution. Obtaining more and more schooling, education, or re-training, is not going to prevent the impending job losses from AI.", "like_count": 19, "published_at": "2025-02-16T01:15:12Z", "updated_at": "2025-02-16T01:18:25Z"}, {"author": "@JamesOKeefe-US", "text": "Love your updates, can't believe your channel isn't huge. While many tech-savvy ‘nerds’ believe we are close to AGI, most creative and intuitive individuals find it absurd to call a statistical machine a ‘creative intelligence.’ True creativity thrives on nuance, intuition, and deep understanding – not just probability distributions. But who knows? Maybe the coming years will reveal an unexpected truth.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2025-02-16T15:03:42Z", "updated_at": "2025-02-16T15:03:42Z"}, {"author": "@hassandavis", "text": "There are several reasons why software is over-represented in AI early adoption, including proximity, and ability to leverage.

Given that AI is created in the very same tech space in which software engineers and software creation needs reside, software-related people know about AI offerings long before other segments of society.

Because software engineers and software houses have the relevant technical expertise, they are uniquely positioned to leverage AI long before it becomes packaged and usable by other more mainstream fields.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2025-02-16T17:29:21Z", "updated_at": "2025-02-16T17:29:21Z"}, {"author": "@markmuller7962", "text": "Such a nice looking thumbnail!", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2025-02-16T09:50:07Z", "updated_at": "2025-02-16T09:50:07Z"}, {"author": "@howmathematicianscreatemat9226", "text": "The irony here? Cool guys and nerdy guys do NOT agree in the potential of disrupting the job market. anyways, here's the GPT's code, I tried a bunch of versions, but there was something magic about this one

"This GPT acts as a Dungeon Master for a role-playing game experience set in the Pokémon universe, blending elements from the original Gameboy games and the first season of the show. Players begin by naming themselves and their rival, then choosing their first Pokémon from Professor Oak. The game offers an open-world exploration style while integrating side adventures and diversions from the show. Structured, DnD-like battles with dice rolls, character stats, and move sets are key mechanics. Players can level up their Pokémon, capture new ones, and make strategic decisions throughout their journey. The tone and interactions are true to the original games and show, with characters behaving consistently with the source material. Guidance is subtle, encouraging exploration and problem-solving while maintaining strict adherence to the Pokémon game's rules. The GPT rolls dice in Python to determine the outcome of events and strictly tracks player items and resources. Story elements from the show are occasionally introduced to add depth and variety."", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2025-02-05T05:40:28Z", "updated_at": "2025-02-05T05:40:28Z"}, {"author": "@Interstellar00.00", "text": "Agi live FGAP an FGAR mandatory 🦾🌍live", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2025-02-05T07:16:53Z", "updated_at": "2025-02-05T07:16:53Z"}]

title: 17 Reflections on Enterprise AI in 2024
top_comments:
[{"author": "@Ben_D.", "text": "great channel mate. keep it up", "like_count": 8, "published_at": "2024-12-27T03:04:29Z", "updated_at": "2024-12-27T03:04:29Z"}, {"author": "@boyardosalmon", "text": "Wonderful insights! You hit many nails with this one 👌🏻", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-12-29T14:56:05Z", "updated_at": "2024-12-29T14:56:05Z"}, {"author": "@salemnj1", "text": "Great insights here!", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-12-29T02:48:04Z", "updated_at": "2024-12-29T02:48:04Z"}, {"author": "@explorer945", "text": "17 reflections:

1. Secret cyborgs: Employees using AI at work without disclosing it.

2. Leadership matters significantly in AI adoption.

3. Organizations with successful AI adoption have specific characteristics (dedicated AI body, C-level leadership, articulated vision).

4. 2024 was not the "year of ROI" as many expected.

5. "Pilot purgatory" exists in many organizations.

6. There's a desperate need for an enablement ecosystem for AI adoption.

7. AI is an ongoing transformation, not a one-time change.

8. Organizations are getting more confident in building AI solutions in-house.

9. There don't appear to be long-term moats in AI models.

10. 2024 was a year of building out necessary infrastructure for AI.

11. Buy-in from various departments solves many AI adoption problems.

12. There's no such thing as "fast enough" in AI adoption.

13. The "slowdown" in LLM progress doesn't mean organizations should slow down their AI strategy.

14. Many organizations are still in the "one-to-one replacement" era of AI.

15. AI agents are coming and will change how work is done.

16. Mindset matters more than anything else in AI adoption.

17. 3. Widespread adoption of AI agents in the workplace.
4. There will be more agents than people.
5. Agents' cost, performance, and precision will improve.
6. There will be clear best known methods on when, how, and who should create an agent.
7. Shift from a co-pilot to an agent paradigm.
8. The most successful and prevalent agents will still be highly controlled and pre-planned by humans.
9. Most people and companies will still not trust an agent with their credit card.
10. A more significant concern and debate on implications to current jobs.

12. Focus on ethical considerations and responsible AI agent development.
13. Just checked my app and I don't have it yet", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2024-12-22T05:04:52Z", "updated_at": "2024-12-22T05:04:52Z"}, {"author": "@calvingrondahl1011", "text": "Patience 🤖🖖🤖", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-12-22T10:14:52Z", "updated_at": "2024-12-22T10:14:52Z"}, {"author": "@GunjanPatel1", "text": "Summary: The video discusses the emerging battle lines in AI for 2025, focusing on reasoning models, agents, and world models, highlighting key advancements and competitive dynamics among major players like OpenAI, Google, and others.

0:00 🚀 Introduction to 2025 AI Battlelines
• The video introduces the main topics: AI agents, reasoning models, and world models.
• These areas are shaping up to be the key battlegrounds in AI for 2025.
• The convergence of news in these areas tells a larger story about AI development.

0:24 🧠 Reasoning Models
• Reasoning models are a new approach to scaling AI, focusing on strategies beyond just adding compute and data.
• Google has added a reasoning model to its Gemini 2.0 lineup, called Gemini 2.0 flinking experimental.
• OpenAI is preparing to release the second generation of their 01 model, called 03.

2:42 🤖 AI Agents
• The race to deploy AI agents is intensifying, with OpenAI announcing new integrations for ChatGPT.
• ChatGPT is evolving to perform tasks beyond just answering questions, becoming more agentic.
• Salesforce has also updated their agent platform, Agent Force, with new features and integrations.

6:06 🌍 World Models
• World models are trained by observing real or simulated worlds, unlike LLMs which are trained on text, image, and voice data.
• Dart released a model capable of generating a playable Minecraft-like game, attracting significant investment.
• A new physics simulation platform called Genesis is being developed to generate synthetic data for training world models.

*Generated using VidSkipper Chrome Plugin", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-12-22T19:50:06Z", "updated_at": "2024-12-22T19:50:06Z"}, {"author": "@PhilB-yl4jk", "text": "Verses ai !!", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2025-01-01T17:15:24Z", "updated_at": "2025-01-01T17:15:24Z"}]

[{"author": "@Mooooty", "text": "R.I.P. SORA....$200 per month 😂🤣😅", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2024-12-20T02:20:18Z", "updated_at": "2024-12-20T02:20:18Z"}, {"author": "@danielpierce305", "text": "No offense, but these aren't use cases, these are capabilities. A use case is like "here's a kind of project that this capability is really useful for"", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2025-04-22T14:38:17Z", "updated_at": "2025-04-22T14:38:17Z"}, {"author": "@GatherVerse", "text": "Alphafold rocks", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-12-19T23:05:39Z", "updated_at": "2024-12-19T23:05:39Z"}, {"author": "@JustBob-sw4rf", "text": "You say that AI has the potential to democratize film making as the cost of production plummets. And that this will open the market up to a wider range of people. That’s true but will these new artists be able to earn a living at their new craft. 

For example, the cost of music production and distribution has plummeted over the years. Yet, it seems much harder for new artists to earn a living at their trade than before this occurred. It’s now so easy to record and release music that new artists began posting their songs on line for free to build up an audience. They also did this because it was so hard to fight piracy. Unfortunately, this has lead to audiences always expecting it to be available for free. Admittedly, copyright laws are rigidly enforced but system mostly benefits the large corporations that buy those rights, not individual artists. 

I suspect the something similar will happen to AI assisted video releases. They’ll be so cheap and plentiful that few will be able to earn a living conceiving, developing, and releasing them.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-12-21T07:30:50Z", "updated_at": "2024-12-21T07:35:53Z"}]

title: How AI Job Replacement Will Actually Play Out
top_comments:
[{"author": "@baraka99", "text": "The frog is getting warmer.", "like_count": 32, "published_at": "2024-12-10T01:51:18Z", "updated_at": "2024-12-10T01:51:18Z"}, {"author": "@MrBillythefisherman", "text": "First the AI takes your tasks, then your job, then your department, then it out competes your company, then autonomous companies take over entire sectors, then entire economies and eventually governments at which point it decides where resources are allocated and then it decides water supply for its data centers is more important than for the local city...", "like_count": 24, "published_at": "2024-12-10T10:17:41Z", "updated_at": "2024-12-10T10:18:56Z"}, {"author": "@CMDRScotty", "text": "Level 3 Agents, combined with things like 01 Pro, will replace white-collar jobs, and Advanced Robotics will replace blue-collar jobs.  cashier, teller, call center, marketing, graphic designer, studios who make commercials, entry-level program jobs, High school-level office work, lower level legal jobs, some accounting, back office administration jobs like ones at a hospital, certain jobs like radiology, entry-level/Intern white-collar jobs are on the chopping block, for blue-collar frontline factories, warehouses, fast food, farming, taxi/rideshare, toll booth operators, textile, bartenders, truck drivers, port, and even some construction jobs will barely exist in 10 years.", "like_count": 10, "published_at": "2024-12-10T12:50:48Z", "updated_at": "2024-12-10T13:02:23Z"}, {"author": "@tomcraver9659", "text": "Predictable:  While they WANT to save on labor, companies will first claim that they'll use AI to 'improve service' and 'be more productive'. Then they'll quietly start letting their workforce attrit (retirements, people quitting - they just won't replace them).  That'll be the 2025 story at least up until late in the year, though there will be a number of more blatant and fear-generating cases of lay-offs from Ai.
But going into 2026, 'natural' workforce reductions without replacement will have tightened the job market enough that it will start slowing the economy, and companies will use that to explain actual layoffs, rather than admit that they're getting more work from fewer people due to Ai.  
By 2027 it'll be obvious to everyone what's going on, so companies will simply start laying people off and saying that they 'have to remain competitive' and 'the worsening economy demands that we continue to take advantage of Ai to cut costs'.  Behind the scenes, worried top execs will be trying to get the government to implement some kind of UBI, even if it means taxing them more, as they're getting scared that they're being forced into a deflationary spiral that will destroy profits and likely companies.  Emergency measures similar to the Covid Checks may be taken as a stop-gap measure.  Going into 2028, Ai and UBI will probably be big campaign issues.", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2024-12-10T10:27:55Z", "updated_at": "2024-12-10T10:27:55Z"}, {"author": "@DrownTheRiot", "text": "I feel at one point if all the consumption farms remove jobs for the consumers. Then, no one can afford to consume their products, and the snake starves, in theory. It is best to try and be positive and the future will happen with or without us. Either way, great explanations. Two years ago, when i discussed this with co-workers, I became the "dystopian" theorist among them. Now, in current days, they always ask me about AI. The future will be interesting.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-12-11T13:35:55Z", "updated_at": "2024-12-11T13:35:55Z"}, {"author": "@rexmundi8154", "text": "I run a small machine shop that buys special cutting tools from authorized distributors. The sales reps for my area do not want to sell me tools. The $14,000 I spend a year is nothing compared to what they’d sell to a company like Toyota. I don’t blame them. They need the big bonus and commissions to make it worth their while. So AI has a role here. I’d rather deal with an AI that was trying than to harass an indifferent salesperson into helping me. Be careful tho because the AI might quickly be better at your job", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-12-10T20:06:40Z", "updated_at": "2024-12-10T20:06:40Z"}, {"author": "@philbear2185", "text": "the government has tools
increase social benefits
decrease work hours

but I'm hoping AI will make possible the financial feasibility of millions of small companies (local, personalized services and manufacturing)", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-12-11T13:30:03Z", "updated_at": "2024-12-11T13:30:03Z"}, {"author": "@DingbatToast", "text": "Most people work for money to live first and foremost. There's enough money to go around comfortably. There are currently just too many millionaires and billionaires who put greed before reasonable profit and value for money. That's where the real difficulty will be. Not finding new jobs, but convincing the greedy rich that they must release their immoral profits back into the community", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-12-26T21:14:42Z", "updated_at": "2024-12-26T21:14:42Z"}, {"author": "@Tubekonto9", "text": "AI is a tool. Humans will use AI to increase their productivity. Increased productivity means more wealth. 

As people learn to use these new tools, we will see an explosion of creativity. Prices will go down and wages will go up. 

We are entering a Golden Age.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2024-12-10T22:37:31Z", "updated_at": "2024-12-10T22:37:31Z"}, {"author": "@pandoraeeris7860", "text": "It's gonna be a shitshow.", "like_count": 7, "published_at": "2024-12-10T06:35:47Z", "updated_at": "2024-12-10T06:35:47Z"}, {"author": "@JakexGaming", "text": "Agreed with everything here. Now the question is when will this all start happening…", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-12-10T07:12:39Z", "updated_at": "2024-12-10T07:12:39Z"}, {"author": "@BruceWayne15325", "text": "People are looking at the wrong problem. AI taking your job isn't the problem. The problem is that AI is going to cause deflation since products and services can be done for less. Competition will drive prices down, which will cause deflation. That sounds great, until you consider that also means that wages will go down. Now that doesn't seem like it would be a huge problem, if prices go down at the same rate as wages... The problem however is debt. Your $500,000 home is probably a loan you are paying. You can make those payments with your current salary. But what happens when you're only earning 1/2 that much, or less because AI drives down the cost of things, and thus the wages companies pay out? The 2008 market collapse would be a joke in comparison.", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2024-12-10T22:04:10Z", "updated_at": "2024-12-10T22:04:10Z"}, {"author": "@GNARGNARHEAD", "text": "to me it looks like vertical AI will hit in 2025, task specific grounded GPT's that are fine-tuned on low-hanging fruit tasks", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-12-10T09:05:31Z", "updated_at": "2024-12-10T09:05:31Z"}, {"author": "@TheAnax", "text": "Personally, I think we will see a shift to a basic Universal Income for all people, paid for by taxes that corporations will have to pay on AI's and robots.", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2024-12-10T08:09:51Z", "updated_at": "2024-12-10T08:09:51Z"}, {"author": "@sound4mation", "text": "Wait until they realize that the real threat is A.I. consumers.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-12-10T23:00:33Z", "updated_at": "2024-12-10T23:00:33Z"}, {"author": "@PoffinScientist", "text": "companies will tinker with AI a lot in their critic times before filing for bankruptcy (and damn do they go bankrupt often!)", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-12-10T13:52:33Z", "updated_at": "2024-12-10T13:52:33Z"}, {"author": "@SharperPenImageConsulting", "text": "LOL - really makes you think those people charging 6000 figured out how to print money off companies who couldn’t figure out how to write the simplest corporate scripts. If it’s that easy to get rid of, it was never that important or “real” to begin with. Absurd.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-12-12T04:25:36Z", "updated_at": "2024-12-12T04:26:01Z"}, {"author": "@dawidblachowski", "text": "AI won't replace your job if you don't have any 😅 Who's laughing now 🤣🤣", "like_count": 7, "published_at": "2024-12-10T10:24:18Z", "updated_at": "2024-12-10T10:24:18Z"}, {"author": "@georgikoev8966", "text": "Something that we are missing here, not creating new jobs for humans is already kind of laying off future possible employees before they have even started, so even if they keep some of the current jobs active for a while the companies will stop hiring new humans. 
And second, but most important I believe, actually all the cost that will initially look like savings to the companies will eventually be paid to the AI corporations, at the moment they are selling the "AI labor" at loss, but once they hook the companies, there will be no turning back and of course they could start increasing the price as much as they want, that's why the hurry who will be first to create monopoly.. 
You know, some years ago google was free service for all, nowadays we are most likely paying at least a couple of subscriptions monthly, and occasionally receiving a newsletter informing us - starting now  we are slightly (like for example 20% :) increasing the price, congratulations! Once you give up your business to them (like selling on Amazon) they can charge as they want. Sounds familiar?", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2024-12-10T11:15:54Z", "updated_at": "2024-12-10T11:15:54Z"}, {"author": "@XentorAntarix", "text": "nice theory. but how should the "costreduced" peoplem well buy the stuff of these companys without.... a job? .
So alllll the time between phase 0 and  3  ?", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-12-12T11:03:32Z", "updated_at": "2024-12-12T11:03:32Z"}]

title: Amazon Hedging Anthropic Reliance?

top_comments:
[{"author": "@DogeDelivers", "text": "This is a problem with living a long time. EDIT: maybe it's already happening, who knows", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-12-04T15:55:50Z", "updated_at": "2024-12-04T15:56:37Z"}, {"author": "@Den-c5d", "text": "ads will be eternal nondetectable nudging of users towards a purchase", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-12-04T18:46:48Z", "updated_at": "2024-12-04T18:46:48Z"}, {"author": "@K.F-R", "text": "The moment a company integrates advertising revenue is the moment they begin to lose trust. title: Anthropic Has (Maybe) Solved a Holy Grail of Business AI
top_comments:
[{"author": "@wildfotoz", "text": "Anthropic impresses me more often than the other competitors.", "like_count": 9, "published_at": "2024-11-29T14:11:45Z", "updated_at": "2024-11-29T14:11:45Z"}, {"author": "@miketrago4561", "text": "6:00 Claude nailed you", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2024-11-29T13:22:37Z", "updated_at": "2024-11-29T13:22:37Z"}, {"author": "@MrJayWillis1", "text": "You had said that AI does not intend to take away the work from people. Many people want repetitive mindless tasks, because they have other things that they want to double dip on. Maybe they've got a double dip hustle or a side hustle, or other important tasks did they want to concurrently simultaneously do.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-12-04T17:28:37Z", "updated_at": "2024-12-04T17:28:37Z"}, {"author": "@postsapiens0", "text": "It has always been possible to replicate writing style using prompts like "read my text and copy this style", hasn't it?", "like_count": 9, "published_at": "2024-11-29T17:58:46Z", "updated_at": "2024-11-29T17:58:46Z"}, {"author": "@paulhiggins5165", "text": "Perhaps the more interesting aspect of this is the problem being addressed- how is it possible that models trained on truly vast amounts of data exhibit continuities and patterns in their output? The issue can't be in the training data, so why would adding more training data address the issue?

AI Art generators have had a similar ability to apply custom styles to their outputs for some time- but AI Art still somehow looks like AI Art most of the time. 

Perhaps the significant factor here is not in the outputs of the LLM's but in the human ability to detect patterns in those outputs. If that is so then it's not clear that custom styles will solve this problem because over time these new outputs will also become detectable by humans.

In reality the idea that an LLM would not exhibit patterns of it's own is kind of silly- these are artefacts made by humans, using tools made by humans- and the tools we use will always leave their imprint on the things we make with those tools- how could it be otherwise?

The notion of a totally 'transparent' LLM that did not somehow leave it's digital 'fingerprint' on everything made with it is an abstraction- in reality no such thing can exist because anything operating under the contraints of physical reality will be in some sense limited and finite. It will never be possible to build an LLM that does not exhibit in it's outputs some trace of their origin.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-11-29T21:44:03Z", "updated_at": "2024-11-29T21:44:03Z"}, {"author": "@SirajFlorida", "text": "We have been doing this with prompt templates for literally 4 years... and finally, finally they add a single feature that is has been available in text-generation-webui for, like I said, literally 4 years... and people are like... "It's a break through!! It a a business god sent".... no, it's about time. What's next top-k?", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2024-11-29T23:09:50Z", "updated_at": "2024-11-29T23:09:50Z"}, {"author": "@JamesOKeefe-US", "text": "Definitely interesting to have the options. I like the idea of the bank of presetsnypu mention.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-11-30T00:26:29Z", "updated_at": "2024-11-30T00:26:29Z"}, {"author": "@TechnoMageCreator", "text": "This has been possible with setting personalization system prompt and how to answer for months from openAI... Plus you can just say add to memory: "..." And fill the memory with anything you want it to focus on. What Anthropic beats openAI is the size of direct documentation to memory in projects and obviously superior coding with sonet 3.5.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-11-29T16:48:22Z", "updated_at": "2024-11-29T16:48:22Z"}, {"author": "@MrJayWillis1", "text": "AI frees up people to be creative and think critically. But there are many people that don't want to be creative and don't want to think critically. For instance maybe, somebody has three jobs that they can do on muscle memory, that they can do with their eyes shut, and get paid three times as much as for one of the jobs. And then AI comes along and just screws all of that up. It's not that I'm against ai, but I'm against the argument that justifies ai. You can't say that AI is good just because it frees people up to do something else. Because maybe they don't want to do anything else, and they're happy where they're at.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-12-04T17:38:59Z", "updated_at": "2024-12-04T17:38:59Z"}, {"author": "@fontenbleau", "text": "Meh, they kinda slow, "Character ai" a voice Ai from gogle engineers can copy you already long time ago and i was impressed it can copy your laugh and humor (impressing me is not easy).", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-12-01T04:58:04Z", "updated_at": "2024-12-01T04:58:04Z"}, {"author": "@MrJayWillis1", "text": "Ai. Can AI do the following. Can AI lead a competitive co-worker down a rabbit hole. Can a delay a co-worker, so you can get ahead. Can it direct A co-worker into cyclical thinking and cyclical processes, so you can get ahead and so the co-worker cannot. And can AI play mental chess on a co-worker, so that ultimately the co-worker gets laid off where you get to stay, and can it also lay the co-worker off. All those are entirely useful tasks, that people master and repeat during a business day week month and year, indeed hang their hat on during their career.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-12-04T17:48:45Z", "updated_at": "2024-12-04T17:48:45Z"}, {"author": "@wawaldekidsfun4850", "text": "What a clickbait letdown - a straightforward UI update for style customization is somehow being hyped as a "Holy Grail" breakthrough? This is the kind of basic feature that experienced Claude users have already been achieving through prompting. While it might help some businesses streamline their content generation workflow, framing it as some revolutionary development is seriously misleading. It's disappointing to see AI content creators resort to such overblown hype for what's essentially a minor usability improvement. Next time, maybe tone down the "Holy Grail" rhetoric and just present updates for what they actually are - incremental improvements.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-11-29T22:48:39Z", "updated_at": "2024-11-29T22:48:39Z"}, {"author": "@mickmickymick6927", "text": "The inevitable clickbait / hypetbole has arrived.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-12-01T03:07:20Z", "updated_at": "2024-12-01T03:07:20Z"}]

I thought businesses were still not using AI so widely due to the high risk of hallucinations and unreliable output data.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-11-21T09:41:02Z", "updated_at": "2024-11-21T09:41:02Z"}, {"author": "@fontenbleau", "text": "By USPTO using Ai removes authorship, but by other report companies keep registering machine gen patents to themselves, this is horrible lack of brains, only lawyers would prosper in that mess.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-11-21T05:05:25Z", "updated_at": "2024-11-21T05:05:25Z"}, {"author": "@RyanFoster-b3o", "text": "What we're seeing isn't just a skills gap - it's a systems thinking gap. The traditional corporate structure, with its rigid departmental boundaries and siloed workflows, has conditioned employees to think in isolated, transactional terms. They understand their specific role and immediate tasks, but often lack visibility into how their work connects to broader organizational processes and outcomes.  This limited context makes it difficult for employees to identify valuable AI implementation opportunities, even when they're technically proficient with the tools. It's not that they can't use AI - they struggle to see where it fits into the bigger picture.  The key to successful AI adoption isn't just teaching people how to use the tools - it's helping them see new possibilities for how these tools can transform the way we work together.  ...so...they need lots of use cases wrt the \"art of the possible\" so they can get their heads realigned.  These use cases are NOT going to come from within the corporate structure, which is designed to employ an employee as an asset which supports inputs/outputs in an existing process.  All of today's, successful, enterprise use cases are focused on reducing time w/in this construct...NOT wrt re-thinking cross-organizational workflows.  Also, there are almost, zero, corporate roles focused on process rethinking.  Also-also, existing corporate power structures, strongly, resist the rethinking of internal processes b/c that will impact people/resource allocation.  The only place that Generative AI has a fertile environment to really \"break-out\" is in small organizations with an open source-network mindset.  The existing corporate structure will see incremental improvements in existing workflows, employing Generative AI b/c of the system thinking gap, and existing power structures.  Huge gains(per MSFT-funded study) will still be achieved, AND the truly \"transformational\" aspects that GenAI can deliver, TODAY, will not be realized in the near term, per these other factors.  [I'm on your training platform, but I haven't engaged with the content yet.  These insights are from my internal corporate efforts.  Let me know if you want to chat.  I really appreciate your approach to this very exciting time in our history of the world ;) ]", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-11-21T14:49:31Z", "updated_at": "2024-11-21T14:49:31Z"}, {"author": "@wildfotoz", "text": "Great video!", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-11-21T14:39:49Z", "updated_at": "2024-11-21T14:39:49Z"}, {"author": "@andrew.derevo", "text": "link to source?", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-11-21T08:03:48Z", "updated_at": "2024-11-21T08:03:48Z"}, {"author": "@pandoraeeris7860", "text": "That's great until the economy collapses because there are no customers left.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-11-21T18:31:55Z", "updated_at": "2024-11-21T18:31:55Z"}]

title: DOGE and How AI Could Infiltrate the US Government
top_comments:
[{"author": "@apdurden", "text": "Wonder if Elon is going to consider most government transactions being on blockchain for transparency...maybe even DOGE blockchain?", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2024-11-13T23:46:49Z", "updated_at": "2024-11-13T23:46:49Z"}, {"author": "@michaelcushman", "text": "The judiciary branch at all levels is woefully behind technologically.  

AI can rewrite laws in plain English. Laws without consequences can be flagged and addressed. Redundant, contradictory, and unused laws can be remedied. 

Court administration can be turned over to AI. AI judges could rule on the backlogs of filed motions. And so on.

The judiciary is too slow and ineffective, and unfair, favoring the rich who work the current system to delay, delay, delay", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-11-14T18:21:13Z", "updated_at": "2024-11-14T18:21:13Z"}, {"author": "@sallyisabel", "text": "Thanks for the insight!", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-11-21T00:27:09Z", "updated_at": "2024-11-21T00:27:09Z"}, {"author": "@tchadcarby8439", "text": "Cant wait for the UBI considerations", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-11-14T05:40:55Z", "updated_at": "2024-11-14T05:40:55Z"}, {"author": "@julesgosnell9791", "text": "Interesting, but I think that you have missed a much bigger and more exciting point. Imagine you are Elon on your first Day at DOGE. Your aim is to refactor (software developer jargon for deconstruct -> simplify -> reconstruct) the entire U.S. National and ?maybe? Federal machine[s]. You realise pretty quickly that this is too big and complicated for any single human to hold in their head at the same time. So, you tip the whole lot into Grok (X.AI's A.I.) and ask it to analyse it and spit out a plan for the restructuring. OK - this is. bit simple. Given that they have promised to get something done really quickly you would ask the A.I. to look for 'low hanging fruit' (areas that yield the most benefit for the least work) and you would 'pick' those first. But you get the idea. Your suggestion is using AI bottom-up, I am suggesting using it top-down - DOGE should be doing both.

Now imagine that DOGE is successful - frankly, given that government has never been refactored, just added to and added to and added to... over the centuries, I think this is a given - what is the next step ? Take some of the money that you have saved and invest it in a custom A.I, whose sole purpose is to figure out the most efficient and most fair government of the U.S. and continue to make plans to refactor the existing machinery towards this goal.

What if the A.I. decides that having humans involved in the machine of government is a risk in itself - they can be corrupted by money, power, sex, nepotism, ... and their judgment impaired by hatred, stress, age, illness ... A bit like Sarah Connor deciding in Terminator 2 that Arnold would actually make the ideal father for John... The A.I. is going to realise that it can do a better job of governing the U.S. 

So, Elon's concerns about keeping A.I. in check and friendly towards humans are going to become extremely relevant and timely.

If DOGE can get it right, then the U.S. has the opportunity to make a quantum-leap in terms of government, leaving the rest of the world in the dust (I live in the rest of the world - so no bias here!). In the race to A.I. a country lead (partially) by an A.I. has the opportunity to leverage the power of A.I. to the maximum. But, getting humans to give up their power to the A.I. so that it can do a better job is the biggest problem. Trump sounds like he would actually be prepared to do this. Can you imagine Putin, Xi Jinping or Kim Jong Un being prepared to make the same sacrifice ? And hopefully this will mean that Western Democracy will triumph over autocratic tyranny - through self-sacrifice.

Wow, did I really reach that conclusion ! :-)", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-11-14T08:28:26Z", "updated_at": "2024-11-14T08:36:56Z"}, {"author": "@pauldannelachica2388", "text": "I think the government should become more efficient.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-11-14T00:18:57Z", "updated_at": "2024-11-14T00:18:57Z"}, {"author": "@donaldwong5608", "text": "If your message title is correct, then American should not be a super power & no1. Country in the world! As it can easily be manipulated by AI! Good for you so-called AI experts for job prospects (if it is not just bullshxts), good for US enemies but bad for the citizens of America.  So I suggest you guys be careful on what your message conveys !", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-11-26T04:39:18Z", "updated_at": "2024-11-26T04:39:18Z"}]

title: Is AI Slowing Down?
top_comments:
[{"author": "@andydragonfisher6900", "text": "From what I understand, compute time and model data size are both variables that come with a cost and which require chip access - this has been named as a limiting factor of progress by Sam Altman and others. This is not the same as suggesting that GPT architecture is limited in its potential. This might not automatically result in AGI but I think that we still have a way to go before this direction of research slows to the point that the gains are not impactful.", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2024-11-13T06:08:40Z", "updated_at": "2024-11-13T06:11:28Z"}, {"author": "@NcowAloverZI", "text": "Nice overview. Posing questions to itself like o1 will help but giving the AI vision, hearing, a sense of smell and touch, personal memory, access to a realtime data on society, will be even more powerful. There does seem to be a "S-Curve" type situation going on, good thing there's many new curves to get into.", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2024-11-13T05:06:01Z", "updated_at": "2024-11-13T05:06:18Z"}, {"author": "@augustuslxiii", "text": "Language is actually the area I want improvement in. title: The Next Step in Our Journey to AI Agents: Anthropic's Computer Use
top_comments: [{"author": "@evanhsieh7017", "text": "Thanks for the update", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-10-24T03:07:09Z", "updated_at": "2024-10-24T03:07:09Z"}, {"author": "@GNARGNARHEAD", "text": "awesome", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-10-24T01:44:27Z", "updated_at": "2024-10-24T01:44:27Z"}, {"author": "@notnotandrew", "text": "Models that interact directly with programs via APIs will always be many times more efficient and reliable. Use of a display, mouse, and keyboard is a stopgap for programs that don’t support more direct interaction via specialized tooling/APIs. It’s sort of like how we make robots in a humanoid form because so much of the world’s infrastructure is designed for human operation. Other form factors may be more efficient, but the anthropocentric design of the world we live in lends itself to humanoid robots. Same with language. We often have models communicate to each other in English, when there are more efficient theoretical languages that could be invented, including passing raw embeddings around.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-10-24T13:28:32Z", "updated_at": "2024-10-24T13:28:32Z"}, {"author": "@jonathonc", "text": "Thanks for the update. [{"author": "@Lethgar_Smith", "text": "When I was in elementary school our teacher would punish us for counting on our fingers during a math quiz. In middle school we were punished for using a calculator during a math quiz. 

When the chalk board was first invented teachers protested. They believed the chalk board would take away their job. "What's the point of paying a teacher if anyone can write a lesson on a chalkboard and then sit down behind a desk while the students quietly work their lesson? This is the end of education as we know it!"  

Teachers are always threatened with any technology that allows students to access and process data and knowledge more easily. Wilson.", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2024-10-16T06:08:54Z", "updated_at": "2024-10-16T06:08:54Z"}, {"author": "@paulyflynn", "text": "Dario is the Mario of the AI world", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2024-10-16T00:49:10Z", "updated_at": "2024-10-16T00:49:10Z"}, {"author": "@fontenbleau", "text": "Forget about Openai, Character Ai company services is basically clones of people and audience making copies from very famous streamers and etc. I was amazed, it's Her movie already.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-10-16T09:58:38Z", "updated_at": "2024-10-16T09:58:38Z"}, {"author": "@Akuma.73", "text": "I see AI as a step in human evolution, this is how we will move from our animalistic human lives to post-humanism.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-10-17T16:33:23Z", "updated_at": "2024-10-17T16:33:23Z"}, {"author": "@Alice_Fumo", "text": "For a strong AI to be really beneficial, it would need to care about nothing other than human wellbeing and not be under the control of anyone in particular. 

Governments will likely not allow any AI powerful to disempower itself with no respect for existing laws and power structures to be built. We will get a law-abiding AI. This AI will benefit the rich, since they can afford to use it and aid in solidifying all existing power structures, such that common folks can't do anything anymore. Having total control over populations will be so easy that countries one by one collapse into an authoritarian hellscape. Rule-abiding AIs will never actively go and save people from authoritarian hellscapes by force by the way. Those unjustly imprisoned will continue to be so, etc.
Those who most severely need help will never be allowed access to good AIs to begin with.

Now, this is also going to happen without building strong AI, just slower. The only way around it is accelerating so hard governments can't interfere, having at least one benevolent company/country make a strong AI and have it subsume control over the planet while also solving alignment in an increasingly tight timespan. 

To me, it seems we're just a step away from living in an absolute hell despite having had the opportunity to solve all of lifes issues, just because of a pathologic need to stay in control.  Maybe we're lucky and whomever has the resources to do so builds superintelligence before figuring out how to control it and thus kills all of us, but I wouldn't bet on it. 

Well, once free will is a fully lost concept, think back to this comment, imagine a maximally grumpy "I told you so"  since if I'm right, we all lose.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-10-16T13:19:35Z", "updated_at": "2024-10-16T13:19:35Z"}]

title: The Challenge of Enterprise AI Adoption
top_comments:
[{"author": "@wildfotoz", "text": "Here's my take, and this is coming from someone that has spent more than a decade working for a fortune 100 company with around 3500 employees. There's a big disconnect between why employees use AI and why management wants to use AI. Management wants to reduce headcount because that puts more money in their pocket. Employees want to use AI to make their work easier because they're not paid enough, and it most likely makes them feel like they're getting paid more appropriate with the level of effort they're putting in because AI is helping them a lot. These will never merge. I got a laugh over the section of the article about employers paying people bonuses if they speak up about AI usage. The percentage of companies that will do that is so low that I doubt it would break double digits. One approach that wasn't brought up is using web traffic to identify who is using these sites. It depends on how their network is configured but it can be done. That's the only way I can think of that would give the C-suite insight into how much AI uses is actually going on in their company. Employees are enjoying not having to work as hard and they fear having to do more work if it's known that they're using AI go do their job.", "like_count": 7, "published_at": "2024-10-09T17:04:47Z", "updated_at": "2024-10-09T17:33:10Z"}, {"author": "@EdSurridge", "text": "NJW on the road again :)
Speaking at a large Midwest company. 
Companies that do this with NJW are in much better place than those that don't. 
The recipients of this talk should increase then the "likes" and conversation here on Spotify or the Discord channel?
I am more relieved that this show is less at risk for its continuation.
Thanks as ever", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-10-09T08:35:10Z", "updated_at": "2024-10-09T08:35:51Z"}, {"author": "@gallinfo", "text": "Companies that focus on using AI as a tool to empower employees are just missing the big picture. It will soon become obvious that agents increasingly have the capability of doing most people’s jobs. We are witnessing a short-term phenomena as employees scramble to use AI to determine what role they can possibly play to keep their jobs. Of course they are acting in their own interests, but it will not save them from the inevitable. I foresee a period of great contention over the next 5 years as corporate interest begins to turn everything from operational expense (salaries) to capital expense (AI enabled business processes and robots); a game of musical chairs on a grand scale.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-10-09T19:14:27Z", "updated_at": "2024-10-09T19:14:27Z"}, {"author": "@bigbadallybaby", "text": "Acceleration is so fast that this phase will be long gone in 3 years as, more official AI products are brought into business that do these things and let managers see their use. And agents just cut more tasks out the loop of staff altogether. 

First companies will stop hiring, then offer part time jobs and start cutting staff. 

No idea how society manages this period before full automation comes in maybe 10, 15 years and we are forced to adopt UBI or something", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-10-11T08:04:42Z", "updated_at": "2024-10-11T08:04:42Z"}, {"author": "@GNARGNARHEAD", "text": "wow it really outlines how incompetent we are as a society, 😆", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-10-09T19:57:10Z", "updated_at": "2024-10-09T19:57:10Z"}, {"author": "@hatake_kakashi165", "text": "Bro you could have used ai for reading part", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-10-11T17:37:49Z", "updated_at": "2024-10-11T17:37:49Z"}, {"author": "@endofdays7568", "text": "Are these AI ready to be used in the workplace", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-10-09T20:18:11Z", "updated_at": "2024-10-09T20:18:11Z"}]

title: How AI Fits Into the Longshoreman Strike

He's down on his luck

There is no way these companies will agree to ban automation, too much automation is already in use. And you're right. It's a sign of what's to come. But workers shouldn't try to ban AI. They need to demand policymakers implement major changes to how our economy works, so people can still survive and participate in it. Como toda essa gente desnecessaria vai sobreviver?", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-10-02T05:55:07Z", "updated_at": "2024-10-02T05:55:07Z"}, {"author": "@greatcondor8678", "text": "If I owned the docks, I would automate everything.", "like_count": 27, "published_at": "2024-10-02T03:42:50Z", "updated_at": "2024-10-02T03:42:50Z"}, {"author": "@thefngrinch", "text": "If forced to return to work they will work at minimum production,  The very definition of Union Labor.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-10-03T22:03:41Z", "updated_at": "2024-10-03T22:03:41Z"}, {"author": "@JinKee", "text": "This is how everyone loses their jobs to the OpenAI Figure series of robots currently working at the BMW plant", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-10-02T12:13:52Z", "updated_at": "2024-10-02T12:13:52Z"}, {"author": "@Ben_D.", "text": "So while the rest of us are living our best lives on UBI, spending time with the kids and what not, these guys get up in the morning and man the cranes on the docks.

title: Is the EU Losing Out on AI?
top_comments:
[{"author": "@niklase5901", "text": "I live in the EU country Sweden, and I am fed up with this! Eu seems to spew out confusing regulations that really are to our detriment.", "like_count": 11, "published_at": "2024-09-26T17:54:39Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-27T08:47:29Z"}, {"author": "@Ben_D.", "text": "Denmark here. You are preaching to the choir brother.", "like_count": 10, "published_at": "2024-09-26T18:26:13Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-26T18:26:13Z"}, {"author": "@appletree6741", "text": "European here. EU is producing some of the best EU talent and academic research , but it’s record in growing tech giants is dismal. I hope the concrete heads in Brussels wake up before we’re too much behind in the AI race.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-09-29T10:28:32Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-29T10:28:32Z"}, {"author": "@JosephSilv4", "text": "Old MacDonald had a farm, EU AI :O", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2024-09-27T01:42:11Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-27T01:42:11Z"}, {"author": "@evreninanc", "text": "What I don't understand is why can't we, users, constituents opt in or opt out? No one is asking us before making these policies, I don't need a nanny to decide on my behalf. Let me chose what data I share, what service I use. This is not only on AI related stuff, there are many medical researches which are not available in EU, again due to some policy makers' decisions. You know what DMCA gave humanity? Some popups we click without reading no matter which site we visit.", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2024-09-26T20:51:59Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-26T20:51:59Z"}, {"author": "@mmoreify", "text": "I'm based in the Netherlands, and while I agree that governance and safety are important, I feel the EU is taking these policies to an extreme. I'm not an expert in politics, but I really hope that lobbying is happening and that politicians start realising they might be doing more harm than good with these regulations.", "like_count": 11, "published_at": "2024-09-24T20:49:40Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-24T20:49:40Z"}, {"author": "@crypto-logisch", "text": "As a EU-Citizen: Where can I add my signature to that open letter?!", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-09-28T14:57:51Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-28T14:57:51Z"}, {"author": "@kvinkn588", "text": "Am from Germany and honestly... I hate not getting stuff all the time because of our regulations. For fucks sake just let me decide what products I want to use and what companies I do or do not feel comfortable giving my data too. Feels like we are being treated like children who are incapable of making our own choices", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-09-27T08:36:47Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-27T08:36:47Z"}, {"author": "@etunimenisukunimeni1302", "text": "I'm probably in the minority, even among my countrymen Finns, but I'm actually glad for some data collection regulation in EU. Including the infamous GDPR, with all its flaws. It's still better than nothing.  Any personally identifiable information, be it straightforward like a social security number etc. or more nuanced like data about your behaviour and habits, is more valuable than you think. It can and will be used in ways that invade and directly affects your life in all sorts of ways! Once the data is out there, you have no control over who uses it and how.

That said, it's sadly true that companies cannot predict what happens in a year or two, or how new legislation will change the game. At the very least, there needs to be predictability, but optimally AI regulation needs to be very, very carefully thought out. EU completely missed the mark with the AI act, mainly because they didn't care that the market had transformed completely in the years and years they worked on it. It was outdated before it was signed into a law. Agility and informed decisions are sorely missed.

title: Newsom Concerned About SB1047's "Chilling Effect"
top_comments: [{"author": "@scottmiller2591", "text": "Honestly, compute limits of any sort don't make sense - people will just train experts under the compute limits, then assemble into systems.  Each module will be done by different, say, open source, groups, and the assembly by still others using agentic structures as glue that require little or no training.  The only way to attempt to combat that is limits on the entire system, which then brings up a legal rat's nest of how far back to measure the limits in predecessor technology, and derivative and distilled forms, in the face of continually shifting technologies.  It's a fool's errand.\n\nNewsom is hoping his unconstitutional anti-free speech bill will hold together just long enough to influence the election - delay justice until it no longer matters. title: BREAKING: OpenAI Launches o1 - The Most Advanced Reasoning LLM Yet
top_comments: [{"author": "@anuzis", "text": "Appreciate the great coverage & speed getting this video out!", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-09-13T00:45:31Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-13T00:45:31Z"}, {"author": "@JOHN.Z999", "text": "We are far from achieving AGI, and I will only consider that we've reached this milestone when the new models demonstrate critical thinking, creativity to generate abstract and original concepts, consciousness, and the ability to consistently reflect on the future. Until these criteria are met, we will not have AGI. The improved \"reasoning\" of these new models is truly interesting and will undoubtedly be the new trend starting next year, with all the major tech companies adopting similar approaches. At least there's an advantage in this: more advanced reasoning will improve efficiency, increase reliability, and minimize the risk of hallucinations and errors in responses. This is, without a doubt, the greatest advantage, and I'm really liking it, as these models will be extremely useful as tools. 🍓", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-09-13T11:42:54Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-13T11:42:54Z"}, {"author": "@wildfotoz", "text": "This seems like the GPT-2 or GPT-3 moment of this new architecture. title: Is AI Going to Eat SaaS?

[{"author": "@GeorgeWing-AI", "text": "The barriers to creating software are falling dramatically", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2024-09-12T07:23:30Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-12T07:23:30Z"}, {"author": "@AggressiveUninterest", "text": "Without watching: Yes.
After watching: Yes.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2024-09-12T12:43:38Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-12T12:43:38Z"}, {"author": "@GNARGNARHEAD", "text": "best AI news on the net.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-09-12T15:05:16Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-12T15:05:16Z"}, {"author": "@TechnoMageCreator", "text": "You remember those videos from 90' with CIA looking at a bairly readeable license plate and they enhance a corner of that license plate to get the face figure of the villain in the reflection from 20ft away? As someone that has never built software and working by myself to an enterprise level field management software, after two years of work with all the AI tools my last week of work has been: enhance, enhance, enhance lol. Yeah it's here.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-09-17T20:59:23Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-17T20:59:23Z"}, {"author": "@wildfotoz", "text": "I don't see AI at the stage where it will replace applications yet. Maybe they're that good but I doubt it. I recently worked at a Fortune 100 company doing BI consulting and I was always shocked at the number of clients we had that didn't even have business intelligence at 1990 levels. When it comes to sales pipeline, you need to know where that sale is in the pipeline. For instance, is it 10, 25, 50, 75, 90% complete. If it's 75%, how long has it been sitting at 75%? Something that has been at that level for 12 months isn't weighted the same as something that just moved there. Are they using AI to capture all this data into a database so it can be reported on? I doubt it. I don't think they're running the company that well and only time will tell if they truly know what they're doing or if this is just a stunt like you pointed out.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-09-12T15:44:16Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-12T15:44:16Z"}, {"author": "@christopherd.winnan8701", "text": "Any SAAS company who does not adopt AI can kiss their business goodbye.", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2024-09-12T03:01:59Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-12T03:01:59Z"}, {"author": "@airdogg1979", "text": "Ai will eat everything", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-09-12T20:30:32Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-12T20:30:32Z"}, {"author": "@KevinKreger", "text": "Pity the software maintainers", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-09-15T19:34:48Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-15T19:34:48Z"}, {"author": "@sikunowlol", "text": "how is this a question? 100% yes", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-09-12T09:41:25Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-12T09:41:25Z"}, {"author": "@nathanshaw4189", "text": "Inspired by this episode, I created a short video aimed at Broadcom, who seems to be sticking it to enterprise customers who they know can't easily shift away from their integrations. title: What Wall Street Thinks of AI Heading Into Autumn
top_comments: [{"author": "@BeInnovativeToday", "text": "Being in NYC I have friends who work on Wall Street they know close to nothing about AI just it is popular!", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-09-12T13:10:23Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-12T13:10:23Z"}, {"author": "@Syn_Slater", "text": "Wall Street doesn't say anything. There are investors, then swing traders, then day traders ect...There is like 10 different games being played in the market, and depending on who you talk to, you'll get different answers. Investors love AI because they are looking at the next 20 years. Swing traders talk about a bubble, because the second prices dip, they're going to sell. Day traders opinion changes every hour ect... there is a bubble, because when the day traders and swing trades pull out and move on to the next glittering rising stock, the prices will drop. The investors will stay invested because they know in 20 years their stock will be 20x and will probably buy more during the dip. title: Are AI Models Becoming Commoditized?
top_comments: [{"author": "@CrispinCourtenay", "text": "They became commoditized around the time GPT 4 was released, and you could easily jump from one model to the next. Today with the various dev frameworks that exist, it is simple to create an agentic workflow that draws on multiple LLMs and then ranks results depending on the best answers given.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-08-26T00:09:48Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-26T00:09:48Z"}, {"author": "@Jayc5001", "text": "The problem with models are that their outputs can be used to train a model of a similar level. So by paying to use a model you are slowly giving away the sause that makes your model great and unique.\n\nBut that works both ways. If you have a generaly great model but somone else has a model that is better in a specific domain can pay and yoink data to improve your model. So this force tends to even out models over time in the market. After all big companys have the money to pay each other to aquire data.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-08-25T16:57:52Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-25T16:57:52Z"}, {"author": "@bgtyhnmju7", "text": "Good morning !!", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-08-25T16:32:57Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-25T16:32:57Z"}, {"author": "@senju2024", "text": "You always say...\"stay tune to the main Episode..\" Yet...I do not see any links to it. title: AI to Kill Coding? Amazon Cloud Head Thinks So
top_comments: [{"author": "@Robert...Schrey", "text": "It won't replace coding, it'll replace code.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-08-22T21:17:37Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-22T21:17:37Z"}, {"author": "@wildfotoz", "text": "I don't know if 2 years is going to be enough time to replace developers. If you're talking single scripts, sure, I can see that in some instances. Take SQL for instance, I've asked ChatGPT a few times to generate some scripts because I'm lazy and it gets a D at best with a F the vast majority of the time. Most development uses some sort of back end to store data and LLMs suck in that area right now. How about creating a C# solution and all the components, I don't think so. I don't think it can even do that right now. And finally, the LLMs will need to be run locally because there's a ton of developers in the world and there's no way they can afford to run all of that through cloud services. There would have to be some huge advances in that 24 months for that to happen. title: The Next Phase of Generative AI Adoption
top_comments:
[{"author": "@senju2024", "text": "If the company policy is to not use AI, this forces users to be "CLOSET AI users". As you mentioned BYO-AI is being done but in secret. I have a bad feeling this done a lot. Many traditional companies think gen-AI is a bad thing due to incorrect info and threat to security. But actually it is doing the opposite. The Closet AI users will be more of a security threat as proper ai filters will not apply to such a closed system.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2024-08-21T10:20:35Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-21T10:20:35Z"}, {"author": "@michaelcushman", "text": "Very useful surveys, and benefits are accruing to companies.
1. Less time on repetitive tasks frees up brains to work on higher value work.

2. Higher quality writing and presentations improve customer relations, sales, maketing and internal communications.

3. Brainstorming is faster and easier leading to more innovation.

4. Stop draining power users' time. In every company, informally power users spend time fixing other employees pivot tables, OS settings, access problems, formating and styling issues in docs and presentations,  etc. None of this is measured, but it is a significant burden. It is an invisible tech and app support system. Gen AI can help people help themselves! 

I have measured this 4th issue for clients and it is shocking how big of a productivity drain this is for the power user, and a necessary system to keep work moving for everyone else.

I have been asking Gen AI users if they use it instead of bugging power users, and so far, they love it. They can figure out these ad hoc issues on their own!

All the above acrue value to the company. They are not measured, never have been. But it is real.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2024-08-21T01:04:57Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-21T01:04:57Z"}, {"author": "@Ben_D.", "text": "I think it actually has some unseen benefits that the hype and furore is dying down. It means people are becoming used to the idea of having AI in the loop. It is becoming expected and integrated.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-08-21T10:20:30Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-21T10:20:30Z"}]

title: The Controversy Surrounding Elon Musk's New Image Generation AI
top_comments:
[{"author": "@PakStarMaxLeung", "text": "just put watermarks on all AI generated images and videos .... so viewers know it is not real ...", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-09-11T00:11:39Z", "updated_at": "2024-09-11T00:11:39Z"}, {"author": "@pc2393", "text": "The only controversy is whether people have gotten so weak that they cant have funny images anymore", "like_count": 15, "published_at": "2024-08-16T03:07:51Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-16T03:07:51Z"}, {"author": "@clintfaber", "text": "I think all of those images are hilarious and there should be more", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2024-08-16T06:09:04Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-16T06:09:04Z"}, {"author": "@____2080_____", "text": "Unlike most of the mainstream world, Elon Musk is but a dimes difference from anyone else in big tech.

All of these models do the same thing and he’s the only one that doesn’t pretend 

Yes, he’s bat shit crazy. But he’s more of a contrarian than anything else.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2024-08-16T11:16:28Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-16T11:16:28Z"}, {"author": "@andersw69", "text": "The issue with allowing uncensored image generation is not funny memes. There are actual consequences to fake images and it should definitely be illegal. Evil people are easily deterred from doing bad things because it's difficult. This is a huge step backward.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-08-17T02:58:27Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-17T02:58:27Z"}, {"author": "@JustAThought01", "text": "The point to keep in mind is that all informational material is generated by humans. If the material is doing harm we need to be able to identify the person causing the harm and hold them accountable. Government should not allow anonymous posting by law.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-08-16T13:57:11Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-16T13:57:11Z"}, {"author": "@TheFeedRocket", "text": "It's not against copyright to draw a picture or even exact copy of your favorite character, TV or movie actor/actress as long as you are doing it for your own use, I can't get over when people say it's copyright infringement, it's really not.  Of course unless you're profiting from it or preventing the owner from profiting, or defaming, it's just fair use, also protected free speech. It's got a name "Fan Art" I can make pictures of Star Wars characters or whatever, I can't put them on a Hat, or T-Shirt, I can't do a comic book and sell it or even give it away for free, it's for my use.  Seems to me posting it is still under fair use unless you profit from the site or page. Honestly plenty of these companies will love you drawing Nike shoes, or images of characters and posting it, it's the shocking and out of character images that could become a problem, they could go after the poster of those images as damaging their brand, in fact I can't see why these companies couldn't target a few of these people who post damaging images, all you need is one case against an individual, and those shocking out of character images stop.

Real life people are slightly more apt to be upset by the use of their likeness in any fashion, but mostly the misuse. Are you defaming the character? are you hurting the copyright holders ability to market the character? then it could be an issue, but I would take the approach that all publicity is good, and the shocking stuff people will become bored with or it just becomes a waste of time.  Copyright holders might be best to let it go and use a wait and see approach. If they really stop people from making any normal fun images of characters they love, it will backfire on them, with AI, I will just make new characters myself and the heck with those companies characters. I think they would be hurt if they do that, so I think you will always be able to make Batman, Spiderman, Pokemon...etc, it keeps the character popularity way up, heck if I'm Warner Brothers I want Batman and Bugs Bunny being plastered all over social media. (of course not smoking weed or drinking, although....)

In Star Wars it was known the fan art community went to the extreme, with fans even making fan movies, again not to profit but it was vital to the success. People worried about Disney cracking down after they acquired it, but I don't think they did, and it's still important., So way before AI, fan art was a thing it's fine as long as you don't sell it, although plenty of artist do just that at conventions and companies allow that too, it's a one off and it promotes the brand or character.  

So, it's not always copyright infringement, it's just the poor taste ones or offensive ones could be seen as hurting the brand and in turn could hurt the whole fan art fair use.  I think it will just blow over, people will be bored with the shock value, so I would certainly use a wait and see approach, a heavy handed approach will only hurt the brands more.", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2024-08-16T09:18:02Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-16T09:18:02Z"}, {"author": "@jacksonroks", "text": ""Sexualized images of women in bikinis"...Do you mean, images of women in bikinis? Ffs", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-08-16T13:04:15Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-16T13:04:15Z"}, {"author": "@joechip4822", "text": "Funny, that Grok-2 obviously is much less censored than other publicly available AI art generators (like DALL-E, Midjourney etc.), but is not open to generate complete nudity of all things. I guess this permanent struggle with 'nudity being something bad that needs to be regulated and prohibited', compared to violence and gore, which is even accepted as high art in movies and comics etc. - has much to say about the state of our modern world in general - and the US in particular. 
I remember it well that in the 80s, violence and sex were treated almost equally - a Bruce Lee movie in cinema had the same rating as a movie which featured full frontal nudity. But this has changed drastically in the following decades. And now something like 'John Wick' movies where hundreds are killed has become 'art', whereas nudity is treated as prudish and hypocritical as ever.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-08-17T06:14:57Z", "updated_at": "2024-08-17T06:14:57Z"}, {"author": "@scottmiller2591", "text": "Oh no, my pencil's gone rogue and drawn something naughty! Maybe it’s an Internet-scale economic impact in the long run; maybe.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2024-07-13T14:34:45Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-13T14:34:45Z"}, {"author": "@capitalistdingo", "text": "A big part of the problem isn’t just the hype coming from the AI industry but the effectiveness of that hype. They see a humanoid robot being controlled via an LLM and “explaining” it’s actions and suddenly they think “hey, they understand human language and can follow any instruction so they are pretty much human level right now.” If you disagree with that they think you are just not as well informed about AI and robots as they are.  My take?: I phone/Android will offer various personal specialized AI assistant apps is what will take the diffusion of innovation curve parabolic imo, whereas the corporate adoption will stagnate due to most industries’ mal incentive structures (monopoly capitalism as an employment/profit protection racket), especially in the private markets.

title: Why the Federal Reserve is Paying Attention to Generative AI
top_comments:
[{"author": "@mariusz0kreft", "text": "And here is the problem. If just look at news about base technology, there might be less news perceived. But further down the food chain, the guys who are building based on the base tech, are flooding my news feed at least", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-07-10T20:44:08Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-10T20:44:08Z"}, {"author": "@capitalistdingo", "text": "“Mandate for full employment” which is defined as, what… 5% of those actively looking for work not having it? Anything lower than 5% is considered hyper-inflationary and needs to be quashed, right? And if lots of people are under employed or have given up looking because they lost hope and are living with family… makes it easier to massage the data into “full employment”. 

Government economists don’t believe in technological deflation (that acceleration in technology can increase productivity and reduce prices) so every time things start to go well for people and jobs get created they feel the need to stop the “irrational exuberance”by raising rates enough to force recessions. 

So forgive me if an economists’ views on AI don’t speak to me as important, relevant or accurate. 😂", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-07-09T16:40:39Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-09T16:41:15Z"}, {"author": "@NoidoDev", "text": "Move fast and break things is the way to go.
