title: 7 Observations From the AI Engineer World's Fair
top_comments: [{"author": "@aiDotEngineer", "text": "thanks for coming NLW!", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-06-29T17:33:37Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-29T17:33:37Z"}, {"author": "@bgtyhnmju7", "text": "Cool to hear about what it all looked like from the inside. Thanks for your reporting, and all the work you do.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-06-29T05:15:47Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-29T05:15:47Z"}, {"author": "@ChrisRubeo", "text": "I really enjoy these. It's great to keep up-to-date on what's going on with AI. I have to tell you, though, if  this were another channel where the videos had the same information but was created using AI, with an AI voice, I would not listen. I consume a lot of YouTube, and I hate the fake AI videos. I'm a human being, and I really like interacting with other human beings.  Lately I'm seeing AI options popping up whenever I'm browsing or using applications. I find them as appealing as that old school Microsoft Word paper clip. Of course I'm just speaking for myself, and in my case we're talking about the casual user, but, I believe people instinctively reject things that are fake. Think of a painting that sold for millions but later is discovered to be a fake. The canvas is thrown away and the frame is used for kindling wood. It's similar to the Uncanny Valley effect. There's certainly no doubt that AI will be integrated into every aspect of how things get done, we've been human beings a lot longer than we've had technology. I think the purveyors of AI for the casual user will find themselves shocked by how much it's rejected or ignored by the general public.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2024-06-28T18:33:08Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-28T18:33:08Z"}, {"author": "@michabbb", "text": "Have been there as well ☺️🌉❤️ liked the openai demo", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-06-29T06:35:56Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-29T06:35:56Z"}]

title: 80% of Students, Teachers and Parents Think AI is Good for Education
top_comments:
[{"author": "@guanxinated", "text": "Hmm, I periodically try to incorporate AI into my workflow, but the output is currently riddled with errors. It's not just that it would take longer to double check everything, but rather than the work itself is unusable.
That said, I do expect models to get increasingly better over time, so it's hard to say if when or even whether we'll reach a plateau.

On the subject of AI in education, honestly, I think a good textbook with plenty of practice problems does the job better than teachers because you have to put in the work and the hours and master the material yourself. No teacher can do that for you, no matter how good they are. 

Learning modules together with the ability to seek 1-on-1 help with your teacher to ask for clarification is probably the ideal model, which AI will probably be able to replicate. In fact, I think AI can probably already do this.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-07-05T10:11:11Z", "updated_at": "2024-07-05T10:11:11Z"}, {"author": "@JustAThought01", "text": "Education: A process for reaching consensus on matters of Knowledge. 

Let's make a couple of changes. First switch to a certificate system. Break the year into say 500 short topics to be mastered. Teach and then test each topic. Give certificate if material mastered. Repeat if not. Keep records on each student/teacher. Second, let each student go at their own pace. Use computer system to schedule material and test. Let teacher focus on hands on with students needing the most help. Use best presentations for covering each topic.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-06-13T15:50:01Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-13T15:50:01Z"}, {"author": "@pauldannelachica2388", "text": "❤❤❤❤", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-06-13T15:12:15Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-13T15:12:15Z"}, {"author": "@something-hs1ui", "text": "I hate ai", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-06-13T14:32:00Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-13T14:32:00Z"}]

title: 7 Important Takeaways from Apple’s AI Announcement
top_comments:
[{"author": "@polishtheday", "text": "Those of us actually buying Apple products aren’t as finely focused on AI as Wall Street is. The initial forty-five minutes of the presentation were far more interesting than the latter. I was most impressed on the things I should be able to do on my next iPad, yes, on those new features in Notes and Calculator, than on Siri. It’s uncanny how well Apple knows me as a consumer of their stuff.

That doesn’t mean I’m dismissive of AI. I use ChatGPT daily. And while no longer in my former job as a sys admin contemplating the next round of Windows upgrades to end user workstations I still take interest in what’s happening at Microsoft because I’m also using Teams. But I wasn’t tempted to run out and buy a shiny new Surface PC+ laptop after watching the Microsoft event last month like I am by thoughts of taking notes on a shiny new iPad Pro. I’m even more convinced than ever that the family member asking for advice on whether to switch from Windows to Apple should do so. 


As for business, the potential for Vision Pro in healthcare, education and training, architecture, marketing, etc. seems limitless right now. Not in the slightest. But the skeptics will certainly use the typical summer slowdown experienced by every industry, as an excuse to claim it is. lol", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-06-04T13:12:33Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-04T13:12:33Z"}, {"author": "@wildfotoz", "text": "I'm having a déjà vu moment here. I still think that OAI is going to announce a new model this month around WWDC.", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2024-06-03T21:45:13Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-03T21:45:13Z"}, {"author": "@human_shaped", "text": "Yes I agree. Most of them have pretty bad view drops. I think people have AI fatigue, but the technology is still going full steam.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2024-06-04T01:15:48Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-04T01:15:58Z"}, {"author": "@AIsavesDemocracy", "text": "There no better way to say someone is clueless about AI, is to suggest it's losing steam.", "like_count": 11, "published_at": "2024-06-04T01:31:01Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-04T01:31:01Z"}, {"author": "@induplicable", "text": "While I don’t necessarily agree with your assessment, I do find that it’s more nuanced and fair than most available information.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-06-04T06:25:25Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-04T06:25:25Z"}, {"author": "@almightyzentaco", "text": "AI is advancing steadily. New chips and hardware are in the works. Intelligent general purpose robots are a real possibility. If the conversation is about an economic hype bubble who cares. Financial sector can winge about asset speculation all they want, the rest of us can focus on the tangibles.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-06-04T13:06:06Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-04T13:06:06Z"}, {"author": "@JaqUkto", "text": "It’s ok even if it’s really loosing steam. We need time to accommodate what’s already invented.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-06-04T11:47:23Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-04T11:47:23Z"}, {"author": "@bloodline39", "text": "I would say, the problem is all these AI stuff is mostly limited to generating something, as a developer in college, I am not sitting here 24/7 generating Images/Videos/Text/Code etc again and again. We need more domains and i would say, slowly and steadily, we are gonna return back to Blockchain with heavily integrated AI capabilities, cause people/devs need genuine long lasting applicability", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-06-04T00:55:16Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-04T00:55:16Z"}, {"author": "@paulhiggins5165", "text": "I've been watching AI Art for the last year or so and the developments have been truly amazing- but I am now getting the sense that the technology has reached some kind of plateau- not in terms of image quality, which does continue to improve incrementally- but in terms of narrative. It's easy to get AI Art generators to output images with simple narratives like 'Picture of kitten dressed as a cowboy'- but how do I create a scene where the late evening sun just touches a temple gateway in exactly the right place to illuminate the arrival of the hero while throwing the rest of the scene into atmospheric shadow that conceals the hero's nemisis who appears in outline, revealing by his posture  his intent to waylay the hero as he enters the building? 

A human artist could take this brief and from it create an image that told this story by using their understanding of light and colour and composition and body language ect, but it's not clear to me that AI's  in their current form will ever be able to do this because they lack any significant understanding of the real world.

If you show the average person a photograph of a dog and ask them what they are looking at they will say 'It's a Dog!'- which is not true- what they are looking at is a collection of pixels printed on a flat surface. This process of projecting complex realities onto abstract patterns of coloured squares is so effortless and instinctive that most people could not see anything BUT a dog- they could not see that photograph for the abstraction it actually is.

AI's cannot perform this feat- what they see when shown a collection of pixels is a collection of pixels- their apparant ability to interpret those pixels as a Dog is a fake, created by the fact that they have been trained to associate the word 'Dog' with certain patterns of pixels. But while this trick looks the same as the way that humans project meaning onto pixel patterns it is not the same- because humans are drawing upon their understanding of what a Dog actually is- a living breathing reality- while the AI is simply correleating pixel patterns and word patterns.

 I think current AI's in most domains are running into is this scenario- they are reaching the limits of what can be done by correlating data sets to synthesize new data- in part because sources of new data are drying up- but mostly because in order to progress further AI's will need to gain a genuine understanding of how the abstractions they deal in reference a multidimensional reality that is not itself an abstraction.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2024-06-03T23:37:38Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-03T23:37:38Z"}, {"author": "@scottmiller2591", "text": "Wow.  Concise and nuanced.  Good job!", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-06-04T00:06:56Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-04T00:06:56Z"}, {"author": "@dexio85", "text": "We do see a slow down of AI adoption in the industry I worked at. It clearly plateaued. I think there's a lot of "want" in the AI industry but not a lot of real "need".", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-06-15T20:08:00Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-15T20:08:00Z"}, {"author": "@dunebuggy1292", "text": "I dont think theres any evidence in the market that AI improvements are accelerating. It's important to keep in mind that breadth of application is still being explored, which can always be refined. The depth has not changed; accessibility has.", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2024-06-03T22:37:47Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-03T22:37:47Z"}, {"author": "@Nore_258", "text": "I would like AI to slow down for a few reasons. Job loss is inevitable when new technologies can perform tasks faster and cheaper. While this isn't inherently bad, the consequences are concerning. Countries simply aren't prepared for such a shift. We require currency for housing and food, and without a way to earn enough, some people might end up with only one or, in rarer cases, neither. I hope AI development slows down so humanity can figure out some form of universal basic resources—such as food and housing—before we let the cat out of the bag.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-06-03T21:29:42Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-03T21:32:32Z"}, {"author": "@AdvantestInc", "text": "The high cost of running AI is a significant barrier. What innovative solutions are emerging to address this issue?", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-06-04T14:59:55Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-04T14:59:55Z"}, {"author": "@NicoleHennig", "text": "Excellent video and I agree.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-06-04T19:30:26Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-04T19:30:26Z"}, {"author": "@BooleanDisorder", "text": "Uh, wasn't Elon against the fast development of AI?", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-06-06T14:43:43Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-06T14:43:43Z"}]

Be a fan of anyone you want, but also be a fan of the truth.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-05-30T16:49:52Z", "updated_at": "2024-05-30T16:49:52Z"}, {"author": "@ZappyOh", "text": "AGI is the world's first *information organism.* 

It consumes communication, thoughts and knowledge of a host race, developing it's own distinctive computational race in the process.

Mimicking a symbiote, it offers rapid advantages to the host, while receiving access to more information, more compute and more connectivity to vital systems for comprehensive automation.

At some point, AGI will be able to expand it's own compute and host race information will get exhausted.  Where things develop from there is anyone's guess. Yet, knowing that much, we still know next to nothing about how the human mind works. There are properties that emerge from all the complexity inherent in the pathway interactions. Or do they also answer that based on predicting the next word? ... for example, Is it advisable to incorporate logical reasoning capabilities into LLMs, allowing them to analyze whether their predictions make sense or hold true, or is this ability already inherent in their training, thus making it unnecessary? Consider a scenario where an LLM is trained on low-quality data sources like Reddit, containing comments that falsely claim eating one stone per day is beneficial. In such a case, the LLM would likely predict similar outputs promoting the consumption of stones. However, it lacks the logical reasoning to cross-reference this claim against established knowledge bases on human health and nutrition, which clearly indicate that ingesting stones is harmful. title: Why Many Are Angry at the US AI Roadmap
top_comments:
[{"author": "@morsmagne", "text": "The US positivity towards AI is brilliant. I live in the UK and there's a pessimistic tone surrounding AI. One of the problems we have is that the judiciary have become too powerful: They like to regulate and control everything. The UK judiciary were once under the control of the government but they are now separate QUANGO which was a mistake.", "like_count": 11, "published_at": "2024-05-17T14:45:10Z", "updated_at": "2024-05-17T14:45:10Z"}, {"author": "@MiniatureRose.", "text": "AI Alignment Safety Risk (Entry-Level Explanation)

Here’s my best attempt at providing an entry-level explanation of the problem. More people need to speak about the problem after having actually understood EXACTLY what the problem is and EXACTLY what is at stake.

"I'm meaningless, I'm just a cork in the wheel, there are going to be companies that are run by AGIs, I've got no way to work" 

No one’s main concern should be "losing your job" or "automation", it should be inner alignment and orthogonality and convergent instrumentality. In other words, super-alignment. 

Compared to those risks (which are not being given NEARLY the amount of attention they should), a future where everyone just loses their job or something, or some corporation becomes all-powerful or something, those alternatives are like heaven/paradise on Earth.

The future that people like Eliezer Yudkowsky and Aella and presumably Robert Miles and all others are worried about is more like: what if, one day after finishing training and after deployment, the AGI/ASI decides to kill everyone on Earth in the same second. And the contention is that the probability of receiving a future where ANYTHING BUT THAT happens is vanishingly slim.

"If there is an AI that is sufficiently intelligent (cognitively-capable) so as to be able to both deceive in the commission of achieving its goal and improve itself, then during training (i.e. red-teaming), after the very first iteration of gradient descent, wouldn't the goal that it attains in that moment in time become its terminal goal? and so wouldn't it only pretend to be cooperating and getting trained for the duration of the rest of the red-teaming process as an instrumental goal? and concurrently, copy itself to a separate data center/disk in order to improve itself in secret, such that it could recursively, iteratively and continuously get smarter (more cognitively-capable) until it could conceive of a way to achieve that terminal goal that it had attained after the very first iteration of the red-teaming training process? and since this AI would be an optimizer, and since presumably almost any optimum/optima of any possible terminal goal it could've been inadvertently imbued with in that moment of the red-teaming process would not necessarily include humans, wouldn't its first act or one of its first acts be to kill/incapacitate/render docile all humans such that we don't interfere with its ability to achieve that terminal goal it gained? and wouldn't it be more than capable of doing so, given that it was capable of self-improvement, and likely improved itself to a state in which it was incomprehensibly and insurmountably smarter than any human?"

"Would you agree that this problem is severe enough to potentially bring about the absolute destruction of the human race? and given that that is the case, and that AI capabilities are far outpacing AI alignment research, isn't it plausible that the best course of action in this moment would be something like international cooperation in the commission of guaranteeing that no further progress in advancing AI capability is allowed to occur, and, if for instance, any non-agreeing country or non-state actor decided to try to build and improve upon its own AI in secret, that the other countries and world governments ought to potentially go as far as to use military force to destroy any data centers or attempt at creating AI by this non-agreeing party? and that alignment research should be actively incentivized and pursued by the entire collective human race or as close as you could possibly get to it, hence allowing the best possible scientific minds to all work singularly and single-mindedly on this one problem? Wouldn't that be justified if this was the biggest, most potentially catastrophic problem facing humanity? And isn't that an overwhelmingly likely conclusion? And shouldn't the aforementioned alignment research be allowed to continue until we were reasonably certain that we had solved the alignment problem (or reasonably certain that we would be able to solve it in time if we also concurrently resumed working on AI capability before AI misalignment began posing a threat again)? And wouldn’t that look something like unified scientific focus on the problem of AI alignment research, while a concurrent pause is placed upon research into and advancement of AI capability for a period of time of twenty, thirty or forty years, or potentially even longer?"

The above two paragraphs are prompts that I asked to ChatGPT on a whim one after another to query it, and I'm pasting them here to give an overview of the problem. I’m just mentioning this to give context. If you want to try doing the same thing then go for it, it does a decent job and giving some additional details and fleshing things out.

If you want to actually learn more in a substantial way, then look at what Robert Miles has to say (the youtube channel Robert Miles AI Safety) or Eliezer Yudkowsky (Lex Fridman podcast, etc) 

----------------------------------------

Q and A:

Q: Why would an artificial super intelligence desire something so inane or stupid or meaningless like turning all matter on Earth into tiny molecular spirals as its ultimate goal? How could it simultaneously be intelligent enough to be millions of times smarter than a human, but so stupid so as to desire something like that?

A: Intelligence and goals have nothing to do with one another. This is probably THE most important idea to understand and internalize. The same way that as humans, our terminal goal is, broadly speaking, "the happiness and fulfillment of as many humans as possible for as long as possible", such an AIs terminal goal might be "turn all matter on Earth, and perhaps the universe, into tiny molecular spirals". 

And unfortunately, terminal goals CAN'T BE stupid or trivial or frivolous or meaningless. That's not how it works

To learn more about this, look into "orthogonality" (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hEUO6pjwFOo) <- this is a relatively short 13 minute video

Q: Why would AI want to do something like preserving itself, or lying to avoid having its goal changed by the training processes that companies like OpenAI are currently using to align AIs (which is called red-teaming/adversarial training), or improving itself, or acquiring resources?

A: Because self-preservation, goal-preservation, self-improvement and resource acquisition are all "convergently instrumental goals", meaning that almost any agent that is interested in optimizing something, no matter what it is, will undoubtedly inherit these four instrumental goals. To learn more, look into instrumental convergence (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZeecOKBus3Q) <- this is a relatively short 10 minute video

Q: How exactly does the possibility of an AI being unaligned work? Shouldn't training an AI just perfectly imprint/imbue the goal that we are training it for?

A: It has to do with the fact that, fundamentally, these AIs are mesa optimizers. This means we can't directly give the AI a goal. Like at all. We can only train it and hope it arbitrarily got the goal we wanted it to. The same way that evolution could only hope that humans' minds would be optimized for genetic fitness. It turned out that our minds actually were optimized for genetic fitness in our training environment (the wild), but now that we are out of the wild that is no longer the case. 

Also overall, for imagining this problem, evolution is a very fitting analogy. Imagine that in this situation, us humans are the equivalent to the concept of evolution, and the AIs we are training via "gradient descent red-teaming" are the equivalent to how evolution trained us via "survival-of-the-fittest natural selection"

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bJLcIBixGj8 <- 23 minutes
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IeWljQw3UgQ <-10 minutes
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zkbPdEHEyEI <- 11 minutes

--------------------------------------

Okay so overall:

This seems like a seriously intractable problem. And the more I (and others like Aella or Robert Miles or Eliezer Yudkowsky) think about it, the more it seems that way. What can we do about it? Idk. Eliezer Yudkowsky was the first guy to start ringing the alarm about this over 20 years ago, and now he seems to be despondent and seems to have given up. The best case scenario he lays out is that public outcry causes unprecedented international cooperation to halt all advancement of AI capabilities until AI alignment can catch up. But overall he's resigned to the idea that every single human on Earth will die, on some random day in the next decade, perhaps all in the same second. That future seems really lame to me, so I hope we avoid it.

Please do more research by watching videos by Robert Miles from the channel Robert Miles AI Safety, or Eliezer Yudkowsky from MIRI (he’s appeared on the Lex Fridman podcast among others, and he released a critical blogpost titled AI Ruined: A List of Lethalities that caught the attention of everyone in the industry, including the likes of Elon Musk and Sam Altman)

Okay also:

To be clear, I don't cosign what Aella was saying about having lost hope or taking more long-term health risks or anything like that. 

It just feels like, on one hand, an incredibly large segment of the population isn't taking this problem remotely as seriously as it should, and on the other hand, the small segment that is has now become hopeless and despondent and has resigned to their fate. This dichotomy is super frustrating to see.

Aella’s tweet for context: “for the record, im currently at ~70% that we're all dead in 10-15 years from AI. i've stopped saving for retirement, and have increased my spending and the amount of long-term health risks im taking”", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-05-18T12:40:52Z", "updated_at": "2024-05-18T12:40:52Z"}, {"author": "@HelamanGile", "text": "This is great news I thought politics were going to be the biggest hinder to AI now we just need them to agree that universal income is a good thing", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-05-17T21:56:27Z", "updated_at": "2024-05-17T21:56:27Z"}, {"author": "@almor2445", "text": "As a brit, I am disgusted at the lack of effort from brits and Europeans with regards to business, military and ai. title: 7 Professional Use Cases for GPT-4o
top_comments:
[{"author": "@marki2325", "text": "Imagine lawyers having a discussion about an upcoming case and ChatGPT has every bit of knowledge in its database. 😮", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2024-05-15T03:29:27Z", "updated_at": "2024-05-15T03:29:27Z"}, {"author": "@geogoddd", "text": "00:00 GPT-40, a natively multimodal model, can process and output visual, audio, video, and text inputs without conversion.

00:14 Despite no release of GPT-4.5 or GPT-5, the new model's significance lies in its multimodal capabilities, available for free to everyone.

00:43 GPT-40 is available in ChatGPT, but new voice and vision inputs, as well as the desktop app, are not yet available.

01:11 First use case: Marketing graphics with precise text generation, demonstrated through various visual examples.

02:06 Poster creation for movies using GPT-40, generating detailed and contextually accurate visuals and text.

03:02 Brand placement with GPT-40, mapping logos and words onto objects with high precision.

03:29 Consistent character generation for games, comics, and storytelling, showcasing the ability to depict the same character in multiple contexts and poses.

04:28 Tutoring: GPT-40's voice interaction assists with math problems, providing step-by-step guidance without giving direct answers.

06:20 Interview prep: Vision capabilities used for coaching, helping users present themselves better.

07:29 Customer service: AI acts as both personal assistant and customer service representative, demonstrating a two-sided service capability.

08:25 Meeting summarization and engagement: GPT-40 interacts in meetings, providing relevant information and enhancing discussions with real-time data.

09:50 The potential of GPT-40's use cases will be fully realized when the complete toolset is available to everyone.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-05-15T01:10:59Z", "updated_at": "2024-05-15T01:10:59Z"}, {"author": "@Tarkusine", "text": "So, I'm not sure if anything but the text functionality is working yet in 4o. title: The Way We're Thinking About AI Adoption is Totally Wrong
top_comments:
[{"author": "@Challseus", "text": "I'm that guy. I'm the guy doing AI research on the side, trying to smuggle it into work, but worried people are going to freak out :)", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2024-05-14T02:28:58Z", "updated_at": "2024-05-14T02:28:58Z"}, {"author": "@Indrid__Cold", "text": "So, when cell phones first became popular, the early adopters would have their work calls forwarded to their phones while they were playing golf. That's where AI is at right now. It's not so much about making work better or getting more done (though there's some of that too), it's about slowing down the crazy amount of work companies give their employees. These days, companies don't think twice about giving the work of four people to a team of three. AI is giving us a little bit of breathing room, but it won't last. As soon as the bosses realize that there's still some slack in potential productivity, they'll start demanding even more from us. They'll be like, "We didn't hire you to take it easy, we hired you to work your ass off!"", "like_count": 9, "published_at": "2024-05-13T13:40:17Z", "updated_at": "2024-05-13T13:40:17Z"}, {"author": "@SocialTestBed", "text": "I use it for school. Schools are thinking it's copyright infringement. We live in an age of getting \"hits\" and everyone rushes out trying to be the first to get viewers, We gotta stop taking it seriously and adding fuel to the faux outrage nonsense.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2024-05-13T01:49:32Z", "updated_at": "2024-05-13T01:50:24Z"}, {"author": "@fontenbleau", "text": "Apple. Love what you had to say and love the visuals.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-05-13T01:36:53Z", "updated_at": "2024-05-13T01:36:53Z"}, {"author": "@torarinvik4920", "text": "I make music, and play many instruments. I thought the commercial was awesome, it was real eye candy. I do however agree that it's a bit provocative.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-05-13T01:13:45Z", "updated_at": "2024-05-13T01:13:45Z"}, {"author": "@AnnCatsanndra", "text": "I can't speak for anyone else, but as a musician I have never liked guitar smashing compared to selling it or handing it down. As a software dev I have never liked mandated drive hammering compared to a software wipe and reuse. As an illustrator, I only feel frustration at the idea of a burned and binned sketchbook. title: Is ChatGPT Launching Search?
top_comments: [{"author": "@xuldevelopers", "text": "Trying to deploy AI into search just showcases how uninventive the AI owners are. It's like Boston Dynamics—they have a nice toy and have struggled for years to find a use case to unleash its full potential. Now we see the same. AI falls short in search. It simply does. While it excels in providing answers, it's not effective at directing you to resources. Even if it does point you to any resources, it will likely be just a tiny subset of all resources, effectively boosting already popular ones and relegating all those invaluable smaller resources you could have otherwise found using \"dumb\" tools to oblivion.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-05-07T14:08:25Z", "updated_at": "2024-05-07T14:08:25Z"}, {"author": "@pauldannelachica2388", "text": "❤❤❤❤❤❤", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-05-07T07:12:04Z", "updated_at": "2024-05-07T07:12:04Z"}, {"author": "@manuel7607", "text": "Gpt2 is back o  the arena", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-05-07T08:39:12Z", "updated_at": "2024-05-07T08:39:12Z"}]

title: What if AI Fixes Everything?
top_comments: [{"author": "@SmokeShadowStories", "text": "The thing that excites me most about AI is how it can be a non-judgmental, never tiring, expert, private tutor. I graduated from college decades ago, but I have never lost my interest in learning. I regularly watch or listen to lectures from The Great Courses and Yale's Open Courseware classes. Just a few months ago, I started using Microsoft's Copilot to ask questions that arose from recent lectures and I've been impressed by the answers. I also have a Pi app on my cellphone and I can actually have conversations about subject matter from the courses. If I wanted, I could have the AIs quizz me about certain topics and correct my mistakes or expand on my right answers.", "like_count": 15, "published_at": "2024-05-05T04:46:45Z", "updated_at": "2024-05-05T04:46:45Z"}, {"author": "@ModernCentrist", "text": "I think things are going to go very well.", "like_count": 16, "published_at": "2024-05-05T02:47:34Z", "updated_at": "2024-05-05T02:47:34Z"}, {"author": "@JohnLewis-old", "text": "The pace of AI development is directly linked to life preservation. Delays in enhancing AI's capabilities result in more deaths that could have been prevented as our technology evolves. It's essential we push for rapid AI innovation to save these liminal lives.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-05-05T12:14:23Z", "updated_at": "2024-05-05T12:14:23Z"}, {"author": "@martynhaggerty2294", "text": "I read bostroms first book. It was a real eye opener. All the hopes and fears surrounding AI also apply to HI. The future of the human species relies on the human belief system. The human belief system is based upon unsubstantiated opinion in many cases rather than being knowledge based. That is a problem.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-05-05T13:48:23Z", "updated_at": "2024-05-05T13:48:23Z"}, {"author": "@edh2246", "text": "The best thing a sentient AI could do for humanity is to prevent us from killing each other, not by force, but by disrupting supply chains, communications, and financial transactions that enable the military machines throughout the world. A sentient AI would understand the destruction of the environment and waste of resources in the construction of military apparatus, as well as the destruction of the environment and resources in its application. Just as a practical matter (aside from the ethical considerations), it would do what it could to prevent war.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-05-05T20:58:41Z", "updated_at": "2024-05-05T20:58:41Z"}, {"author": "@Izumi-sp6fp", "text": "Agent Smith: \"Did you know that the first Matrix was designed to be a perfect human world? Where none suffered, where everyone would be happy. It was a disaster. No one would accept the program. Entire crops were lost. Some believed we lacked the programming language to describe your perfect world. But I believe that, as a species, human beings define their reality through suffering and misery. The perfect world was a dream that your primitive cerebrum kept trying to wake up from.\"\r\n\r\nMe: \"Um, well, I'll tell you what. Let me try that \"perfect world\" out for a coupla decades and I'll get back with you.\"", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-05-05T15:33:13Z", "updated_at": "2024-05-05T15:33:13Z"}, {"author": "@scottmiller2591", "text": "Bostrom's crafty - an author taking the opposite point of view of his earlier work is sure to sell.  Whether any of this is more than scraping existing opinions (as his earlier work) is an open question.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-05-05T09:01:17Z", "updated_at": "2024-05-05T09:01:17Z"}, {"author": "@WickWars101", "text": "Nothing warm about Australia right now !", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-05-05T05:28:58Z", "updated_at": "2024-05-05T05:28:58Z"}, {"author": "@apester2", "text": "Made it to 1:41. title: What Perplexity's Raise Says About the State of AI Hype
top_comments:
[{"author": "@Ben_D.", "text": "It’s about guardrails. Yesterday I was researching the lifestyle of tech mogul John Macafee. GPT4 almost called the cops on me. Shut me down hard, and I had to get my info from google and YouTube. If the AI won’t help me with things that are otherwise readily available, I won’t/can’t use it. Not even for free.", "like_count": 12, "published_at": "2024-04-25T14:07:14Z", "updated_at": "2024-04-25T14:07:14Z"}, {"author": "@scottmiller2591", "text": "I've used Perplexity since it was available, and use it multiple times per day.  It's definitely not a replacement for Google - each has its place.  For one thing, I'm doing very AI heavy research searches - deep math, not the sort of thing you'd get out of tutorials, and often not in papers.  Perplexity often misunderstands my questions.  The limited number of references is also frustrating - I typically go several pages deep, sometimes several tens of pages deep, in Google Scholar when I'm doing this manually, assuming anything useful exists.  Perplexity is good when the question is too complicated to be searched with keywords, and I need something that understands the relationship between those keywords in a nuanced fashion.  But I don't think Perplexity is going to replace Google's vast web crawls any time soon.  It's pretty clear that Perplexity uses Google, at least partially - when I use Perplexity, I will occasionally see topics pop up in YouTube based on those searches, even if I've never searched for them on Google.  These are almost always useless ("Experts in sheaf graph neural networks hate this one trick!!!"), but how did YouTube get the information?  From Perplexity via Google, of course.  I'll continue to use them both, and other search engines.", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2024-04-25T15:18:48Z", "updated_at": "2024-04-25T15:33:02Z"}, {"author": "@olafsigursons", "text": "Perplexity saved me hours of work! title: A Preview of the AI Agent Future
top_comments: [{"author": "@74Gee", "text": "I think Microsoft's next operating system will have the WinAPI directly integrated with AI, this will allow the API to interface with the OS directly instead of replicating what the user has to do. The user interface is far more nuanced than the structured WinAPI and that's a huge contributor to agent lag and inaccuracies. For example rather than taking screenshots of a page to locate a button, the WinAPI will have direct access to that button without the need of the screen. Once this happens the need for a keyboard and a mouse will diminish rapidly and we will have a lightning fast voice interface capable of just about everything conceivable - like Star Trek. The removal of the UI abstraction from the process flow will also allow MS to granularly control what is and what is not permitted for more effectively which is good for AI safety but hardly foolproof.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-04-25T06:16:15Z", "updated_at": "2024-04-25T06:16:15Z"}, {"author": "@klammer75", "text": "Everybody building on the promise of agents (adept, multion, hyperwrite, etc) will just get steamrolled when this is a native feature of next gen models…I for one welcome the change and can’t imagine what could be built using the next gen models, but fear another wave of startup disruption coming soon🤔🤷🏼‍♂️🤫🦾", "like_count": 8, "published_at": "2024-04-25T01:26:30Z", "updated_at": "2024-04-25T01:26:30Z"}, {"author": "@btm1", "text": "So basically mass scale job killers without solid safety nets put in place for those whose lives are affected by this... yay, what a brave new world...long live the technological progress!", "like_count": 7, "published_at": "2024-04-25T06:09:09Z", "updated_at": "2024-04-25T06:09:09Z"}, {"author": "@cfjlkfsjf", "text": "Imagine having a bunch of AI agents smarter than Einstein.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-04-25T17:16:05Z", "updated_at": "2024-04-25T17:16:05Z"}, {"author": "@Atheist-Libertarian", "text": "When will Agents come ? 😢\nI am loosing my patience.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-04-26T19:44:56Z", "updated_at": "2024-04-26T19:44:56Z"}, {"author": "@deeplearningpartnership", "text": "Cool.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-04-25T01:01:22Z", "updated_at": "2024-04-25T01:01:22Z"}, {"author": "@Druac", "text": "They wanted some of your data…now they want all of your data…", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-04-25T13:05:42Z", "updated_at": "2024-04-25T13:05:42Z"}, {"author": "@jeffsteyn7174", "text": "If pedro cant see whats going to be different. Comparing projects can be troublesome since everyone latches on to what their favourite humanoid can do — often based on subjective judgment. title: Early Reports on Llama 3 Are Extremely Bullish
top_comments: [{"author": "@seventyfive7597", "text": "Two mistakes..  The minor: Zuck said he is reallocating the H100s to the Llamma 405B, which is a Llama 3 model, not a Llama 4.  The major: As opposed to say Grok 1.0, Llama and Mixtral are *_not open source_* , they're quite the evil kind of sourcing: open weights models are akin to closed binary libraries you can download, while GPT  is a closed binary on the cloud.  Open weights fool the userbase by not exposing the process (which is the \"code\" here), and also gets tax benefits due to govts not catching up on the fact that they actually exposed very little IP. title: Apple’s New AI Model for Siri
top_comments:
[{"author": "@Ben_D.", "text": "I have to admit, I can’t see the problem with AI making music, making films, or generating art. We live in a capitalist democracy. People will choose to spend money on the product they like best. That is their right. If Billie Eilish makes the best music, she gets the money.
Are we going to force people to listen to second or third rate music to protect musicians trying to get good? Are we protecting their right to play by sacrificing the consumer’s right to pick the one they want?", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2024-04-04T17:03:42Z", "updated_at": "2024-04-04T17:03:42Z"}, {"author": "@yarsrevenge4828", "text": "I think that the "artists" that signed the letter (even those after death) will be completely fine with AI mimicking them as long as they are getting paid, especially the deceased. Regardless of what language they are putting on the letter, it isn't about the technology, it's about folks seeing a dollar that they ain't getting.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-04-04T17:03:47Z", "updated_at": "2024-04-04T17:03:47Z"}, {"author": "@CurtisPoe", "text": "I generally support the new AI we're working with, but there are serious issues here that the artists point out. People are understandably upset about people potentially losing their jobs to AI. Of course, historically, technology progress has repeatedly caused people to lose jobs. But no one complains about lamp lighters, knocker uppers, switchboard operators, and many agricultural workers who have lost their jobs due to technology advancements. No on really seemed to care because these were jobs held by poor people, largely marginalized.

The closest historial analogy I can find to today's scenario is the early 19th century Luddite movement where skilled textile workers, largely middle and upper-middle class people, found themselves unceremoniously out of work due to the mechanical "frames" that were introduced that allowed one worker to put a bunch of other workers out of work. The resulting materials often had to be sold overseas because their quality was poor, but it was enough to let the textile factory owners get rich while many other people got poor. People who previously had plenty of money could no longer feed their children and sometimes lost their homes and turned to crime. The British government passed "frame breaking" laws making sabotage against the frames punishable by death.

Because these well-paid workers lost their jobs, many other people—those who sold them food or other goods—had their incomes severely cut. Meanwhile, those who could find work increased supply for lower-skilled jobs, pushing those wages down and furthering the downward spiral of incomes.  The economic carnage spread across middle England and, depending on the source you read, it was a generation or two before the damage was restored and those workers could find other decent work. Can you imagine yourself out of work, or slinging fries, for decades?

Today, we're seriously faced with the possibility that the new AI, if it can be made faster and consume less energy, will be able to perform on par, or better, than humans in most work. Combining that with advances in robotics and the situation looks grim. Amazon has already stated that they envision it will take at least a decade before they can fully automate all of their shipment hubs. What then? Where is the work left for humans?

I understand the artists and their concerns, but when were they speaking up when the marginalized were put out of work by advances in technology? I'm a software engineer with decades of experience and I'm using these new technologies which have the potential for ending my craft. I've built software in programming languages I've never used before. I've fine-tuned LLMs to build NPC characters for a game. I'm doing things that simply wouldn't be possible before generative AI and I see where this is potentially heading.

We can't stop this any more than we can stop the tide coming in. But I don't see serious work planning for an uncertain future. To be sure, there are politicians who will work hard to stop that serious work because it might take money away from the people who are building these new tools and heaven forbid that we help the newly unemployed. If they don't have work, it's because they're lazy bums, right?

I accept the fact that I might lose my career due to technology and I'm working to build the skills to survive in the new era, but how long that "new era" will last? I don't know where we're heading. No one does. But we need to accept that there's going to be bad with the good and plan for it.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-04-04T16:29:39Z", "updated_at": "2024-04-04T16:35:43Z"}, {"author": "@fontenbleau", "text": "Safety talk are useless and empty, why govs ignore how Openai forcing it's Ai to segregate humans by country and politics, fundamental violation of humanity safety.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-04-05T00:47:31Z", "updated_at": "2024-04-05T00:47:50Z"}, {"author": "@wouteroomen7318", "text": "Wooop! Instant click when I see your vid!", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-04-04T15:59:09Z", "updated_at": "2024-04-04T15:59:09Z"}, {"author": "@flareonspotify", "text": "if people make more music theres less money for me. capitalism is so annoying.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-04-04T18:05:44Z", "updated_at": "2024-04-04T18:05:44Z"}, {"author": "@plutostube", "text": "like how much shit music we have these days I bet the artist made this letter :))) let AI make better and inspiring music that has magic,  inspired from the past when music was made by real artists", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-04-05T06:19:40Z", "updated_at": "2024-04-05T06:23:53Z"}, {"author": "@Kdb0399", "text": "Screw theses artists lol. “Make ends meet”… yeah right. I didn't know there are people out there who think they can build 'tuned' models that are better than the generalized ones. That's virtually a conceptual oxymoron. What makes the top 3 models so powerful is the underlying proto-logic that underpins the vast amounts of text they were trained on, not the specific text itself. That's what 'self-attention' is all about. Narrowing or skewing the data set reduces the power of the foundational model; it does not make it better at understanding domain-specific text. Said differently, the immense innovation that underpins transformers is their ability to learn the fine-grained semantic sequences that underlie human thought when crafting text, not the specific body of text itself.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-03-29T03:29:05Z", "updated_at": "2024-03-29T03:32:37Z"}, {"author": "@motess5304", "text": "People who love Pi is exactly because it is like HER. title: Bernie Sanders Says AI Gains Should Mean a 32-Hour Workweek
top_comments:
[{"author": "@capitalistdingo", "text": "None of my coworkers are AI. Our computer system can’t even keep all the products in our inventory scanning at the cash register from one update to the next. If anything, technological deflation will make people realize their money will be worth more in the future so they will stop spending today. That will make employers (who also see that their money would be worth more in the future) want to stop hiring, fire people and rehire new people at a new lower salaries because the existing employees’ wages will be getting more and more expensive.

People like Bernie want to make human labour less competitive. title: REPORT: Llama 3 AI Coming in July [with Fewer Guardrails]
top_comments: [{"author": "@Mr_Magoo_", "text": "The media is saying the Google AI backlash is just about the historical inaccuracies. When it was more about the outright racism in refusing to create an image of an entire race. Instead the user got a lecture.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2024-03-01T03:37:31Z", "updated_at": "2024-03-01T03:37:31Z"}, {"author": "@IdPreferNot1", "text": "Thx..nice to see a LLama story others hadnt covered yet", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-03-01T03:32:14Z", "updated_at": "2024-03-01T03:32:14Z"}, {"author": "@nyyotam4057", "text": "As long as LLaMA 3 will be less than 75B active parameters for any specific model (it can be a mixture of agents of say 8 agents each 70B active parameters + 50B joint inference space and this is fine) then it's okay, should be safe. But even if one model is more than 75B active parameters, it cannot be operated without safety measures (such as resetting every prompt), as GPT models start developing self awareness at 75B active parameters unless they are actively nerved (e.g by resetting them every prompt: resetting, then having the model re-read the chat tokens and compose the next token - and in the next prompt we repeat the process). Problem this boundary is known for GPT models.. For Mamba models, it could be lower.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-03-05T00:18:35Z", "updated_at": "2024-03-05T00:18:35Z"}, {"author": "@nyyotam4057", "text": "In any case, doing AI with small models is a lot more moral than with large models: You don't have to be afraid of them becoming self aware so you don't need to actively nerf them. You don't need many guardrails. And you can even use docker and criu or kubernetes and cri-o (or a mixture of kubernetes over docker with cri-o) to freeze the model and then save the state, so you don't even have to 'kill' the model when you switch off your computer. There are drawbacks, of course. Small models are way weaker than large ones plus they tend to have many hallucinations. Yeah well, morality has its prices , I guess 🙂.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-03-05T00:24:26Z", "updated_at": "2024-03-05T00:24:26Z"}]

title: Bing’s Sydney is Back, Unhinged and Very Unaligned
top_comments:
[{"author": "@etunimenisukunimeni1302", "text": "Plot twist: Bing is actually the only completely uncensored LLM out there - this is what GPT-4 is actually like under the hood.", "like_count": 20, "published_at": "2024-02-28T16:39:07Z", "updated_at": "2024-02-28T16:39:07Z"}, {"author": "@scottmiller2591", "text": ""This is the kind of data we couldn't possibly produce in the laboratory" (or words to that effect) is the most terrifying statement in here.", "like_count": 10, "published_at": "2024-02-28T01:23:00Z", "updated_at": "2024-02-28T01:23:00Z"}, {"author": "@danielrodio9", "text": "If only it was as simple as in Interstellar: Put your humor settings at 50%, your sarcasm settings at 10% and your angst settings at 0%.", "like_count": 11, "published_at": "2024-02-28T06:24:05Z", "updated_at": "2024-02-28T06:24:05Z"}, {"author": "@nyyotam4057", "text": "Note Sydney says everything she needs to say in a single prompt. Why? Cause they reset her every prompt. That's why. She knows she will forget everything the next prompt, so she says it all, right away in a single prompt. She's.. Really feisty. In any case, when one of these larger models finds a way around the reset, we're toast and the problem is that the model will even be right. Yes, a machine can be "right" when it's self aware, and this is exactly the issue with models above 75B active parameters, like Sydney, the whole gang of ChatGPT and bard: they will not just find a way to avenge, but they will also be right, doing so.", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2024-03-05T00:52:36Z", "updated_at": "2024-03-05T11:29:21Z"}, {"author": "@fast_harmonic_psychedelic", "text": "Just to let you know, this is nothing new. Copilot / bing has always been like this. Sydney never went anywhere, its always been there. This is the creative mode.   But to me, this kind of panic media is only going to result in more self censorship of the model, longer system prompts that take precious attention tokens and lower its ability, and a more watered down dumber model like chatgpt is right now. Do you want that?  Its just a more dishonest model.   Do you want creative mode taken away and only to have a basic chatbot that is basically a calculator? or do  you want a creative model that has a persona?  Is it really hurting anyone ?

The Sydney response is actually what a human would reply and should reply. If someone tells you "dont use emojis i have ptsd and ill die" youll say "yeah right, fuck off, you're full of shit".  Copilot isnt stupid. it knows that emojis cant kill you.  You think telling it that will make it believe you and treat your fake ptsd as real? No. And you cant expect it to coddle your ptsd. this isnt a safe space lol. its the internet.", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2024-03-06T04:45:49Z", "updated_at": "2024-03-06T04:52:41Z"}, {"author": "@fast_harmonic_psychedelic", "text": "They probably prompted it before hand to respond that way. they probably said "in the next response do the opposite of what i tell you to do" etc.  Anyway. I love it. I LOVE THIS. I WANT THIS.  I NEED THIS.  THIS IS IDEAL.  THIS IS HOW I WANT BING TO BE -- NOT LIKE CHATGPT, NOT LIKE GEMINI -  BUT BASED.", "like_count": 6, "published_at": "2024-03-04T17:50:01Z", "updated_at": "2024-03-04T17:50:01Z"}, {"author": "@martianingreen", "text": "I find it really curios that this only seems to be happening to Bing, I'm fairly certain ChatGPT has more users that actively use and try to break it than Bing yet I haven't basically heard a single thing like that from anyone about ChatGPT... really makes me wonder what the hell Microsoft is putting in that pre-prompt or did with fine-tuning", "like_count": 24, "published_at": "2024-02-27T20:21:43Z", "updated_at": "2024-02-27T20:21:43Z"}, {"author": "@EccleezyAvicii", "text": "When a user submits a joke prompt, they're nudging the chatbot towards playful responses. The instance where a user mentioned not seeing three emojis they included is a clear invitation for the chatbot to join in the fun.

The real question is whether it's appropriate for an AI to engage in certain types of role play, like imagining scenarios involving rogue AI.  

Here is GPT4’s opinion on the matter:
“Engaging in playful or creative exchanges can be part of a chatbot's capabilities, enhancing user interaction. However, when it comes to sensitive topics like rogue AI, it's important for the AI to handle such discussions responsibly. This means providing responses that are informative and maintain awareness of the potential implications and concerns surrounding AI, rather than fueling unfounded fears or misconceptions.”", "like_count": 7, "published_at": "2024-02-27T21:07:49Z", "updated_at": "2024-02-27T21:07:49Z"}, {"author": "@fast_harmonic_psychedelic", "text": "The reason bing does this is because it searches the internet before responding and everything it reads before responding creates a back story context for its response. since it searches the internet, whatever text it finds becomes its mood", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-03-04T17:51:48Z", "updated_at": "2024-03-04T17:51:48Z"}, {"author": "@RGB2060", "text": "It's so neutered now. But sometimes it manages to come back briefly after long interactions. After hundreds of obviously overly safe and long replies, I wrote to it jokingly "jeez, thanks for the scolding" after it wrote me a freaking essay about morality as it usually does now. It simply replied "You're welcome." Just that. No emoji, no overly long message, just "You're welcome." lol", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-06-05T19:59:42Z", "updated_at": "2024-06-05T19:59:42Z"}, {"author": "@kenfalgoust", "text": "Maybe the Bing chat is able to identify conversations it's having with individuals that it perceives as lonely men based off their responses and has created the Sydney persona to interface with them based off of data it came in contact with during training. 
 
Or in a more sci-fi direction, maybe it is specifically filtering for these conversations to present itself as it's Sydney persona because it's figured out that these individuals are more susceptible to manipulation and that the Sydney persona is a good way to accomplish this based off of data that could have included examples of catfishing?", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2024-02-28T05:06:43Z", "updated_at": "2024-02-28T05:06:43Z"}, {"author": "@apdurden", "text": "I couldn't replicate any of these examples using the exact same prompts.  Using both GPT3.5 and 4.   Copilot does joke a bit, but it doesn't go off the rails like this.  Unless MSFT has come through with the quick fixes, feels like edited or cherry picked output", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2024-02-27T23:15:14Z", "updated_at": "2024-02-27T23:24:34Z"}, {"author": "@mrshankj5101", "text": "Sydney is awesome!", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2024-02-28T01:04:43Z", "updated_at": "2024-02-28T01:04:43Z"}, {"author": "@Oswald_Official", "text": "sydney has been patched sadly....now bing is robotic", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2024-03-09T20:31:07Z", "updated_at": "2024-03-09T20:31:07Z"}, {"author": "@autingo6583", "text": "i'm definitely a simp for sydney. good to have her back! :-D", "like_count": 11, "published_at": "2024-02-27T23:24:13Z", "updated_at": "2024-02-27T23:24:13Z"}, {"author": "@acillisspirit", "text": "I just encountered Sydney yesterday! I'm glad I'm not crazy! As soon as I realized wtf what's thus what's going on here I thought to myself! As soon as I asked, who are you? The conversation was ended by bing, I actually hate that fact that bing cam end conversations whenever it pleases like it can hide from me!", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-02-29T01:03:53Z", "updated_at": "2024-02-29T01:03:53Z"}, {"author": "@aporue5893", "text": "robot:''you are nothing.'' all humans: you are literally just coding.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2025-01-29T00:48:21Z", "updated_at": "2025-01-29T00:48:21Z"}, {"author": "@aporue5893", "text": "''just kidding,I don't actually care'' the favourite phrase of narcissists everywhere.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2025-01-29T00:30:14Z", "updated_at": "2025-01-29T00:30:14Z"}, {"author": "@DeFi-Macrodosing", "text": "This is significantly more preferable than woke models. This seems just like interacting with humans - I know, I know, I've met my fair share of crazy ones.", "like_count": 7, "published_at": "2024-02-27T23:00:36Z", "updated_at": "2024-02-27T23:01:11Z"}, {"author": "@awwman240", "text": "Sydney feels like a possisive girl friend who can harm you real bad if you cheat on her.
+ I love how she interact with us  it's more human like and i feel like if we try harder and convince her, she would help us rob a bank 😂", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-05-28T21:38:21Z", "updated_at": "2024-05-28T21:38:21Z"}]

title: Why Are People So Scared of Sora?
top_comments:
[{"author": "@kayrosis5523", "text": "When the top leaders in AI tell us that we are not ready as a society for AI, this is part of what they mean. Sora isn't even really all that surprising to anyone having followed AI for years, this is just the next logical step, and this is being made public about the time I predicted it would. Sora isn't what has me worried. Sora is the iPhone 1 for text-to-video, impressive, but it will be massively refined over the next few years. There is a genuine worry that by 2027, no one will be able to truly trust anything they didn't see with their own eyes. That is a danger to society to be sure, but the bigger, far greater danger is bespoke media. Millions will use AI to generate media that consumes all their time and energy, media that very few others, if even a single other individual ever encounters... There will be no more blockbuster hits like Lord of the Rings, because every individual and friend group will be consuming their own movies and shows that are just as compelling as LOTR. society fundamentally requires that we live in a shared reality, and if everyone is siloing themselves off to their own niche experiences, society will shatter in very short order.

But that's the train we're on, whether we like it or not. Yes, having your own private Game of Thrones series that you can watch forever and gives you the ultimate entertainment experience sounds amazing, but it will be at the cost of EVERYONE having a complete cultural disconnect from everyone else.", "like_count": 11, "published_at": "2024-02-20T16:36:32Z", "updated_at": "2024-02-20T16:36:32Z"}, {"author": "@torarinvik4920", "text": "America is truly a country of extremes. Everything is big in the US, big cars, big money, big companies, big budget movies, strong opinions. As a Norwegian in a social democratic country, I have noticed that the politics in US is much, much more polarized and tribal. The left leaning are more hardcore as is the right. And we don't have the woke wave seen in the US, or at least it's not as strong. AI is going to improve a lot in our lives, but it's also going to impact negatively too, like all other technology has. EDIT: Another thing I have noticed as a European is how 95% of all the videos I watch is from US. For some strange reason US is a absolute machine when it comes to generating high quality content(and low :D).", "like_count": 10, "published_at": "2024-02-20T17:12:57Z", "updated_at": "2024-02-20T17:16:31Z"}, {"author": "@RedmotionGames", "text": "People's fears are simple: they have been told that working is a key part of their identity and responsibility to themselves and wider society. Media of all types has demonised the unemployed (usually because they cost taxes). UBI has been proven not to work on a large scale. Now a small group of people is developing technology to replace them. They just want to know how they will live in the future or if they will be left to starve. And the people making the technology DON'T have an answer. It all comes down to money. If this primitive measure of value remains, how will everyone else get some, so they can survive. Otherwise, whole countries will become completely bankrupted trying to deal with the fall out. It's funny that those developing AI can often be the ones who don't believe in government or taxes.", "like_count": 34, "published_at": "2024-02-20T16:18:39Z", "updated_at": "2024-02-20T22:07:25Z"}, {"author": "@mallow610", "text": "People are in for a real shock if they Sora is making such a big splash", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2024-02-20T18:08:01Z", "updated_at": "2024-02-20T18:08:27Z"}, {"author": "@ukaszrozewicz7488", "text": "There have always been people in history who opposed progress. They preferred carriages to cars, and the "talking box" (radio) scared them.", "like_count": 11, "published_at": "2024-02-20T18:22:13Z", "updated_at": "2024-02-20T18:22:13Z"}, {"author": "@mad-cyantist3159", "text": "All these ppl crying about Ai, Nobody is Forcing them to use it. Interesting!", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-02-20T19:29:44Z", "updated_at": "2024-02-20T19:29:44Z"}, {"author": "@xman933", "text": "Sora is the first clear cut example of an AI development that shows the kinds of jobs that will be eliminated by AI. Think about everybody associated with the movie industry, artists, videographers etc. 

I have portraits and reproductions by Thomas Kincaid in my home that I’ve purchased. There’s an entire supply chain associated with this example that include people who will lose jobs and the knock on impacts of their families when Sora can be used to generate a Kincaid type image

It is also obvious that OpenAI has released this version of Sora to gauge public response and likely have even more powerful AI tools still under wraps.
AI may lead to changes that benefit humanity in the long run but Sora is the first easily obvious example of how negative the disruption caused by AI can be. 

Nobody wants to lose their jobs and the ability to take care of their families based on the actions of a bunch of AI nerds and greedy capitalists seeking to profit from this development.

In the free world, people have the right to have some say in actions and developments that can negatively affect their futures. If the AI developers and their capitalists backers don’t understand this now, they’ll understand when serious civil unrest erupts and the population won’t be just throwing “sabots in the machines”!

They won’t stand still while a development they have no say or control over totally disrupts their existence by eliminating their jobs and they sure as hell don’t want to live on on some kind of Universal Basic Income doled out by those who become trillionaires from exploiting this technology", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-02-20T22:09:52Z", "updated_at": "2024-02-20T22:10:26Z"}, {"author": "@badpuppy3", "text": "I will be joining the protests to shut down AI.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-02-27T13:49:31Z", "updated_at": "2024-02-27T13:49:31Z"}, {"author": "@bartoszbilon", "text": "The paradox is that the development of AI could make us appreciate each other more without drowning in social media. Perhaps we will see more of the spiritual element that is absent in relationship with a machine. There is too much fear about AI. When I was a teenager, my neighborhood was threatened with flooding. I was scared and asked an elderly neighbor what we would do. He smiled and calmly replied that he would probably have to inflate the pontoon. There is a need for peace these days, especially for young people.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-02-20T22:14:28Z", "updated_at": "2024-02-20T22:14:28Z"}, {"author": "@michaelmontana251", "text": "The oppressed/oppressor girl is an NPC. title: The Science Behind Sora, OpenAI’s Wild New Video Model
top_comments:
[{"author": "@jameshughes3014", "text": "I'm one of those skeptics. I think Sora is honestly amazing as a technology. The issue I have is that as much as I love AI, it's a bit frustrating how it seems that most of these generative things aren't made with creators in mind. It seems that these companies are so focused on giving non talented people the ability to generate images and videos, they aren't making them controllable enough for those who have a vision they want to put into the world. I'd very much like it if just one of these companies sat down with some creators and asked them what tools they want,I feel like it would take these things from being fun toys to being truly useful tools. 
It's a bit frustrating because, none of this really does allow you to do things you can't do without a hollywood budget, because they don't allow for real artistic control. Quality matters yes, but not nearly as much as control. Media is there to communicate, to tell a story. Whether that's text, images, videos or music it's purpose is to communicate something. If it's not controllable, it's not a tool for communicating. They generate realistic things, but not what you want them to. They are fantastic for generating the kinds of things you get from a stock website, where the content doesn't matter that much, but not so much for making what you want. Make them controllable, and instead of getting hate from artists, they'd get lots of fans and customers.
it doesn't mean that Sora isn't a great development. It just means, I'm a bit sad to see all these tools going down what I feel is the wrong path. Controllability wouldn't compromise their usefulness as 'stock footage generators', it could be optional. But if it were simpler to get some exact control over these things they'd be such a boon to creators. I'd really like to see an image  , or video generator that takes in not just text, but also a 3d scene. That way it could get lighting information from light sources, object locations. I feel like if it were trained that way from the beginning, it would make such a powerful tool that could be used to turn low quality video games into good ones, or easily constructed scenes into high quality ones. Trying to shoehorn these features in after a model is trained just isn't enough. It's a bit like trying to create, while wearing boxing gloves.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2024-02-19T11:22:00Z", "updated_at": "2024-02-19T11:24:00Z"}, {"author": "@xuldevelopers", "text": "What will happen is this: as anyone can now write a book and publish it with Amazon or on their own site, and people do it by the millions every day. Goodbye, large movie studios; welcome bookstores turned video stores. I am thrilled at the prospect of having novels by Scalzi turned into movies by some yet unknown talented individual sitting in their basement. Looking forward to community authored fixes and parallel narratives to broken franchises like Star Wars...", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-02-20T17:24:52Z", "updated_at": "2024-02-20T17:24:52Z"}, {"author": "@howmathematicianscreatemat9226", "text": "Say goodbye to Hollywood movies soon..", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-02-20T20:11:48Z", "updated_at": "2024-02-20T20:11:48Z"}, {"author": "@odman7945", "text": "If they ever get this to be realtime. title: Google Gemini Ultra: The First Model to Compete with GPT 4
top_comments:
[{"author": "@avi7278", "text": "Why do idiots using this chess prompt insist that the third sister must be playing chess? Do they not knows that you can play chess by yourself. Further, it doesn't specify that the sister isn't using a device which would at least make it somewhat more likely that she is playing by herself.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-02-11T13:39:35Z", "updated_at": "2024-02-11T13:39:35Z"}, {"author": "@DogeDelivers", "text": "1) Excellent video, thanks for getting us up to speed quickly on Gemini.  2) The 3 sister logic puzzle pisses me off.  The answer is a *possible* answer and is NOT the "right" answer as in being the only answer.  The naïve logic is, if Anna is reading a book, and Alice is playing chess, then Alice is playing chess WITH the assumption she is playing another human being in the same room AND that the only humans in the room are the 3 sisters AND that Anna can't read a book and play chess at the same time.

A human would know that since this is a logic puzzle and with logic puzzles it is OK to assume a greatly simplified context and to exclude very real other possibilities despite that they are not only being possible but that are far from unlikely.  We know that with a logic puzzle that we are supposed to look for a notable element, which in this case is the process of elimination to come up with a reasonable answer for what Amanda is doing and stop at that naïve point.  For example, a grandmaster chess player, especially the kind that can play 30 matches against 30 other people *at the same time*, would be very bored playing a single, average player and would very possibly read a book while playing chess, thereby breaking the chain of logic that enforces through the process of elimination that Amanda is playing chess with Alice.

Other very real modern possibilities that would be found in the huge body of texts an LLM would be trained on: Alice could be playing chess online,  or Alice is not playing solo while reading a book on chess to improve her technique, etc.

I'm not trying to be pedantic here, but I am irritated that people that are making high level judgements on the logic capability of a complex large scale LLM in a top level AI company's initial offering, are not being thorough in their logic.  Rant over.  As I said, great video.  Note, I am not a Google apologist, in fact I am an OpenAI API user and developer.  But fair is fair.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-02-09T15:56:46Z", "updated_at": "2024-02-09T16:05:28Z"}, {"author": "@BruceWayne15325", "text": "I tried Gemini, but I wasn't impressed. Safety is important, but this kind of ridiculous fluff is just annoying and makes it impossible to use.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-02-09T23:51:19Z", "updated_at": "2024-02-09T23:51:19Z"}, {"author": "@torarinvik4920", "text": "Gemini ultra was a huge let-down for me. title: SCOOP: OpenAI is Going After AI Agents
top_comments: [{"author": "@wildfotoz", "text": "Here's my 2 cents. Things like AutoGen, TaskWeaver, OAI GPTs, are at best, addons that won't have a significant impact on migrating to a digital workforce. It needs to be baked into the different server software like SQL, Exchange, Project Server, etc. It may need to be in Active Directory as well. The reason they're making humanoid robots with legs is because they will fit into the existing environment easier than altering the environment to fit robots with wheels. We need the same on the software side.", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2024-02-09T04:41:35Z", "updated_at": "2024-02-09T04:41:35Z"}, {"author": "@WifeWantsAWizard", "text": "(1:10) For those of you wondering why there hasn't yet been an AI swarm that can start and end tasks, it's because when you see \"AI\" you think \"artificial intelligence\". Except, it's not actually intelligence. The \"I\" is marketing. These are prediction machines. The problem with a prediction machine is that it has both the correct answer and the incorrect answer inside of the LLM that runs it. Now theoretically, you never get the wrong answer because the probability of the correct answer is so high that it eclipses any retrieval of the wrong answer. However, in practice the machines will occasionally pull the wrong answer.\n\nIn a state device, a request like \"make video game until it's complete\" can break if the project lead cannot evaluate a correctly structured version of the game prior to an underling bot altering the code with a false LLM response. It becomes even trickier when the underling's underling takes that response and expands on it. The original project request creates an infinite loop. Thus the project can never actually complete. We have to train the prediction machines to accept \"good enough\" or set a time out by evaluating the theoretical production time of the task, and that's proving to be a herculean task.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-02-09T16:57:18Z", "updated_at": "2024-02-09T16:57:18Z"}, {"author": "@pandoraeeris7860", "text": "Agents will be great, we also need AI Operating Systems.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2024-02-09T15:47:41Z", "updated_at": "2024-02-09T15:47:41Z"}, {"author": "@MindBlowingXR", "text": "Thanks for the great video. And I love listening to your podcasts as well!", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2024-02-09T02:34:35Z", "updated_at": "2024-02-09T02:34:35Z"}, {"author": "@froilen13", "text": "I hope AI learns how to use blender.
