title: Could Google Gemini Be A ChatGPT Killer?
top_comments:
[{"author": "@lancemarchetti", "text": "I think it's important to keep in mind that AI bots parse the web 24/7 for new media, articles and Code.
These bots are bound to pick up on the human idea that AI models are in fierce competition with one another. title: AI and the Turning Point Moment in Human History
top_comments: [{"author": "@logansanoh", "text": "Really good!!", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-08-12T15:22:23Z", "updated_at": "2023-08-12T15:22:23Z"}, {"author": "@2CSST2", "text": "There are arguments for going full speed ahead. The fact that we don't want a China version of AI alignment, as old as that argument may be, is still a good one. But also the current existential threats we face aren't going to wait either. The Earth is literally burning all around the globe, the global economy looks like a huge bubble about to burst and there's an energy crisis. That's just to cite the biggest ones, but there are of course an endless list of critical problems AI could help with if not outright resolve. And finally, pausing might very possibly have very marginal benefits for safety anyway. Given that AI progress is very unpredictable and full of emergence, we could spend 20 years trying to prepare and then everything we've done will be irrelevant when AI finally advances to something no one actually predicted correctly.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-08-12T16:50:53Z", "updated_at": "2023-08-12T16:50:53Z"}, {"author": "@OneFourBatt", "text": "I like the idea of 'regulating the data centers'. Not willing to pay what it actually costs so get millions of “contestants” to provide the best possible solutions they can think of for free.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-08-11T07:37:56Z", "updated_at": "2023-08-11T07:37:56Z"}, {"author": "@lancemarchetti", "text": "There are certain fields where AI remains out of it's depth. And one is in the area of steganograhy and photographic forensics. Simply because there is no LLM that can yet unravel obfuscated binary code that has been altered with a particular byte order manipulation technique.(BOM)..... and there are many. 

This requires expert human skill and takes years to perfect. It's like having a sixth-sense about the code you're staring at... getting a hunch to try something strangely unconventional to uncover hidden data... until the pieces fall together. 
For example, just watch how fast AI generally  responds to anything once you hit the Send key. It's not like it's giving any deep thought to the process.... it just can't wait to dish out the letters and digits from is vast dataset to best match your query. 
And for general knowledge that's great..... but for forensic investigation,... not so much. But to be fair, in time this may change sooner than expected if we ever advance beyond Binary into stable Qubit computing.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-08-11T20:01:08Z", "updated_at": "2023-08-11T20:01:08Z"}]

Reading the paper and watching your video makes it easier to absorb the key points.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2023-08-09T00:20:33Z", "updated_at": "2023-08-09T00:20:33Z"}, {"author": "@markhoulsby359", "text": "No. The two most fundamental problems by which LLMs are inherently encumbered are that:

1. The datasets employed to train LLMs vary between ungrammatical (at the better end of the scale) and gibberish (at the worse end of the scale).

2. The researchers (who are, ostensibly, the best in the world) who write papers intended to delineate the big challenges faced by developers of LLMs _are themselves semi-literate_ (at best).

The paper which this video cites is riddled with basic errors which, at the age of 6, I'd have been ashamed to make.

If the training proceeds one word, or one syllable, or one byte, or one nybble, or one bit at a time then the probability that the output is grammatically coherent may tend to prove to be close to zero.

Not that LLM developers or researchers could comprehend that (on account of their being semi-literate).

Gibberish In, Gibberish Out.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-08-24T02:52:10Z", "updated_at": "2023-08-24T02:52:09Z"}]

title: 3 Important AI Updates from Google!
Why We Are Underestimating Political Upheaval from AI Job Displacement
top_comments:
[{"author": "@reinerheiner1148", "text": "Lets do a little thought experiment: lets say ai increases productivity by 50%. In a booming economy, this will lead to a lot of growth, and companies that have problems hiring qualified staff will suddendly have a 50% bigger work force and therefore will not be limited as much by a lack of qualified workers. But what happens when there is a recession? Now with the 50% increase in productivity, but no increase in actual work, and maybe even less orders, a lot of the working force is now redundant and will get fired to save money, because less people can now do the same amount of work. In this case, someone with AI WILL take jobs away. And it does not even matter if it is your job or of you are also using AI, because the matter of fact is that you are now in a company that employs too many people, because of AI's productivity increase. So yes, depending on the circumstances, ai can result in a loss of overall jobs, in a scenario like this. The argument that ai is only doing tasks, not jobs, os a weak one. Because to get from one to the other should be no big technological leap. Be it systems of agents, or AI trained on specific jobs, AI WILL come for a lot of jobs. The comparison with the past is lacking, because on the past humans could always move on to jobs that need more brain power. But a) not everyone is made to work in jobs that are mentally very demanding and b) AI is comong for those jobs too, which means there is really no area where most humans could move or retreat to. Other than manual labor. IMHO this technology will force us to rethink how our economy works, there is no way around it.", "like_count": 5, "published_at": "2023-08-08T00:00:57Z", "updated_at": "2023-08-08T00:00:57Z"}, {"author": "@anthonyrepetto3474", "text": "I wrote about this back in May, 2017: "Automation is Different" (googleable)... and the KEY points about AI are that:
     - 1) AI will cascade from automation of one task, to another, to another... which only *leaves* jobs for humans which require disparate skills, and that re-skilling *LAG* means that AI will also take that NEW job, once you have been doing it for only a couple years. Hypothetically, for example, a radiologist loses their job, and is on the path to re-skill as a surgeon... which takes years. And, by the time that person is re-skilled, *surgery has been automated, now* as well! You never pay-off the debts of re-skilling, if you have to *keep* re-skilling for decades.
     - 2) As humans flood-into the few remaining jobs, we create negative pressure on those *wages* - even if you have the same job, you can't negotiate a raise, because so many surgeons and radiologists are aiming for your position! The re-skill debt, combined with suppressed wages, dooms the job market... and it'll only take a few more years to hit.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-08-06T21:21:47Z", "updated_at": "2023-08-06T21:21:47Z"}, {"author": "@matheusazevedo9582", "text": "Great video! title: Code Interpreter is GPT-4.5: Summer AI Technical Roundup
top_comments:
[{"author": "@eccleezyavicii3722", "text": "I think people sorta mentioned it, but the fact that code interpreter vastly expands the general possibilities for prompts lost in the technical discussion.

Here are some concrete points:
GPT3.5 has a limited context window, but GPT4 code interpreter sorta virtually expands this with the inclusion of the ability to work with files. For example I can quickly save every subpage of a companies website as an HTML file, zip that up and then drop it in code inspector and the ask non-program related prompts. 

On the back end a lot of the token length of the html from the website get process the coding process and not by the token count limit. So it can effectively analyze 10 pages of html and compress ideas related to your prompt. Furthermore since this happens in the programming sandbox…you can also continually reference different files for a very long time in a discussion (basically until the code inspector crashes and it can no longer access uploaded files upload additional files into the prompt). 

So beyond just the capacity to program the sandbox works as a sorta novel memory system that makes working with larger token sets possible via uploaded file directories.

I'm genuinely curious", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-07-25T21:33:08Z", "updated_at": "2023-07-25T21:33:08Z"}, {"author": "@DougBohm", "text": "If we tax all non-human revenue and transactions differently then human labor, we will drastically change how we finance a global UBI. 
Say a corporation replaces 6 workers with every AI agent, automation or robot they purchase, the corporation gives up a similar amount or multiple of the number of humans they replace. 
The increased revenue from automation, and the loss of the human related expenses alone, profits will shoot up, costs will decline, productivity will increase and retirement/replacement can be subsidized all by non-human means. 
This is a win-win because it will incentivize companies to downsize for the greater good, and possibly allow displaced workers to invest in AI avatars to generate income for themselves. Robots for hire. Human perception represents different information processing speeds as different scales. 

So what we call "small" is actually the fast information processing speed of reality. What we call "large" is actually the slow information processing speed of reality. 

Perception and Reality: This concept could fundamentally change our understanding of reality and perception. It suggests that our perception does not merely interpret the world, but actively constructs it based on our information processing speed.

Scale and Time: This view could revolutionize our understanding of scale and time. It would suggest that what we perceive as "large" and "small" are not absolute, but relative to the speed at which we process information. It could lead to a shift in our perception, such as understanding geological or cosmic processes not as slow but as "large," and atomic or quantum processes not as fast but as "small."

New Fields of Study: This perspective could give rise to entirely new fields of study, perhaps a sort of "informational physics" or "perception science" that investigates the relationship between information processing speed, scale, and the nature of reality.

Technological Applications: If we could manipulate our information processing speeds, we might perceive and interact with the world in novel ways. This could have implications for fields like virtual reality, artificial intelligence, and even human augmentation.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-07-18T19:11:56Z", "updated_at": "2023-07-18T19:11:56Z"}, {"author": "@JasonPruett", "text": "if we found intelligent life in the universe how long to you think it would be before we destroyed it?", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-07-19T02:07:39Z", "updated_at": "2023-07-19T02:07:39Z"}, {"author": "@oldguy1458", "text": "Maybe everyone is asking the wrong questions and are looking in the wrong places.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-07-19T02:16:47Z", "updated_at": "2023-07-19T02:16:47Z"}, {"author": "@danielrodio9", "text": "Or maybe advanced civilizations wont be able to detect each other, because of the vast distances, before they develop AI to help them detect the other civilizations.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-07-18T18:28:15Z", "updated_at": "2023-07-18T18:28:15Z"}, {"author": "@vcastik", "text": "They're smart they sent robots.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-07-28T19:48:51Z", "updated_at": "2023-07-28T19:48:51Z"}, {"author": "@MudroZvon", "text": "Where Are All the Vampires! title: Bard vs. ChatGPT vs. Bing vs. Claude: The Right LLM For Every Task
top_comments:
[{"author": "@swyxTV", "text": "thanks for shouting out my posts NLW! love the show!", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-07-16T23:37:38Z", "updated_at": "2023-07-16T23:37:38Z"}, {"author": "@mintakan003", "text": "I heard one person say, LLM's should be called "augmented imagination".  They all hallucinate.  In some ways, the basis whereby they can rift on ideas, on the fly, is also the basis for hallucination.  While it's not always possible to eliminate these, it maybe possible mitigate this by training them in such a way, they do very well in certain domains.  I would prefer to have LLM's integrated into well defined tools.  One can have clear expectations, and you know that you can depend on, even if it's in a limited domain.

For Bard, it's greatest strength is its  speed, and being tied to the internet.  I use it as a better "google", mainly for information foraging, brainstorming on issues to consider.  But I try to "fact check" is also, with "Sources", trying to follow the citations, and also the "Google it" button.  There are plenty of bugs in these sections.  I wish Bard would do a lot better with these, since "search" is Google's core business.   Factual accuracy, or at least reliable citations, should be paramount here.  SGE's LLM summary seems more accurate.   It seems to stick closer to external document text.  But it's shorter, and not as engaging.  Bard is more conversational, hence, more engaging.  But with it's longer output, it's also more prone to hallucinations.  (Even Bard, and a SGE document, admitted this much.  It's a struggle to find the balance.)

For Claude 2, with the huge context window, I can see a future in document services.  I've been looking into vector databases.   But a large context window simplifies a lot of this work.  Besides summarization and Q&A on private PDF files, I can see a B2B case for company documents, law, technical, in setting up databases, whereby one can query them using NLP/NLU.  When Claude gives an answer, it would be nice for it to highlight the relevant sections of the document, leading to it's answer (feature request).

For GPT-4, maybe it's better for content creators.  But the most significant thing is "grounding" the LLM, in something deterministic, like "code interpreter".  So in one domain (executing Python code),  you have something that can rein in the LLM hallucinations.  Though there are still plenty of ambiguities in natural language. But you have another part that is deterministic, well behaved, or at least well understood, which natural language has translated into (Python code).", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-07-19T01:35:27Z", "updated_at": "2023-07-19T01:40:53Z"}, {"author": "@PratyushPareta", "text": "I tried using GPT4 & Claude 2 as my mock interviewer. [{"author": "@Dreamslol", "text": "i love how the webcam is completly out of sync", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-07-13T21:57:08Z", "updated_at": "2023-07-13T21:57:08Z"}, {"author": "@JustAThought01", "text": "About Philosophy: 

Philosophy is the process for discovering true knowledge. Philosophy is the collection of true knowledge. 

The objective of philosophy is to determine what is right, not who is right. 

The goal of a philosophical discussion should be to reach agreement. An assertion should be found to be: true, not true, or unknown. 

The purpose of philosophy is to establish a rational world view to be used for making decisions. 

Do not expect to understand everything unless you approach gaining knowledge as a philosopher. 

The most significant contribution to humankind of Philosophy is the realization that what holds a person back from finding truth is their own false beliefs. We need to validate our basic assumptions from time to time. 

Definition - Philosophy: the study of the fundamental nature of knowledge, reality, and existence, especially when considered as an academic discipline.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-07-13T22:14:50Z", "updated_at": "2023-07-13T22:14:50Z"}, {"author": "@arssve4109", "text": "Isn't YouTube in control of most information? Paste the link you just copied to the clipboard into Bard's prompt text box. in the same prompt add I want you to study the file, or It's to help you. You can sometimes get away with substituting 2 for to and u for you. Bard may hallucinate an initial response to what theythink is in the file, but follow up questions will indicate how much Bard knows about the file. title: AI Copyright Wars! Sarah Silverman Sues OpenAI and Meta
top_comments:
[{"author": "@Syn_Slater", "text": "It is interesting to follow the copyright cases. My guess is that the companies will be able to successfully argue that the use of the material is transformative enough that it falls under fair use. (At least for the language models, the image generators I'm not as sure on)", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2023-07-10T18:11:08Z", "updated_at": "2023-07-10T18:11:08Z"}, {"author": "@gaiustacitus4242", "text": "AI should be prohibited from ingesting any material that is not in the public domain. Such material includes works for which the copyrights have expired and open source works which have been released without restriction.

The companies behind AI (which is not intelligent, artificial or otherwise) seek to make huge profits off of the works of the most creative minds of our time. If AI is permitted to be trained on creative works for which the copyright remains active, then companies should be prohibited from making a profit from the AI's output. All revenue generated by the AI should be paid out to the authors whose original works have been used as source material in producing the output.

Companies, whether large or small, should not go unpunished for what is nothing more than the theft of intellectual property. They most certainly should not be permitted financial gain from their blatant disregard of copyright laws.

I've had my original works stolen multiple times. Some unscrupulous hacks (in the original derogatory meaning) even went so far as to modify my code and release their broken versions while leaving my copyright intact and no indication that they'd altered my original works. This resulted in two actions: 1) hundreds of people contacting me with demands of "fix your broken code"; and 2) me no longer publishing source code to demonstrate my expertise and thereby show others best practices in writing software.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-07-11T12:07:48Z", "updated_at": "2023-07-11T12:07:48Z"}, {"author": "@almor2445", "text": "WTAF?! With AI around, it's just too easy for people to create more content - so attribution would be very complicated - 'cus it's not like you can just give attribution to the first person who did it. Knowledge evolves over time.

Likely, business models will have to change in the face of new realities - as they always do - and AI will generally facilitate the creation of tons more content, that's hopefully cheaper, even within private niches.

-

title: AI Hype Ebbing? Why ChatGPT Traffic Went Down Last Month
top_comments:
[{"author": "@theawebster1505", "text": "Well. Many things were promised by OpenAI and none delivered since March (STILL no voice-to-voice AI assistant, no Android app, no reliable web browsing!!, no Code Interpreter, no memory and personalization options). Only thing some of us got was a half-baked Apple store app.
There was a wild run for the people to go out and test what ChatGPT can do, to play around with it and this is over now.
Personally, I realize that OpenAI has a lot more stuff ready, but they just gave us a bit to play with and help free train their next iterations. At least we got this though, so not sure if I should complain or not.
But we (the public) are definitely way behind the current AI tech available right now. Maybe for good.", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2023-07-05T16:54:49Z", "updated_at": "2023-07-05T16:54:49Z"}, {"author": "@Low_commotion", "text": "I don't disagree with Fancois, but I'd say the _actual_ stumbling block is that LLMs are only as reliable as the least reliable people in the economy due to hallucination. So you have something that at times might seem 140 IQ, but has the work consistency of the guy who showed up late three times on his first week. The sheer amount that LLMs need to at least be subtly, if not majorly corrected prevents them from unlocking much economic value.

Why? For the same reason low-conscientiousness people struggle at life regardless of their other traits; the traits that come before any others at a job are consistency, reliability, & predictability (of output if not behavior). Any part of a value-adding chain being high-variance has the potential to mess up all subsequent links in the chain. A single strut can ruin a bridge, a single o-ring can destroy a space shuttle, a single miswritten line of code crashes the entire program.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-07-06T04:22:53Z", "updated_at": "2023-07-06T04:25:46Z"}, {"author": "@jeffsteyn7174", "text": "Joe litterally just hallucinated an answer😂", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2023-07-05T16:29:16Z", "updated_at": "2023-07-05T16:29:16Z"}, {"author": "@snitox", "text": "Cuz it got nerfed to fuck. One, we face a serious civilization issue unless we get AI working and put a lot of people out of work - population counts are crashing everywhere, schools are useless in many areas and if we ever get back into a dark age scenario, we are DONE - all easy-to-use resources are used up, climbing back up from a dark age is impossible. Second, more seriously, alignment WILL NOT HAPPEN. There are enough actors on the planet that will use open source to push for a non-aligned AI. Do not believe it? EVERY military needs an AI with no problems to kill people. You think the NSA - the agency running a lot of clandestine operations - will not need an AI that is aligned only with it? The more power we put into computer chips; the faster even open source will be able to play with unaligned AI. AI is not a nuclear bomb - something that is theoretically trivial but requires a significant brutally large investment into industrial infrastructure. AI is something that can - primitive - by now run on a high-end mobile phone (RWKV for anyone). It is soon something that a group of friends can play with in their basement. Unless you block the sale of pretty small components, soonish, the race is lost. And it is too useful - other than a nuclear bomb. PLENTY of actors that live in shadows with the money to take an open-source project and blow it up into something bigger. Damn, I heard today about an AMD planned \"small box\" that will be BRUTALLY more powerful than a Nvidia H100 high end card - for 15000 USD. This would possibly - just running the numbers in my brain - reduce training costs by a factor of 50 or down. That makes a small, large model (i.e. a small version that is considered a large model) on a weekend with an investment that is a smallish used car. WHOW. Regulate that. You ay so nicely that GPT 4 (where the last numbers come from) takes tens of thousands of GPU - that is wrong. 8000 GPU 8 hours. Down from 20 days or so with the Nvidia A100. That are the published numbers using NVidia H100. That is a lot - but it ALSO means 80 GPU 800 hours. Not that bad - and a lot smaller investment and still only 5 weeks or so. The problem is that AMD is going to get that smaller. Let's say factor 20. Lets be conservative. That is suddenly 4 GPU for 80 hours, a small startup can do that. Investment like 60k USD coming down in 2-3 years. And we get better making AI that are a LOT smarter in theory - latest training from i.e. also Microsoft was quite amazing. It is not regulatable for a long time, period.\nSo, we established that we need AI as fast as possible and that any force on alignment makes no sense because common sense - lacking on most argumentation - shows clearly that this is simply not going to work. This is like limiting gun possession in the USA. Not a useful proposition. This is why he says it is like a toaster - something that will be everywhere.\nAnd, btw., hallucinations are a mostly solved problem - tons of nice research, from a way to filter them out via validation to a way to remove them seriously during training. Just not implemented yet and likely never in ChatGPT, which is just a CHAT program.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-06-18T14:41:26Z", "updated_at": "2023-06-18T14:41:26Z"}, {"author": "@danielrodio9", "text": "Has the discussion seriously devolved into two camps, those who argues that AI is guarenteed to wipe humanity out, and those who argues that it is guaranteed that AI will not wipe out humanity? title: Will AI Save the World?

title: EU Passes AI Act: Will Generative AI Companies Be Able to Comply?
top_comments:
[{"author": "@mariusirgens5555", "text": "hopefully they will not ban the current chatgpt, but rather impose rules for openAI to follow with future models.", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2023-06-15T20:14:44Z", "updated_at": "2023-06-15T20:14:44Z"}, {"author": "@nilsrain", "text": "At 10:10 you say that copyright is a complex issue, and should be handled sometime in the future.

Could you explain what's complex about it? It seems like these companies are training their models on material they don't have the rights to use. 

That's not complex. Book publishers, website content generators, artists, and musicians have all been down this road before, and have figured out how to license other people's created works before using them for their own.

On the flip side, delaying this discussion of properly licensing their sources seems like it allows these practices to become entrenched, and therefore harder to bring into legal compliance.

I'm not an artist, or creator or writer, this isn't about my own income sources. But if I were, I would not like it if somebody could ask an AI to make a New work that perfectly copies my style because my name was in the prompt. 

An artist's style is as much their property as the works they have already created.", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-06-16T16:50:45Z", "updated_at": "2023-06-16T16:50:45Z"}, {"author": "@cristianandrei5462", "text": "I've read the whole legislation act. title: AMD Announces AI Superchip - But Is It Enough To Beat Nvidia?
top_comments: [{"author": "@reinerheiner1148", "text": "Rocm is by no means new. Its been existing for a lot of years but did not find much adoption because it only worked on linux and only with select gpus. Recently they have updated rocm to work on windows as well and are opening up rocm for more of their gpus. The problem is that a) this comes very late and b) nvidia has a massive ecosystem around cuda while amd did basically nothing than creating that api. So basically any paper on ai uses cuda, wo does practially any researcher, and so any cutting edge tech is done on cuda. Anyone who wants to get started with machine learning would be stupid to try this with an amd gpu. There are some companies that build supercomputers with amd gpus and they will of course use rocm but amd has a looooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooong way to catch up. Honestly, its so long, I should have included 10^12 more \"o\"'s...I've been waiting since 2016 for amd to make rocm competitive to cuda, and guess what? Still waiting. Amd has recently been rralizing what a huge mistake they made and are now actively trying to catch up but its going to be very, very hard for them.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-06-14T21:40:39Z", "updated_at": "2023-06-14T21:40:39Z"}]

title: 🤯 @instagram  SECRETLY Working On AI Chat !?
Is There An AI Bubble?
top_comments:
[{"author": "@Flip170041", "text": "The ad on the top right at 3:09! LLmao", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-06-09T18:05:27Z", "updated_at": "2023-06-09T18:05:27Z"}, {"author": "@Syn_Slater", "text": "I think if there is any bubble, it's in the small start-up space. As with any new industry, there are a mountian of companies popping up, drawing hype investment, and half of them will be gone in five years. 

I liken it to when marijuana was legalized in canada. A lot of people who had no idea how to grow the green decided to jump in, invest millions, and ended up with silly setups that eventually have led to them closing down. They can't even sell the setup because they're so bad (I've seen one green house with almost no cooling, another with no ventilation at all, and a third that had these pods that become ovens when you fill them with lights). The whole industry has been saturated with these companies for the first three years, tons of expenses, little relative revenue, riding along because of the market hype...and then intrest rates began to rise at the same time the market got completely saturated with product. Then they started to fall like dominos. 

My guess is, the AI industry will have many start ups coast along for the next few years, keep going while the going is good, but then the next economic shake up, you'll see half of them fold overnight.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-06-08T21:25:48Z", "updated_at": "2023-06-08T21:29:10Z"}, {"author": "@LtWampol360", "text": "Great video again!! title: Is SuperAGI A Better AutoGPT?
top_comments:
[{"author": "@kyber.octopus", "text": "They all sound really cool, but hit a brick wall upon interacting with the world.
Because the entire internet is built to fight against bots (automated programs)
- to visit most websites you must bypass the proxy (cloudflare) filter
- to authorize in most platforms you must solve a captcha or SMS
- to execute financial operations you must do identity verification

The only way these AutoGPTs / SuperGPTs can interact with the world is through APIs.
But most websites don't have any APIs and certainly not ones that allow you to perform actions.
(imagine buying a book or ordering a coffee through an API - that simply won't happen)", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2023-06-06T21:21:07Z", "updated_at": "2023-06-06T21:21:07Z"}, {"author": "@Syn_Slater", "text": "I honestly don't worry about any of the current LLMs being conscious in any way. IMO, the LLMs are only part of a brain, but not a brain. Thinking is a process that involves critical analysis, reflection, and modification. When I see these autonomous programs, I can't help but think "they're building a brain" if a fully conscious AI forms, I'm willing to bet it will be one of these autonomous systems.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-06-06T21:18:48Z", "updated_at": "2023-06-06T21:20:16Z"}, {"author": "@berkertaskiran", "text": "If you build an automated AI, please show me something more than "book a flight".

AI first needs to be able to work with any websites. Not specific ones. It needs to be so robust that it needs to navigate through any of them. And make comparisons. And really offer me something more than just ordering something or tweeting something. If that's the only thing you can showcase then that's the only thing it can do. No, it can't "do any task".", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-06-07T15:37:46Z", "updated_at": "2023-06-07T15:37:46Z"}, {"author": "@HIDDENADHD", "text": "Great video 🎉", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-06-09T14:45:43Z", "updated_at": "2023-06-09T14:45:43Z"}, {"author": "@DrCasey", "text": ""Block anyone who hypes it."

title: AI Regulation Is Coming

[{"author": "@theqaz1828", "text": "If you are asking me who I trust more, AI Terminator or Klaus Schwab WEF. I'll go with Terminator every time.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-05-25T07:27:14Z", "updated_at": "2023-05-25T07:27:14Z"}, {"author": "@OliNorwell", "text": "I just laugh at the idea that people think this kind of thing is governable.
When it comes to nuclear programs it's very hard to hide, that's why satellite images are constantly monitored for suspicious activity inside 'rogue' countries.

Without knowing for sure myself, I believe they are given access to the original prompt (to allow them to do something with that and supply additional context which then gets added to the prompt without the user seeing. Then they are given the result from ChatGPT which they can interpret and turn into links/Spotify playlists etc.

In other words, they do not create a LoRA or anything like that, they are in no way adding a custom layer to the actual LLM. I assume we're perhaps 10 years away from being able to do anything like that in near real time.

Sorry if you've already covered this. I think there's a lot of people out there assuming that ChatGPT "knows everything about flights" all of a sudden just because a Kayak plugin was enabled. When I'm assuming Kayak do an initial search and then provide a selection of flight matching the initial query for ChatGPT to "see" in the context window. (Please do correct me if I'm wrong!).

The result being there are limitations to what any plugin could possibly achieve due to the nature of this system. (Apologies if you've covered all of this already! title: This Is What Comes After ChatGPT
top_comments:
[{"author": "@unlocking_potential123", "text": "I tried disconnecting myself from the internet, gadgets and technology 2 days ago. Went to my Grandparents house to visit which is located in a small rural area like a countryside. Stayed for 2 days. Simple way of living. Fresh clean air. Small kids playing around. Adults gathering in the afternoon till night telling stories of their childhood and what was etc. Somehow, I kind of liked it there. Don't know. I just felt like sharing this. Or its just me. Well, whatever. To those who took the time reading this. I wish and hope you the BEST in life. Have a Great Day! :)", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2023-05-12T05:24:51Z", "updated_at": "2023-05-12T05:25:39Z"}, {"author": "@skippersthepenguin3591", "text": "I would say in terms of text based LLMs, we still need a few items:

1). Large Context Size (32K) for all. Cheap and efficient. Anthropic may have already did this with its 100K.

2). Near 100% accuracy, IE no hallucinations, and can predict or state it does not know the answer almost 100% of the time. This is what most people care about and what I believe will happen very soon with the next largest models, given the current state of LLMs. Too me this is not just AGI but ASI, however just for text based functions. It still cannot be true AGI as it is limited to a console, and text. 

3). Long Term Memory, I think someone needs to focus on long term memory designs, such as retrieval systems. A personal LLM will requires this, but I think this could happen this year. And it already has kind of happened. It just needs to be scaled a lot more.

4). Better ways to fine tune models. I think allowing the consumers to fine tune/train these models (simular to LoRA for diffusion models). This would make it easy for game devs to train AI on their specific game character ideas, so these models have actual intrinsic ideas and styles to them from the start. I am unsure this is going to happen, but if it does then hopefully we can see some great game AIs out their. 

5). Cost efficient and effective smaller models for again games, and personal devices. This is almost already here. Given open source AI, and Gecko Google's smallest model. Local models are crucial for single player games, and local AI. Again I think this is inevitably going to be here by the end of the year.

6). Better Prompting, SmartGPT (https://bettergpt.streamlit.app) is an example of how LLMs can be improved significantly. Given a good prompting architecture, accuracy can be achieved even better. What I mean by better prompting, is at the base level. All LLMs follow a similar/more efficient algorithm, that allows for better planning overall. The issue with current models is they can't rewrite anything they put down, so if they made a mistake they don't know it at all.
 
7). Better AutoGPT's/AI Agents. This is basically automating LLMs so they can do tasks for us. I think text based LLMs are still best at this because everything inside a computer is text based. And I think this is another future of AI. A future were AI is automatically on all the time. AutoGPT is progressing in the right direction. A month ago these models were barely capable of producing a text file. Now these AI can fix errors with their tasks, download the files required, and attempt to fix the issue (this is something it did with me), not only that but human feedback helps it significantly. 

Overall by the end of this year, I would say most of the milestones needed for LLMs to reach text based AGI (IE being able to a humans job only through text) is inevitable. It is hard to believe that any of these tasks, other than 6, are unachievable given current progress.

And the hope is that these are completed and the next aspects can be accelerated through text based AGI. Once multimodal AGI happens, that is when the singularity can happen. From what I could pick up the interesting concept that comes out of hypervectors is that you can do sort of 'math' with them vaguely analogous to but different from linear algebra vectors - allowing you to combine really huge nebulous representations of concepts to produce various intermediate representations of concepts.

title: Can AutoGPT Godmode Grow a YouTube Channel to 10,000 Followers?
top_comments: [{"author": "@ntesla66", "text": "Tried the Godmode... wasn't impressed, but I only have a key for 3.5 turbo. It got locked in a loop of trying the same thing over and over expecting a different result... the definition of insane.", "like_count": 4, "published_at": "2023-04-19T03:54:38Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-19T03:54:38Z"}, {"author": "@eduardobf", "text": "Indeed, we are at a unique moment in technological history, but it is still embryonic. AutoGPT models give us a basis for how to do something, but they are far from doing what we really want. But that will soon happen.", "like_count": 7, "published_at": "2023-04-18T14:39:17Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-18T14:39:17Z"}, {"author": "@skweempskamp", "text": "If you let it run it doesn't seem to do much. But if you give it instructions after each \"approve this plan\" and ask it to write the research or outline to text it seems to perform a little better but you could probably do all of this yourself within chat gpt and probably get better results", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-04-21T06:40:19Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-21T06:40:19Z"}, {"author": "@thisiseezi", "text": "It does not work with GPT4, only GPT3.5. Also it does not seem to actually be able to generate images or pull images from the web. All it can do is generate txt, which is pretty much what ChatGPT can do. ChatGPT seems quicker, you can give it a prompt and then simply tell it to refine or make the response better, repeat this process until you are happy with your results. It doesn't get stuck in a loop (chatgpt) although your are limited to 25 questions / suggestions / instructions every 3 hours. However if you are clever you can put multiple tasks in one query. So \"Create a master plan to grow your YouTube subscribers to 10k, create this in bullet points and with each bullet point write a paragraph explaining how you would do it\" and so on. results in that case have been pretty good. Plus it remembers, for example bullet point 3 and you can say \" bullet point 3 is pretty good but can you revise and integrate into the original response\". it does seem to understand and remember quite well", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-05-13T08:04:15Z", "updated_at": "2023-05-13T08:04:15Z"}, {"author": "@dfsed1057", "text": "Am learning between this and autogpt locally that there are memory issues. my theory is that 3.5turbo is more likely to hit those issues", "like_count": 2, "published_at": "2023-04-24T00:31:15Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-24T00:31:15Z"}, {"author": "@ThomasTomiczek", "text": "Ah, tasks - the limits are obious. This needs configurable agents so the agent, i.e., writing text has a setup that steers it in a more emotional and gung ho wording. Not that this can not be done, but \"personas\" is not something that gpt will put into such a task automatically. If the task to write the text was delegated to an author agent that could have \"use an appropriate persona\" as part of it's setup. A normal AI prompt setting up tasks just behaves as an AI - which is \"dry\".", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-05-01T15:54:17Z", "updated_at": "2023-05-01T15:54:17Z"}, {"author": "@Flo-Karuna", "text": "How do they get access to your youtube account? Are they actually doing actions, or just telling us what to do. I got a lot of responses on God Mode, but no actions actually happened.", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-05-19T03:13:52Z", "updated_at": "2023-05-19T03:13:52Z"}, {"author": "@funnyperson4016", "text": "What changed that enabled going from “computers will never get to AGI, they’ll never be creative, etc”\n\nTo what we have now? Was there one person that solved something?", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-07-20T22:04:46Z", "updated_at": "2023-07-20T22:04:46Z"}, {"author": "@jr-yn4lk", "text": "So you gotta give them your API key ? Isn't that unsafe ?", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-04-25T20:08:02Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-25T20:08:02Z"}, {"author": "@SacredOm369", "text": "So basically it sucks bro. LOL", "like_count": 3, "published_at": "2023-04-21T20:17:57Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-21T20:17:57Z"}, {"author": "@warpspeed8305", "text": "Just don't tell it about your youtube channel :) or youtube may disable monetization because of unusual activity.", "like_count": 1, "published_at": "2023-04-24T10:38:16Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-24T10:38:16Z"}, {"author": "@blue5659", "text": "That would be more views than this video", "like_count": 0, "published_at": "2023-04-24T10:06:28Z", "updated_at": "2023-04-24T10:06:28Z"}, {"author": "@PreciousEyeballs", "text": "Does it only work with GPT4 api. title: AutoGPT: The Next Big Thing? #ai #openai #gpt4 #autogpt

top_comments: [{"author": "@randomaccount2644", "text": "I think the popular dream is to let autoGPTs learn and think whatever they want and run whatever code they want while the human who needs to be supervising all this is sound asleep.\nSure, Auto-GPT is buggy at the moment, but it's getting improvements and patches in pursuit of full autonomy.
